SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules require separate client ledgers for each client, identified by name.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) mandates individual client ledgers identified by name and matter description.

SolAc.q: Money received for unpaid disbursements prior to a bill is client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) defines money for unpaid disbursements held pre-bill as client money.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the business side of a client ledger indicates the firm owes the client money.
SolAc.exp: A debit balance on the business side means the client owes the firm money (e.g., for a bill).

SolAc.q: Interest earned on a general client account belongs to the firm unless accounted for to the client.
SolAc.exp: Interest on general client accounts is usually paid to the firm's business account, then accounted to the client as a fair sum (Rule 7.1).

SolAc.q: When splitting a mixed payment cheque, the firm credits the Client Ledger Business Account for the non-client portion.
SolAc.exp: The non-client portion goes to the business account, crediting the business side of the client ledger to reduce client debt.

SolAc.q: A transfer of funds between two clients requires entries in the cash sheet.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers happen within the ledgers (Dr Client A, Cr Client B) and do not affect the bank/cash sheet.

SolAc.q: Client money must be paid into a client account promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3 requires prompt payment of client money into a client account.

SolAc.q: If a bill has been delivered, money held for costs becomes non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) implies money held for costs becomes non-client money once a bill is delivered (assuming it's for fees/paid disbursements).

SolAc.q: To withdraw client money for costs, a bill or written notification must be given first.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification before transferring client money for costs.

SolAc.q: A credit entry in the cash sheet (client account) represents money paid out.
SolAc.exp: In the firm's cash book, a credit reduces the asset/balance, representing a payment out.

SolAc.q: Receipt of a deposit as stakeholder is credited to the seller's client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Stakeholder funds are credited to a separate 'Stakeholder' ledger, not the seller's, until completion.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as agent, VAT is recorded separately in the VAT account.
SolAc.exp: As agent, the gross amount (including VAT) is debited to the client ledger; VAT is not separated.

SolAc.q: Petty cash is client money.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash belongs to the firm and is non-client money.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm uses a Third Party Managed Account (TPMA).
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance requires firms to notify the SRA of TPMA use.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the client side of a client ledger is a breach of the rules.
SolAc.exp: It means the firm has paid out more than it holds for that client, using other clients' funds.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations of client accounts must be done at least every five weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 mandates reconciliations at least every five weeks.

SolAc.q: Under the 'Principal' method for disbursements, the firm uses client money to pay the third party.
SolAc.exp: As principal, the firm is liable and must use business money (non-client money) to pay.

SolAc.q: Accounting records must be retained for at least six years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 sets a minimum retention period of six years for accounting records.

SolAc.q: A transfer from business to client account debits the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing from business to pay client account debits the business ledger (increasing client debt/reducing firm cash).

SolAc.q: Abatement of a bill requires a debit to the Profit Costs account.
SolAc.exp: Abatement reduces revenue, so the Profit Costs account (originally credited) is debited.

SolAc.q: Money held in a joint account is subject to all SRA Accounts Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 9.1 states Part 2 does not apply to joint accounts (except Rules 8.2 and 8.4).

SolAc.q: Legal Aid Agency payments for costs must be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(b) exempts Legal Aid payments for costs from the client account requirement.

SolAc.q: Writing off a bad debt involves crediting the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the ledger wipes the debt owed by the client.

SolAc.q: If a cheque is dishonoured, the firm must correct the client account immediately.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires immediate correction of breaches/shortfalls.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules do not apply to employees of a firm.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.1 states the rules apply to authorised bodies, managers, AND employees.

SolAc.q: Mixed payments can be paid entirely into the client account if the non-client element is transferred promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 permits this, provided prompt allocation/transfer occurs.

SolAc.q: VAT on a bill is credited to the VAT Account.
SolAc.exp: Recording the bill involves crediting Profit Costs and crediting VAT Account (liability to HMRC).

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held as a trustee.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) includes money held as trustee or holder of a specified office.

SolAc.q: An accountant's report is always required if a firm holds client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.2 provides exemptions (e.g., Legal Aid or low average/max balance).

SolAc.q: If a firm holds a deposit as agent, the funds are credited to the stakeholder ledger.
SolAc.exp: As agent, funds belong to the seller and are credited to the seller's client ledger.

SolAc.q: Transfers between clients require written authority from both parties.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance states authority is needed from both lender and borrower.

SolAc.q: A separate designated client account must include the client's name in its title.
SolAc.exp: This distinguishes it from the general client account.

SolAc.q: Reimbursement of a paid disbursement from a client is client money.
SolAc.exp: It reimburses the firm for a cost already incurred, so it is non-client money.

SolAc.q: Withdrawing client money requires a debit to the Cash Sheet Client Account.
SolAc.exp: A withdrawal reduces the bank balance, so it is a Credit to the Cash Sheet.

SolAc.q: Rule 5.1 allows withdrawal of client money on the SRA's written authorisation.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(c) permits withdrawal with SRA authorisation or in prescribed circumstances.

SolAc.q: When a firm acts for a lender without a separate ledger, the lender's bill is debited to the borrower's ledger.
SolAc.exp: The borrower usually pays, so the debt is recorded on their ledger.

SolAc.q: If a client pays a bill by transfer from client account, the firm debits the Client Ledger Client Account.
SolAc.exp: This withdraws funds from the client side to pay the business side.

SolAc.q: Prescribed circumstances for withdrawing residual balances apply to amounts under £500.
SolAc.exp: SRA prescribed circumstances for self-authorised withdrawal to charity apply to balances ≤£500.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules prohibit using a client account as a banking facility.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly forbids providing banking facilities.

SolAc.q: A firm must keep a central record of all bills.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates a central record of bills/notifications of costs.

SolAc.q: Payment of a disbursement as principal requires a debit to the VAT account for the VAT element.
SolAc.exp: As principal, VAT is separated and debited to the VAT account (input tax).

SolAc.q: Funds in a TPMA are client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.1 confirms TPMA funds are not client money as they aren't held by the firm.

SolAc.q: Rule 12.2 exemption applies if the average balance is under £10,000 and max is under £250,000.
SolAc.exp: Both conditions (average ≤£10k, max ≤£250k) must be met for the exemption.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must be signed by the COFA or a manager.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires sign-off by the COFA or a manager.

SolAc.q: A transfer from client account to business account requires a credit to the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the business ledger records the receipt/payment of the debt.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned when there is no longer a proper reason to hold it.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 mandates prompt return of funds.

SolAc.q: The standard rate of VAT for legal services is 15%.
SolAc.exp: Standard VAT rate is 20%.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses a TPMA, it must obtain regular statements from the provider.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 requires regular statements.

SolAc.q: In double entry, a Debit to the Client Ledger Client Account decreases the balance held for the client.
SolAc.exp: A debit on the client side represents a withdrawal/reduction of funds.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as agent, the firm debits the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: As agent, payment is from client funds, debiting the Client Ledger *Client* Account.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules require client money to be kept separate from business money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.1 mandates the separation of client and business funds.

SolAc.q: Funds for unpaid disbursements must always be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) classifies funds for unpaid disbursements as client money (pre-bill).

SolAc.q: A client account can be used as a banking facility for a client's convenience.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly prohibits using the client account as a banking facility.

SolAc.q: Interest on a general client account is typically paid into the business account.
SolAc.exp: Banks usually pay interest to the business account, after which the firm accounts to the client.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as an agent, the VAT is separated in the ledger.
SolAc.exp: Under the agency method, VAT is not separated; the gross amount is recorded.

SolAc.q: Transfers between clients require a debit to the transferring client's ledger.
SolAc.exp: Debiting the transferring client's ledger reduces their balance.

SolAc.q: Mixed payments can be split at the bank at the time of deposit.
SolAc.exp: This is a valid method to handle mixed payments under Rule 4.2.

SolAc.q: A bill of costs must be delivered before transferring money for fees.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification before transfer.

SolAc.q: Client account reconciliations are required every 5 weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 sets the reconciliation frequency at least every five weeks.

SolAc.q: A debit entry in the Cash Sheet Client Account represents money paid in.
SolAc.exp: In the firm's cash book, a debit represents an increase in the asset (money received).

SolAc.q: Funds held as a stakeholder are credited to the seller's client ledger.
SolAc.exp: They are credited to a separate stakeholder ledger until completion.

SolAc.q: The 'Principal' method for disbursements requires using business money.
SolAc.exp: As principal, the firm is liable and must pay from its own funds (business money).

SolAc.q: Petty cash expenses are recorded on the client side of the client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash is business money; expenses are debited to the business side.

SolAc.q: A TPMA is considered a type of client account under the Rules.
SolAc.exp: TPMA funds are not client money; Rule 11.1 distinguishes them.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the client side of a ledger is a breach.
SolAc.exp: It indicates the firm has used other clients' funds.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must be signed off by the COFA or a manager.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 mandates sign-off by a manager or COFA.

SolAc.q: Under the 'Agency' method, the firm uses client money to pay the disbursement.
SolAc.exp: The firm acts on behalf of the client, using client funds.

SolAc.q: Accounting records must be kept for 6 years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 mandates a six-year retention period.

SolAc.q: Transferring from business to client account involves debiting the business cash sheet.
SolAc.exp: It involves crediting the business cash sheet (money out) and debiting the client cash sheet (money in).

SolAc.q: Abating a bill involves debiting the VAT account for the reduction.
SolAc.exp: The VAT liability is reduced, so the VAT account is debited.

SolAc.q: Joint accounts are fully subject to Part 2 of the Accounts Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 9.1 exempts joint accounts from most of Part 2.

SolAc.q: Legal Aid payments for costs can be paid into the business account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(b) allows this exemption.

SolAc.q: Writing off a bad debt requires a debit to the Bad Debts ledger.
SolAc.exp: The expense/loss is recorded by debiting Bad Debts.

SolAc.q: Immediate replacement of funds is required for dishonoured cheques causing a shortfall.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires immediate rectification of shortfalls.

SolAc.q: Employees are not personally responsible for compliance with the Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.1 states the rules apply to employees as well.

SolAc.q: Client money received as cash must be paid into the client account promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3 applies to all forms of client money, including cash.

SolAc.q: VAT on a bill is a credit to the Profit Costs account.
SolAc.exp: VAT is credited to the VAT Account, not Profit Costs.

SolAc.q: Money held as a trustee is not client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) explicitly includes trust money as client money.

SolAc.q: An accountant's report is mandatory if client money held exceeds £250,000.
SolAc.exp: Exceeding the £250,000 maximum balance removes the exemption (Rule 12.2).

SolAc.q: Deposits held as agent are credited to the stakeholder ledger.
SolAc.exp: As agent, funds belong to the client and are credited to their ledger.

SolAc.q: Written authority is needed from both parties for inter-client transfers.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance mandates written authority from lender and borrower.

SolAc.q: Separate designated client accounts do not need the word 'client' in the title.
SolAc.exp: All client accounts must include the word 'client' (Rule 3.2).

SolAc.q: Reimbursement for a paid disbursement is non-client money.
SolAc.exp: It repays the firm, so it belongs to the firm.

SolAc.q: Withdrawing client money requires a credit to the Cash Sheet Client Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the cash sheet reduces the balance.

SolAc.q: Withdrawals are permitted on the SRA's written authorisation.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(c) allows this.

SolAc.q: Lender's fees are typically debited to the borrower's ledger if no separate ledger exists.
SolAc.exp: The borrower pays, so the debt sits on their ledger.

SolAc.q: Paying a bill from client funds involves debiting the Client Ledger Client Account.
SolAc.exp: This withdraws funds from the client side.

SolAc.q: Residual balances under £500 can be donated to charity without SRA authorisation.
SolAc.exp: Prescribed circumstances allow this self-authorisation.

SolAc.q: Using a client account to hold funds for a non-legal transaction is permitted.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 requires a link to regulated services.

SolAc.q: A central record of bills must be maintained.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates this.

SolAc.q: Paying a disbursement as principal debits the VAT account.
SolAc.exp: Input tax is recoverable and debited to the VAT account.

SolAc.q: TPMA funds are held by the firm.
SolAc.exp: They are held by a third party.

SolAc.q: The exemption for accountant's reports applies if the average balance is £10,000 or less.
SolAc.exp: Assuming the max balance condition is also met (Rule 12.2).

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must check the bank statement against the cash book only.
SolAc.exp: They must also check against the client ledger total (Rule 8.3).

SolAc.q: Crediting the business ledger records a payment by the client.
SolAc.exp: It reduces the client's debt to the firm.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned promptly when the matter concludes.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 requires prompt return.

SolAc.q: The VAT rate for legal services is 20%.
SolAc.exp: Standard rate is 20%.

SolAc.q: Regular statements are required for TPMAs.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 mandates this.

SolAc.q: A debit to the client ledger client account increases the client's funds.
SolAc.exp: A debit reduces the funds (withdrawal).

SolAc.q: As agent, a firm debits the client ledger business account for disbursements.
SolAc.exp: As agent, they debit the client ledger *client* account.

SolAc.q: Client ledgers must show a clear running balance.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(b) and SRA Guidance require maintaining a running total of liabilities to clients.

SolAc.q: Money held for a specified office holder appointment is client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) explicitly includes money held as a trustee or specified office holder.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules apply to foreign lawyers registered with the SRA.
SolAc.exp: The rules apply to all authorised bodies and regulated individuals, including registered foreign lawyers.

SolAc.q: Firms must have systems to ensure compliance with the Accounts Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.2 and the introduction require systems and controls appropriate to the firm's nature/volume.

SolAc.q: A debit on the Cash Sheet Business Account indicates money paid out.
SolAc.exp: In double entry, a debit to a cash/bank asset account represents money *received* (increasing the asset).

SolAc.q: Client money can be withheld from a client account if the client agrees in writing.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(c) allows an alternative arrangement in writing to hold money outside a client account.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses a TPMA, it must obtain regular statements.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 requires regular statements to ensure accurate reflection of transactions.

SolAc.q: A credit balance on the business side of a client ledger means the firm owes the client.
SolAc.exp: A credit on the business side means the client has overpaid or the firm owes them money (non-client money).

SolAc.q: The SRA must authorise all withdrawals from client accounts.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawals are permitted for the purpose held or on client instructions (Rule 5.1); SRA authorisation is rare.

SolAc.q: Money received for professional disbursements already paid is client money.
SolAc.exp: Reimbursement for paid disbursements is non-client money (business money).

SolAc.q: A 'mixed payment' must be split between client and business accounts.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 requires prompt allocation to the correct accounts.

SolAc.q: Firms must keep records of all bills issued.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates a central record of all bills/notifications of costs.

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held as a stakeholder.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(b) includes money held on behalf of a third party (e.g., stakeholder) as client money.

SolAc.q: A debit entry in a client ledger (client side) reduces the client's balance.
SolAc.exp: Debiting the client side represents a withdrawal, reducing the amount held for the client.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules allow firms to use client accounts for banking facilities.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly prohibits providing banking facilities; funds must relate to regulated services.

SolAc.q: Client account reconciliations must be done every month.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires reconciliations at least every *five weeks*.

SolAc.q: A separate designated client account is for monies of a specific client.
SolAc.exp: It is an account for a single client, referencing them in the title.

SolAc.q: Interest must be paid on money held in a TPMA.
SolAc.exp: TPMA funds are not client money; Rule 7 (Interest) doesn't apply directly.

SolAc.q: Managers are jointly and severally liable for compliance.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.2 confirms joint and several responsibility for managers.

SolAc.q: Breaches of the rules must be corrected promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 mandates prompt correction upon discovery.

SolAc.q: Client money can be withdrawn to pay a charity if the beneficiary cannot be found.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(c) allows withdrawal for charity in prescribed circumstances (residual balances).

SolAc.q: If a firm uses the 'Principal' method, they debit the VAT Account when paying the disbursement.
SolAc.exp: As principal, input VAT is recoverable, so it is debited to the VAT account.

SolAc.q: A transfer from client to business account for costs requires a bill to be delivered first.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification before transfer.

SolAc.q: Accountant's reports are required for all firms holding client money.
SolAc.exp: Exemptions exist (Rule 12.2) for low balances or Legal Aid funds.

SolAc.q: Client ledgers must include a description of the matter.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) requires client name and matter description.

SolAc.q: A 'Credit' to the Cash Sheet Client Account decreases the bank balance.
SolAc.exp: In the cash book, a credit represents a payment out, reducing the asset.

SolAc.q: Money received for unpaid disbursements is non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) classifies money for *unpaid* disbursements (pre-bill) as client money.

SolAc.q: A firm must pay interest if the amount is fair.
SolAc.exp: Rule 7.1 requires accounting for a 'fair sum' of interest.

SolAc.q: Withdrawals from client account must be supervised.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.2 requires appropriate authorisation and supervision of withdrawals.

SolAc.q: Records must be retained for six years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 sets the retention period at six years.

SolAc.q: A client account must be at a bank in England and Wales.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.1 specifies the account must be at a bank/building society in England & Wales.

SolAc.q: If a cheque is dishonoured, the shortfall must be replaced.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires replacement of any shortfall/improper withdrawal.

SolAc.q: VAT on a bill is a credit to the VAT Account.
SolAc.exp: Output tax (VAT charged) is a liability, so it is credited to the VAT account.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned as soon as there is no proper reason to hold it.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 mandates prompt return.

SolAc.q: A 'mixed payment' can be paid into the business account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 allows mixed payments into either account, provided prompt transfer follows.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules apply to Third Party Managed Accounts.
SolAc.exp: Most rules don't apply; Rule 11.1 governs TPMAs specifically (funds aren't 'client money').

SolAc.q: A firm acts for a lender and borrower; the lender's fees are usually debited to the borrower's ledger.
SolAc.exp: Borrowers typically pay lender fees; without a separate ledger, it goes on the borrower's.

SolAc.q: Petty cash must be recorded in the client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash is non-client money; expenses are debited to the business side, not client side.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must include a comparison with the client ledger total.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires reconciling bank statement, cash book, and client ledger total.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the business side of a client ledger is a breach.
SolAc.exp: A debit on the business side is normal (client owes firm); a debit on the *client* side is a breach.

SolAc.q: A transfer between clients involves a withdrawal from the bank.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers are ledger-only adjustments; no cash moves in/out of the bank.

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held for paid disbursements.
SolAc.exp: Reimbursement for paid disbursements is business money.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm holds a residual balance of £400.
SolAc.exp: Notification/authorisation is needed for >£500; ≤£500 can be self-authorised.

SolAc.q: Interest on a general client account must be paid to the client.
SolAc.exp: Rule 7.1 requires accounting for a 'fair sum' (unless agreed otherwise).

SolAc.q: A transfer from client to business account requires a Credit to the Client Ledger Client Account.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing from client account is a Debit to the Client Ledger Client Account.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules allow firms to use client accounts for non-legal services.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 requires funds to relate to *regulated* services.

SolAc.q: Money held in a joint account is client money.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance confirms joint account funds are client money, though Part 2 rules largely don't apply.

SolAc.q: A bill must be delivered before transferring money for disbursements.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3 applies to 'costs' (fees); disbursements *incurred* can be reimbursed, but best practice often involves a bill/notification.

SolAc.q: The business side of the client ledger records non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a)(ii) allocates non-client money and bills to the business side.

SolAc.q: Firms must keep a central record of all bills.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates this record.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules require separate client ledgers for each client, identified by name.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) mandates individual client ledgers identified by name and matter description.

SolAc.q: Money received for unpaid disbursements prior to a bill is client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) defines money for unpaid disbursements held pre-bill as client money.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the business side of a client ledger indicates the firm owes the client money.
SolAc.exp: A debit balance on the business side means the client owes the firm money (e.g., for a bill).

SolAc.q: Interest earned on a general client account belongs to the firm unless accounted for to the client.
SolAc.exp: Interest on general client accounts is usually paid to the firm's business account, then accounted to the client as a fair sum (Rule 7.1).

SolAc.q: When splitting a mixed payment cheque, the firm credits the Client Ledger Business Account for the non-client portion.
SolAc.exp: The non-client portion goes to the business account, crediting the business side of the client ledger to reduce client debt.

SolAc.q: A transfer of funds between two clients requires entries in the cash sheet.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers happen within the ledgers (Dr Client A, Cr Client B) and do not affect the bank/cash sheet.

SolAc.q: Client money must be paid into a client account promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3 requires prompt payment of client money into a client account.

SolAc.q: If a bill has been delivered, money held for costs becomes non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) implies money held for costs becomes non-client money once a bill is delivered (assuming it's for fees/paid disbursements).

SolAc.q: To withdraw client money for costs, a bill or written notification must be given first.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification before transferring client money for costs.

SolAc.q: A credit entry in the cash sheet (client account) represents money paid out.
SolAc.exp: In the firm's cash book, a credit reduces the asset/balance, representing a payment out.

SolAc.q: Receipt of a deposit as stakeholder is credited to the seller's client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Stakeholder funds are credited to a separate 'Stakeholder' ledger, not the seller's, until completion.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as agent, VAT is recorded separately in the VAT account.
SolAc.exp: As agent, the gross amount (including VAT) is debited to the client ledger; VAT is not separated.

SolAc.q: Petty cash is client money.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash belongs to the firm and is non-client money.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm uses a Third Party Managed Account (TPMA).
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance requires firms to notify the SRA of TPMA use.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the client side of a client ledger is a breach of the rules.
SolAc.exp: It means the firm has paid out more than it holds for that client, using other clients' funds.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations of client accounts must be done at least every five weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 mandates reconciliations at least every five weeks.

SolAc.q: Under the 'Principal' method for disbursements, the firm uses client money to pay the third party.
SolAc.exp: As principal, the firm is liable and must use business money (non-client money) to pay.

SolAc.q: Accounting records must be retained for at least six years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 sets a minimum retention period of six years for accounting records.

SolAc.q: A transfer from business to client account debits the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing from business to pay client account debits the business ledger (increasing client debt/reducing firm cash).

SolAc.q: Abatement of a bill requires a debit to the Profit Costs account.
SolAc.exp: Abatement reduces revenue, so the Profit Costs account (originally credited) is debited.

SolAc.q: Money held in a joint account is subject to all SRA Accounts Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 9.1 states Part 2 does not apply to joint accounts (except Rules 8.2 and 8.4).

SolAc.q: Legal Aid Agency payments for costs must be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(b) exempts Legal Aid payments for costs from the client account requirement.

SolAc.q: Writing off a bad debt involves crediting the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the ledger wipes the debt owed by the client.

SolAc.q: If a cheque is dishonoured, the firm must correct the client account immediately.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires immediate correction of breaches/shortfalls.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules do not apply to employees of a firm.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.1 states the rules apply to authorised bodies, managers, AND employees.

SolAc.q: Mixed payments can be paid entirely into the client account if the non-client element is transferred promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 permits this, provided prompt allocation/transfer occurs.

SolAc.q: VAT on a bill is credited to the VAT Account.
SolAc.exp: Recording the bill involves crediting Profit Costs and crediting VAT Account (liability to HMRC).

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held as a trustee.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) includes money held as trustee or holder of a specified office.

SolAc.q: An accountant's report is always required if a firm holds client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.2 provides exemptions (e.g., Legal Aid or low average/max balance).

SolAc.q: If a firm holds a deposit as agent, the funds are credited to the stakeholder ledger.
SolAc.exp: As agent, funds belong to the seller and are credited to the seller's client ledger.

SolAc.q: Transfers between clients require written authority from both parties.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance states authority is needed from both lender and borrower.

SolAc.q: A separate designated client account must include the client's name in its title.
SolAc.exp: This distinguishes it from the general client account.

SolAc.q: Reimbursement of a paid disbursement from a client is client money.
SolAc.exp: It reimburses the firm for a cost already incurred, so it is non-client money.

SolAc.q: Withdrawing client money requires a debit to the Cash Sheet Client Account.
SolAc.exp: A withdrawal reduces the bank balance, so it is a Credit to the Cash Sheet.

SolAc.q: Rule 5.1 allows withdrawal of client money on the SRA's written authorisation.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(c) permits withdrawal with SRA authorisation or in prescribed circumstances.

SolAc.q: When a firm acts for a lender without a separate ledger, the lender's bill is debited to the borrower's ledger.
SolAc.exp: The borrower usually pays, so the debt is recorded on their ledger.

SolAc.q: If a client pays a bill by transfer from client account, the firm debits the Client Ledger Client Account.
SolAc.exp: This withdraws funds from the client side to pay the business side.

SolAc.q: Prescribed circumstances for withdrawing residual balances apply to amounts under £500.
SolAc.exp: SRA prescribed circumstances for self-authorised withdrawal to charity apply to balances ≤£500.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules prohibit using a client account as a banking facility.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly forbids providing banking facilities.

SolAc.q: A firm must keep a central record of all bills.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates a central record of bills/notifications of costs.

SolAc.q: Payment of a disbursement as principal requires a debit to the VAT account for the VAT element.
SolAc.exp: As principal, VAT is separated and debited to the VAT account (input tax).

SolAc.q: Funds in a TPMA are client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.1 confirms TPMA funds are not client money as they aren't held by the firm.

SolAc.q: Rule 12.2 exemption applies if the average balance is under £10,000 and max is under £250,000.
SolAc.exp: Both conditions (average ≤£10k, max ≤£250k) must be met for the exemption.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must be signed by the COFA or a manager.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires sign-off by the COFA or a manager.

SolAc.q: A transfer from client account to business account requires a credit to the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the business ledger records the receipt/payment of the debt.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned when there is no longer a proper reason to hold it.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 mandates prompt return of funds.

SolAc.q: The standard rate of VAT for legal services is 15%.
SolAc.exp: Standard VAT rate is 20%.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses a TPMA, it must obtain regular statements from the provider.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 requires regular statements.

SolAc.q: In double entry, a Debit to the Client Ledger Client Account decreases the balance held for the client.
SolAc.exp: A debit on the client side represents a withdrawal/reduction of funds.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as agent, the firm debits the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: As agent, payment is from client funds, debiting the Client Ledger *Client* Account.

SolAc.q: Client ledgers must show a clear running balance.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(b) and SRA Guidance require maintaining a running total of liabilities to clients.

SolAc.q: Money held for a specified office holder appointment is client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) explicitly includes money held as a trustee or specified office holder.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules apply to foreign lawyers registered with the SRA.
SolAc.exp: The rules apply to all authorised bodies and regulated individuals, including registered foreign lawyers.

SolAc.q: Firms must have systems to ensure compliance with the Accounts Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.2 and the introduction require systems and controls appropriate to the firm's nature/volume.

SolAc.q: A debit on the Cash Sheet Business Account indicates money paid out.
SolAc.exp: In double entry, a debit to a cash/bank asset account represents money *received* (increasing the asset).

SolAc.q: Client money can be withheld from a client account if the client agrees in writing.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(c) allows an alternative arrangement in writing to hold money outside a client account.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses a TPMA, it must obtain regular statements.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 requires regular statements to ensure accurate reflection of transactions.

SolAc.q: A credit balance on the business side of a client ledger means the firm owes the client.
SolAc.exp: A credit on the business side means the client has overpaid or the firm owes them money (non-client money).

SolAc.q: The SRA must authorise all withdrawals from client accounts.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawals are permitted for the purpose held or on client instructions (Rule 5.1); SRA authorisation is rare.

SolAc.q: Money received for professional disbursements already paid is client money.
SolAc.exp: Reimbursement for paid disbursements is non-client money (business money).

SolAc.q: A 'mixed payment' must be split between client and business accounts.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 requires prompt allocation to the correct accounts.

SolAc.q: Firms must keep records of all bills issued.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates a central record of all bills/notifications of costs.

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held as a stakeholder.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(b) includes money held on behalf of a third party (e.g., stakeholder) as client money.

SolAc.q: A debit entry in a client ledger (client side) reduces the client's balance.
SolAc.exp: Debiting the client side represents a withdrawal, reducing the amount held for the client.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules allow firms to use client accounts for banking facilities.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly prohibits providing banking facilities; funds must relate to regulated services.

SolAc.q: Client account reconciliations must be done every month.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires reconciliations at least every *five weeks*.

SolAc.q: A separate designated client account is for monies of a specific client.
SolAc.exp: It is an account for a single client, referencing them in the title.

SolAc.q: Interest must be paid on money held in a TPMA.
SolAc.exp: TPMA funds are not client money; Rule 7 (Interest) doesn't apply directly.

SolAc.q: Managers are jointly and severally liable for compliance.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.2 confirms joint and several responsibility for managers.

SolAc.q: Breaches of the rules must be corrected promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 mandates prompt correction upon discovery.

SolAc.q: Client money can be withdrawn to pay a charity if the beneficiary cannot be found.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(c) allows withdrawal for charity in prescribed circumstances (residual balances).

SolAc.q: If a firm uses the 'Principal' method, they debit the VAT Account when paying the disbursement.
SolAc.exp: As principal, input VAT is recoverable, so it is debited to the VAT account.

SolAc.q: A transfer from client to business account for costs requires a bill to be delivered first.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification before transfer.

SolAc.q: Accountant's reports are required for all firms holding client money.
SolAc.exp: Exemptions exist (Rule 12.2) for low balances or Legal Aid funds.

SolAc.q: Client ledgers must include a description of the matter.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) requires client name and matter description.

SolAc.q: A 'Credit' to the Cash Sheet Client Account decreases the bank balance.
SolAc.exp: In the cash book, a credit represents a payment out, reducing the asset.

SolAc.q: Money received for unpaid disbursements is non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) classifies money for *unpaid* disbursements (pre-bill) as client money.

SolAc.q: A firm must pay interest if the amount is fair.
SolAc.exp: Rule 7.1 requires accounting for a 'fair sum' of interest.

SolAc.q: Withdrawals from client account must be supervised.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.2 requires appropriate authorisation and supervision of withdrawals.

SolAc.q: Records must be retained for six years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 sets the retention period at six years.

SolAc.q: A client account must be at a bank in England and Wales.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.1 specifies the account must be at a bank/building society in England & Wales.

SolAc.q: If a cheque is dishonoured, the shortfall must be replaced.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires replacement of any shortfall/improper withdrawal.

SolAc.q: VAT on a bill is a credit to the VAT Account.
SolAc.exp: Output tax (VAT charged) is a liability, so it is credited to the VAT account.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned as soon as there is no proper reason to hold it.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 mandates prompt return.

SolAc.q: A 'mixed payment' can be paid into the business account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 allows mixed payments into either account, provided prompt transfer follows.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules apply to Third Party Managed Accounts.
SolAc.exp: Most rules don't apply; Rule 11.1 governs TPMAs specifically (funds aren't 'client money').

SolAc.q: A firm acts for a lender and borrower; the lender's fees are usually debited to the borrower's ledger.
SolAc.exp: Borrowers typically pay lender fees; without a separate ledger, it goes on the borrower's.

SolAc.q: Petty cash must be recorded in the client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash is non-client money; expenses are debited to the business side, not client side.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must include a comparison with the client ledger total.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires reconciling bank statement, cash book, and client ledger total.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the business side of a client ledger is a breach.
SolAc.exp: A debit on the business side is normal (client owes firm); a debit on the *client* side is a breach.

SolAc.q: A transfer between clients involves a withdrawal from the bank.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers are ledger-only adjustments; no cash moves in/out of the bank.

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held for paid disbursements.
SolAc.exp: Reimbursement for paid disbursements is business money.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm holds a residual balance of £400.
SolAc.exp: Notification/authorisation is needed for >£500; ≤£500 can be self-authorised.

SolAc.q: Interest on a general client account must be paid to the client.
SolAc.exp: Rule 7.1 requires accounting for a 'fair sum' (unless agreed otherwise).

SolAc.q: A transfer from client to business account requires a Credit to the Client Ledger Client Account.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing from client account is a Debit to the Client Ledger Client Account.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules allow firms to use client accounts for non-legal services.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 requires funds to relate to *regulated* services.

SolAc.q: Money held in a joint account is client money.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance confirms joint account funds are client money, though Part 2 rules largely don't apply.

SolAc.q: A bill must be delivered before transferring money for disbursements.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3 applies to 'costs' (fees); disbursements *incurred* can be reimbursed, but best practice often involves a bill/notification.

SolAc.q: The business side of the client ledger records non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a)(ii) allocates non-client money and bills to the business side.

SolAc.q: Firms must keep a central record of all bills.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates this record.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules require separate client ledgers for each client, identified by name.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) mandates individual client ledgers identified by name and matter description.

SolAc.q: Money received for unpaid disbursements prior to a bill is client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) defines money for unpaid disbursements held pre-bill as client money.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the business side of a client ledger indicates the firm owes the client money.
SolAc.exp: A debit balance on the business side means the client owes the firm money (e.g., for a bill).

SolAc.q: Interest earned on a general client account belongs to the firm unless accounted for to the client.
SolAc.exp: Interest on general client accounts is usually paid to the firm's business account, then accounted to the client as a fair sum (Rule 7.1).

SolAc.q: When splitting a mixed payment cheque, the firm credits the Client Ledger Business Account for the non-client portion.
SolAc.exp: The non-client portion goes to the business account, crediting the business side of the client ledger to reduce client debt.

SolAc.q: A transfer of funds between two clients requires entries in the cash sheet.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers happen within the ledgers (Dr Client A, Cr Client B) and do not affect the bank/cash sheet.

SolAc.q: Client money must be paid into a client account promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3 requires prompt payment of client money into a client account.

SolAc.q: If a bill has been delivered, money held for costs becomes non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) implies money held for costs becomes non-client money once a bill is delivered (assuming it's for fees/paid disbursements).

SolAc.q: To withdraw client money for costs, a bill or written notification must be given first.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification before transferring client money for costs.

SolAc.q: A credit entry in the cash sheet (client account) represents money paid out.
SolAc.exp: In the firm's cash book, a credit reduces the asset/balance, representing a payment out.

SolAc.q: Receipt of a deposit as stakeholder is credited to the seller's client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Stakeholder funds are credited to a separate 'Stakeholder' ledger, not the seller's, until completion.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as agent, VAT is recorded separately in the VAT account.
SolAc.exp: As agent, the gross amount (including VAT) is debited to the client ledger; VAT is not separated.

SolAc.q: Petty cash is client money.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash belongs to the firm and is non-client money.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm uses a Third Party Managed Account (TPMA).
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance requires firms to notify the SRA of TPMA use.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the client side of a client ledger is a breach of the rules.
SolAc.exp: It means the firm has paid out more than it holds for that client, using other clients' funds.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations of client accounts must be done at least every five weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 mandates reconciliations at least every five weeks.

SolAc.q: Under the 'Principal' method for disbursements, the firm uses client money to pay the third party.
SolAc.exp: As principal, the firm is liable and must use business money (non-client money) to pay.

SolAc.q: Accounting records must be retained for at least six years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 sets a minimum retention period of six years for accounting records.

SolAc.q: A transfer from business to client account debits the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing from business to pay client account debits the business ledger (increasing client debt/reducing firm cash).

SolAc.q: Abatement of a bill requires a debit to the Profit Costs account.
SolAc.exp: Abatement reduces revenue, so the Profit Costs account (originally credited) is debited.

SolAc.q: Money held in a joint account is subject to all SRA Accounts Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 9.1 states Part 2 does not apply to joint accounts (except Rules 8.2 and 8.4).

SolAc.q: Legal Aid Agency payments for costs must be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(b) exempts Legal Aid payments for costs from the client account requirement.

SolAc.q: Writing off a bad debt involves crediting the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the ledger wipes the debt owed by the client.

SolAc.q: If a cheque is dishonoured, the firm must correct the client account immediately.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires immediate correction of breaches/shortfalls.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules do not apply to employees of a firm.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.1 states the rules apply to authorised bodies, managers, AND employees.

SolAc.q: Mixed payments can be paid entirely into the client account if the non-client element is transferred promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 permits this, provided prompt allocation/transfer occurs.

SolAc.q: VAT on a bill is credited to the VAT Account.
SolAc.exp: Recording the bill involves crediting Profit Costs and crediting VAT Account (liability to HMRC).

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held as a trustee.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) includes money held as trustee or holder of a specified office.

SolAc.q: An accountant's report is always required if a firm holds client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.2 provides exemptions (e.g., Legal Aid or low average/max balance).

SolAc.q: If a firm holds a deposit as agent, the funds are credited to the stakeholder ledger.
SolAc.exp: As agent, funds belong to the seller and are credited to the seller's client ledger.

SolAc.q: Transfers between clients require written authority from both parties.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance states authority is needed from both lender and borrower.

SolAc.q: A separate designated client account must include the client's name in its title.
SolAc.exp: This distinguishes it from the general client account.

SolAc.q: Reimbursement of a paid disbursement from a client is client money.
SolAc.exp: It reimburses the firm for a cost already incurred, so it is non-client money.

SolAc.q: Withdrawing client money requires a debit to the Cash Sheet Client Account.
SolAc.exp: A withdrawal reduces the bank balance, so it is a Credit to the Cash Sheet.

SolAc.q: Rule 5.1 allows withdrawal of client money on the SRA's written authorisation.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(c) permits withdrawal with SRA authorisation or in prescribed circumstances.

SolAc.q: When a firm acts for a lender without a separate ledger, the lender's bill is debited to the borrower's ledger.
SolAc.exp: The borrower usually pays, so the debt is recorded on their ledger.

SolAc.q: If a client pays a bill by transfer from client account, the firm debits the Client Ledger Client Account.
SolAc.exp: This withdraws funds from the client side to pay the business side.

SolAc.q: Prescribed circumstances for withdrawing residual balances apply to amounts under £500.
SolAc.exp: SRA prescribed circumstances for self-authorised withdrawal to charity apply to balances ≤£500.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules prohibit using a client account as a banking facility.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly forbids providing banking facilities.

SolAc.q: A firm must keep a central record of all bills.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates a central record of bills/notifications of costs.

SolAc.q: Payment of a disbursement as principal requires a debit to the VAT account for the VAT element.
SolAc.exp: As principal, VAT is separated and debited to the VAT account (input tax).

SolAc.q: Funds in a TPMA are client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.1 confirms TPMA funds are not client money as they aren't held by the firm.

SolAc.q: Rule 12.2 exemption applies if the average balance is under £10,000 and max is under £250,000.
SolAc.exp: Both conditions (average ≤£10k, max ≤£250k) must be met for the exemption.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must be signed by the COFA or a manager.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires sign-off by the COFA or a manager.

SolAc.q: A transfer from client account to business account requires a credit to the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Crediting the business ledger records the receipt/payment of the debt.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned when there is no longer a proper reason to hold it.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 mandates prompt return of funds.

SolAc.q: The standard rate of VAT for legal services is 15%.
SolAc.exp: Standard VAT rate is 20%.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses a TPMA, it must obtain regular statements from the provider.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 requires regular statements.

SolAc.q: In double entry, a Debit to the Client Ledger Client Account decreases the balance held for the client.
SolAc.exp: A debit on the client side represents a withdrawal/reduction of funds.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as agent, the firm debits the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: As agent, payment is from client funds, debiting the Client Ledger *Client* Account.

SolAc.q: A transfer of funds between two clients requires a withdrawal from the client bank account.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers are ledger entries only (Dr Client A, Cr Client B) and do not affect the bank balance.

SolAc.q: When 'splitting' a mixed cheque at the bank, the firm records a debit to the Cash Sheet Business Account for the non-client element.
SolAc.exp: Splitting involves paying the non-client portion directly into the business account, requiring a debit to that cash sheet.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses petty cash for a client expense, it must credit the Cash Sheet Petty Cash account.
SolAc.exp: Money leaving the petty cash pot is recorded as a credit to the Cash Sheet Petty Cash.

SolAc.q: To pay a bill from client funds under Rule 4.3, the firm must first debit the Client Ledger (Business side) to record the bill.
SolAc.exp: The bill must be recorded (Dr Client Ledger Business) before the transfer from client account (Cr Client Ledger Client) can settle it.

SolAc.q: When a client reimburses petty cash, the money must be paid into the petty cash box immediately.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash reimbursement is non-client money and must be paid into the business bank account, not the cash box.

SolAc.q: If a firm acts for a lender and borrower, mortgage funds are client money under Rule 2.1(a).
SolAc.exp: Mortgage funds received are held for the lender (a client/third party) and fall under the definition of client money.

SolAc.q: Upon completion of a property purchase, the deposit held as stakeholder is transferred to the seller's ledger.
SolAc.exp: At completion, the stakeholding ends and the funds belong to the seller, requiring a transfer to their ledger.

SolAc.q: Paying Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) is a withdrawal of client money for the purpose for which it is held.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(a) permits withdrawals for the purpose for which the money is held, such as paying SDLT.

SolAc.q: If a bill includes anticipated disbursements, the money for them must be transferred to the business account immediately.
SolAc.exp: SRA guidance expects money for anticipated disbursements to remain in the client account until they are actually paid.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on the client side of a client ledger indicates the firm has breached the rules.
SolAc.exp: A debit balance on the client side means the firm has paid out more than it holds for that client (using other clients' money).

SolAc.q: When transferring costs from a lender's ledger to a borrower's ledger, the firm Debits the Lender's Business Ledger.
SolAc.exp: The firm Credits the Lender's Business Ledger (clearing their debt) and Debits the Borrower's Business Ledger (assigning the debt).

SolAc.q: If a client sends £500 for costs and £200 for a bill, the entire £700 can be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 allows mixed payments into the client account, provided the non-client element (£200) is transferred promptly.

SolAc.q: A firm must obtain an accountant's report if the maximum client balance exceeds £250,000.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.2(b) exemption requires the maximum balance to be £250,000 or less; exceeding this triggers the report requirement.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as principal, the VAT is debited to the Client Ledger (Business side).
SolAc.exp: As principal, VAT is debited to the VAT account initially, not the client ledger (until billed).

SolAc.q: Before transferring funds between clients, the firm must obtain written authority from the lender only.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance states written authority should be obtained from *both* the lender and the borrower.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm holds a residual balance of £600.
SolAc.exp: Prescribed circumstances for self-authorised withdrawal only apply to balances of £500 or less.

SolAc.q: A transfer from business to client account requires a Debit to the Client Ledger Business Account.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing from business account to pay client account is a Debit to the Client Ledger Business Account.

SolAc.q: If a firm uses a TPMA, they are exempt from keeping accounting records for those funds.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.2 requires firms to obtain regular statements and ensure they accurately reflect transactions.

SolAc.q: A credit entry in the Cash Sheet Client Account represents money flowing out of the bank.
SolAc.exp: In the cash sheet (firm's view of the bank), a Credit entry reduces the balance (payment out).

SolAc.q: If a solicitor is a signatory on a client's own account, they must reconcile the account every 5 weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 10.1(b) applies Rule 8.3 (reconciliations) to the operation of a client's own account.

SolAc.q: When issuing a bill, the VAT element is Credited to the VAT Account.
SolAc.exp: The firm creates a liability to HMRC (or records output tax), so the VAT Account is Credited.

SolAc.q: Money held for the Legal Aid Agency for costs must be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(b) provides an exemption for payments from the Legal Aid Agency for costs; they can go to the business account.

SolAc.q: If a client pays a bill by cheque, this is considered client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) excludes money received for fees *after* a bill is delivered; it is non-client money.

SolAc.q: A firm can transfer money for costs from the client account before delivering a bill if the client agrees orally.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) explicitly requires a bill or *written* notification of costs before any transfer.

SolAc.q: When a firm pays a disbursement as agent, the client's business ledger is debited.
SolAc.exp: As agent, the payment is usually made from client funds, debiting the *Client Ledger Client Account*.

SolAc.q: Rule 2.1 defines client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1 is the primary definition clause for client money in the SRA Accounts Rules.

SolAc.q: Accounting records must be updated chronologically.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1 requires accurate, contemporaneous, and chronological records.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules apply to employees of authorised bodies.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.1 confirms the rules apply to authorised bodies, managers, and employees.

SolAc.q: A client account must include the word 'client' in its title.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.2(b) mandates the inclusion of the word 'client' to distinguish it from office accounts.

SolAc.q: Client money must be returned to the client promptly when there is no proper reason to hold it.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.5 mandates the prompt return of client money when no longer needed.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations must be signed off by a COFA or manager.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires the reconciliation record to be signed off by the COFA or a manager.

SolAc.q: A 'mixed payment' consists of client money and money belonging to the firm.
SolAc.exp: SRA Glossary defines a mixed payment as one including both client money and non-client money.

SolAc.q: Records of bills must be kept for at least six years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 applies the six-year retention period to all accounting records, including bills.

SolAc.q: Petty cash is considered non-client money.
SolAc.exp: Petty cash belongs to the firm and does not fall under the Rule 2.1 definition of client money.

SolAc.q: VAT is charged at 20% on profit costs.
SolAc.exp: Standard rate VAT for legal services is currently 20%.

SolAc.q: Rule 4.1 requires client money to be kept separate from business money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.1 is the fundamental rule requiring separation of client and firm money.

SolAc.q: A 'disbursement' includes general office overheads like telephone calls.
SolAc.exp: The SRA Glossary definition of disbursements excludes office expenses like postage and telephone calls.

SolAc.q: Firms must obtain bank statements at least every five weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.2 requires statements to be obtained at least every five weeks for reconciliation.

SolAc.q: A 'stakeholder' holds money for one party only.
SolAc.exp: A stakeholder holds money (usually a deposit) on trust for *both* parties until a specific event.

SolAc.q: Accountant's reports are mandatory for all firms regardless of the amount of client money held.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.2 provides exemptions based on the source (Legal Aid) or amount (Average/Max balance) of funds.

SolAc.q: Client ledgers must include the client's name.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) requires client ledgers to be identified by the client's name and matter description.

SolAc.q: A 'Credit' entry in a client ledger (client side) increases the client's balance.
SolAc.exp: Money received for a client is Credited to their ledger, increasing the amount held.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules allow the use of a client account to pass money through for non-legal matters.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 prohibits using the client account for banking facilities; funds must relate to regulated services.

SolAc.q: Interest must be calculated and paid on money held in a joint account.
SolAc.exp: Part 2 rules (including Rule 7 on interest) generally do not apply to joint accounts (Rule 9.1).

SolAc.q: The 'Cash Sheet' is a record of transactions passing through the bank account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(c) requires a cash book (cash sheet) showing a running total of transactions through the account.

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held for unpaid disbursements before a bill is delivered.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) includes unpaid disbursements as client money if held prior to delivery of a bill.

SolAc.q: A 'separate designated client account' is a general client account holding pooled funds.
SolAc.exp: A separate designated account is for a specific client; a general account holds pooled funds.

SolAc.q: Firms must account for interest on money held in a Third Party Managed Account.
SolAc.exp: Money in a TPMA is not client money; Rule 7 (Interest) does not apply to it.

SolAc.q: Breaches of the Accounts Rules must be corrected promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires prompt correction of any breaches upon discovery.

SolAc.q: The Business Ledger records money the client owes to the firm.
SolAc.exp: The business side of the client ledger records bills and non-client money, showing the client's debt.

SolAc.q: If a solicitor holds a deposit as a stakeholder, the receipt is credited to the seller's client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Money held as a stakeholder is credited to a separate 'stakeholder' ledger, not the seller's client ledger, until completion.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as an agent using client money, the firm must record a debit in the VAT account.
SolAc.exp: As an agent, no separate VAT entry is made; the gross amount is debited to the client ledger (client side).

SolAc.q: A transfer of funds between two clients of the same firm requires entries in the cash sheet.
SolAc.exp: Inter-client transfers occur only within the ledgers (Dr Client A, Cr Client B) and do not impact the cash sheet.

SolAc.q: If a client pays a bill of costs using non-client money, the entry is Credit Client Ledger (Business side).
SolAc.exp: Receipt of non-client money (bill payment) is credited to the business side of the client ledger to reduce the debt.

SolAc.q: Under Rule 4.3, a firm must deliver a bill of costs before transferring client money to the business account to pay that bill.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.3(a) requires a bill or written notification of costs be given prior to any transfer for costs.

SolAc.q: Money held in a Third Party Managed Account (TPMA) is defined as client money under Rule 2.1.
SolAc.exp: Rule 11.1(a) clarifies that money in a TPMA is not held or received by the firm and is therefore not client money.

SolAc.q: A mixed payment paid into the client account must have the non-client element transferred out promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 4.2 requires prompt allocation of funds to the correct account, meaning non-client money must be moved.

SolAc.q: When a bill is abated, the firm must Debit the Profit Costs account.
SolAc.exp: Abatement reduces the income recorded, so the Profit Costs account (originally credited) is debited.

SolAc.q: Writing off a bad debt requires a Debit to the Bad Debts account and a Credit to the Client Ledger (Business side).
SolAc.exp: Crediting the client ledger wipes the debt owed by the client; the balancing debit is to the Bad Debt account.

SolAc.q: If a solicitor acts as an agent for a seller, the deposit received is credited directly to the seller's client ledger.
SolAc.exp: Unlike stakeholder funds, agent funds belong to the client immediately and are credited to their ledger.

SolAc.q: Interest earned on a general client account must be paid into the client account directly by the bank.
SolAc.exp: Interest on a general account is usually paid to the business account, then the firm accounts to the client for a fair sum.

SolAc.q: When paying a disbursement as principal, the firm debits the Client Ledger (Business side) for the net amount.
SolAc.exp: As principal, the net cost is debited to the client's business ledger and VAT is recorded separately in the VAT account.

SolAc.q: A firm may withdraw client money for a purpose other than that for which it was held without written instructions.
SolAc.exp: Rule 5.1(a)-(b) requires withdrawal only for the specific purpose or upon receipt of instructions.

SolAc.q: If a cheque from a client is dishonoured, the firm must immediately correct any resulting shortfall in the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 6.1 requires immediate rectification of any shortfall/breach upon discovery.

SolAc.q: When a lender client has a separate ledger, mortgage funds are first credited to the lender's ledger.
SolAc.exp: If a separate ledger exists, funds are credited there first, then transferred to the borrower upon completion.

SolAc.q: The SRA requires firms to obtain an accountant's report if the average client account balance exceeds £10,000.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.2(b) exemptions only apply if the average is ≤£10,000 AND the maximum is ≤£250,000.

SolAc.q: Petty cash payments on behalf of a client are recorded as a Debit in the Client Ledger (Client side).
SolAc.exp: Petty cash is non-client money; payments are debited to the Client Ledger (Business side).

SolAc.q: If a firm uses the 'Agency' method for a disbursement, they must separate the VAT element in the ledger.
SolAc.exp: Under the Agency method, VAT is not separated; the gross amount is recorded in the client ledger.

SolAc.q: A client pays a bill of £1,200 (£1,000 + VAT) by transfer from client account. The entry in the Cash Sheet (Client) is a Debit.
SolAc.exp: Withdrawing money from the client account is a Credit entry in the Cash Sheet (Client).

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules allow a client account to be used as a banking facility for clients.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.3 strictly prohibits using the client account as a banking facility.

SolAc.q: A firm acts for a lender without a separate ledger. The bill to the lender is debited to the borrower's business ledger.
SolAc.exp: Without a separate lender ledger, the borrower covers the fees, so the debt is recorded on the borrower's ledger.

SolAc.q: When transferring funds between clients, the firm must obtain written authority from both parties.
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance requires written authority from both the lender and borrower for inter-client loans/transfers.

SolAc.q: Under the 'Principal' method, the VAT on a disbursement is charged to the client only when the firm issues its own bill.
SolAc.exp: The VAT sits in the VAT account until the firm bills the client, at which point it moves to the client ledger.

SolAc.q: If a firm ceases to hold client money, the SRA can still require a final accountant's report.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.4 allows the SRA to require a report when a firm ceases to operate a client account.

SolAc.q: A withdrawal from a separate designated client account requires four ledger entries in total.
SolAc.exp: It requires two entries: Debit Client Ledger (Designated), Credit Cash Sheet (Designated). Transfers require four.

SolAc.q: Client money includes money held as a trustee.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(c) defines money held as a trustee or holder of a specified office as client money.

SolAc.q: A 'mixed payment' contains both client money and non-client money.
SolAc.exp: SRA Glossary and Rule 4.2 define a mixed payment as one including both client and non-client money.

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules apply only to the managers of an authorised body.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.1 states the rules apply to authorised bodies, their managers, AND employees.

SolAc.q: Accounting records must be retained for at least five years.
SolAc.exp: Rule 13.1 requires accounting records to be stored and retained for at least six years.

SolAc.q: Reconciliations of the client account must be carried out at least every five weeks.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 mandates reconciliations be completed at least every five weeks.

SolAc.q: Managers of an authorised body are jointly and severally responsible for compliance with the Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 1.2 states managers are jointly and severally responsible for compliance.

SolAc.q: Money held in a joint account is considered client money under Part 2 of the Rules.
SolAc.exp: Rule 9.1 states Part 2 (Client Money) does not apply to joint accounts (except 8.2 and 8.4).

SolAc.q: A 'disbursement' includes office expenses such as postage and courier fees.
SolAc.exp: The SRA Glossary definition explicitly excludes office expenses like postage from being disbursements.

SolAc.q: The standard rate of VAT charged on legal services is 20%.
SolAc.exp: Legal services are subject to the standard VAT rate of 20%.

SolAc.q: Client money must be paid into a client account immediately.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3 requires client money to be paid in 'promptly', not immediately.

SolAc.q: Rule 8.4 requires a central record of all bills of costs.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.4 mandates a readily accessible central record of all bills given.

SolAc.q: Money received for paid disbursements is classified as client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.1(d) only includes *unpaid* disbursements; reimbursement for paid ones is non-client money.

SolAc.q: An accountant's report must be obtained within six months of the end of the accounting period.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.1(a) sets the deadline at six months after the accounting period ends.

SolAc.q: The SRA must be notified if a firm uses a Third Party Managed Account (TPMA).
SolAc.exp: SRA Guidance requires firms to notify the SRA if they use a TPMA.

SolAc.q: Rule 7.1 requires firms to pay a 'commercial rate' of interest.
SolAc.exp: Rule 7.1 requires accounting for a 'fair sum' of interest, not necessarily a commercial rate.

SolAc.q: A client account name must include the name of the authorised body and the word 'client'.
SolAc.exp: Rule 3.2 requires the account name to include the body's name and the word 'client'.

SolAc.q: If a client account reconciliation shows a difference, it must be resolved promptly.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.3 requires differences shown by reconciliation to be promptly investigated and resolved.

SolAc.q: Firms are required to have a separate client ledger for every client.
SolAc.exp: Rule 8.1(a) requires records in client ledgers identified by the client's name.

SolAc.q: In double entry book-keeping, a Debit (DR) entry signifies money coming into a bank account.
SolAc.exp: For the cash sheet (bank record), a Debit represents money received/paid in.

SolAc.q: Legal Aid Agency payments for costs must always be paid into the client account.
SolAc.exp: Rule 2.3(b) provides an exception for Legal Aid Agency payments for costs.

SolAc.q: The SRA can disqualify an accountant from preparing reports.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.6 allows the SRA to disqualify an accountant for misconduct or lack of care.

SolAc.q: A debit balance on a client ledger (client side) indicates a breach of the rules.
SolAc.exp: A debit balance means more money was paid out than held, implying other clients' money was used.

SolAc.q: Rule 12.1 requires an accountant's report even if the firm never held client money.
SolAc.exp: Rule 12.1 only applies if the firm has held or received client money (or operated joint/client own accounts).

SolAc.q: Firms must account for interest to clients even if the amount is negligible, unless agreed otherwise.
SolAc.exp: While Rule 7.1 requires a fair sum, Rule 7.2 allows written agreements to alter this (often setting de minimis limits).

SolAc.q: The SRA Accounts Rules 2019 replaced the Solicitors Accounts Rules 2011.
SolAc.exp: The context implies the current rules discussed are the SRA Accounts Rules (effective 2019).

business.q: A sole trader must register with Companies House.
business.exp: Only with HMRC.

business.q: Partners in a general partnership are jointly and severally liable.
business.exp: Unlimited liability for firm debts.

business.q: LLP must have at least two designated members.
business.exp: Compliance duty.

business.q: Shareholders own the company's assets.
business.exp: The Company owns its assets (separate personality).

business.q: Pre-emption rights apply to transfer of existing shares.
business.exp: Usually applies to allotment of new shares only.

business.q: Special Resolution requires a simple majority (>50%).
business.exp: Requires 75% majority.

business.q: Written resolutions can be used by Public Limited Companies (PLCs).
business.exp: Private companies only.

business.q: Directors must avoid conflicts of interest (s.175).
business.exp: Strict fiduciary duty.

business.q: A Fixed Charge allows the company to deal with the asset freely.
business.exp: Asset is locked/controlled by lender.

business.q: Wrongful trading creates personal liability for directors.
business.exp: If insolvency ignored and loss not minimized.

business.q: Company secretary is mandatory for private companies.
business.exp: Optional since CA 2006.

business.q: PSC Register tracks People with Significant Control (>25%).
business.exp: Transparency requirement.

business.q: Dividends can be paid from capital.
business.exp: Must be paid from distributable profits.

business.q: Corporate Veil can be lifted for fraud.
business.exp: Gilford Motor Co v Horne.

business.q: Partnership agreement must be in writing.
business.exp: Can be oral or implied by conduct.

business.q: Directors can be removed by Ordinary Resolution.
business.exp: s.168 CA 2006 (requires Special Notice).

business.q: Floating Charge crystallizes on winding up.
business.exp: Becomes a fixed charge.

business.q: Preference shares usually carry voting rights.
business.exp: Usually non-voting, but priority dividends.

business.q: Shadow Director is not liable for breach of duties.
business.exp: Liable as if they were a de facto director.

business.q: Substantial Property Transactions (>£100k) need shareholder approval.
Company can ratify a director's breach of duty.
business.exp: By Ordinary Resolution.

business.q: Administration aim is to sell assets piecemeal.
business.exp: Primary aim is rescuing company as going concern.

business.q: Partners pay Corporation Tax on profits.
business.exp: Partners pay Income Tax on their share.

business.q: UK Companies pay Corp Tax on worldwide profits.
business.exp: If UK resident.

business.q: VAT registration is mandatory if turnover >£90k.
business.exp: Taxable turnover threshold.

business.q: Insider Dealing is a civil offence only.
business.exp: It is a criminal offence (CJA 1993).

business.q: Money Laundering 'tipping off' is an offence.
business.exp: Under POCA 2002.

business.q: Quorum for board meeting is always 2.
business.exp: Unless articles say 1 (e.g. sole director).

business.q: Poll vote counts: 1 member 1 vote.
business.exp: Poll is 1 share 1 vote.

business.q: Derivative Claim is brought by shareholder for the company.
business.exp: Exception to Foss v Harbottle.

business.q: Unfair Prejudice (s.994) protects minority shareholders.
business.exp: Against management conduct.

business.q: Pre-incorporation contracts bind the company automatically.
business.exp: Promoter is personally liable.

business.q: Company name changed by Special Resolution.
business.exp: Form NM01.

business.q: Directors must declare interest in proposed transaction (s.177).
business.exp: Duty of disclosure.

business.q: General Partnership is a separate legal entity.
business.exp: Unless LLP or Scottish Partnership.

business.q: Bribes received by fiduciary are kept in 'slush fund'.
business.exp: Held on constructive trust for principal.

business.q: Liquidators pay shareholders before creditors.
business.exp: Shareholders are last.

business.q: Fraudulent Trading requires proof of dishonesty.
business.exp: Criminal intent required.

business.q: Holding company is liable for subsidiary debts.
business.exp: Separate legal personality applies.

business.q: AGM is mandatory for private companies.
business.exp: Mandatory only for Public Companies.

business.q: Director service contract >2 years needs approval.
Filing new director appointment: 14 days.
business.exp: Form AP01.

business.q: Connected persons include director's step-children.
Class rights variation requires 75% consent of class.
business.exp: Protection of class rights.

business.q: Loan to director usually needs shareholder approval.
Income Tax is payable on dividends.
business.exp: Dividend Tax rates apply.

business.q: BADR (Entrepreneurs Relief) reduces CGT to 10%.
business.exp: Business Asset Disposal Relief.

business.q: Agency by estoppel arises from representation.
business.exp: Principal held out agent as having authority.

business.q: Undisclosed principal can sue on contract.
business.exp: General rule of agency.

business.q: Agency terminates automatically on death.
business.exp: Operation of law.

business.q: Accounts Filing (Private): 9 months.
business.exp: From accounting reference date.

business.q: Accounts Filing (Public): 6 months.
business.exp: From accounting reference date.

business.q: Register Charge (MR01): 21 days.
business.exp: From creation of charge.

business.q: Special Resolution filing: 15 days.
business.exp: To Companies House.

business.q: VAT Return deadline: 1 month 7 days.
business.exp: From end of period.

business.q: Failure to disclose (s.330 POCA) applies to work outside the regulated sector.
business.exp: The s.330 offence applies only to information received in the course of business in the regulated sector.

business.q: A solicitor acts in the 'regulated sector' when buying a business entity for a client.
business.exp: Schedule 9 POCA includes participating in the buying and selling of business entities.

business.q: Tipping off (s.333A) applies if a solicitor discloses a money laundering investigation to a client.
business.exp: It is an offence to disclose that a report has been made if it is likely to prejudice an investigation.

business.q: A solicitor is liable for s.328 if they merely suspect an arrangement facilitates using criminal property.
business.exp: The mens rea for s.328 is knowledge or suspicion.

business.q: Authorised disclosure under s.338 must always be made before the prohibited act.
business.exp: Disclosure can be made during or after the act if there is a good reason for the delay (s.338(3)).

business.q: Enhanced CDD is optional for clients established in high-risk third countries.
business.exp: Regulation 33(1)(b) MLR 2017 makes Enhanced CDD mandatory for high-risk third countries.

business.q: A solicitor can rely on a third party's CDD without remaining liable for failures.
business.exp: Regulation 39; the solicitor remains liable for any failure to comply with CDD requirements.

business.q: Occasional transactions of 500 Euros require standard CDD.
business.exp: Regulation 27(1)(b) triggers CDD only for occasional transactions exceeding 1,000 Euros.

business.q: Simplified CDD is permitted if a transaction presents a low risk of money laundering.
business.exp: Regulation 37 allows simplified CDD where the risk of money laundering is determined to be low.

business.q: Ongoing monitoring of a business relationship includes scrutinizing source of funds.
business.exp: Regulation 28(11) requires scrutiny of transactions including source of funds where necessary.

business.q: Advising a client on the merits of buying specific shares is a regulated activity.
business.exp: Article 53(1) RAO; advising on the merits of a specified investment is a specified activity.

business.q: Generic advice on the benefits of investing in shares requires FCA authorisation.
business.exp: Generic advice is not a specified activity; the advice must relate to a specific investment.

business.q: The Article 70 RAO exclusion applies to the sale of 40% of a company's voting shares.
business.exp: Article 70 requires 50% or more of voting shares, or acquisition of day-to-day control.

business.q: A firm can use the s.327 FSMA exemption if it receives and keeps a commission.
business.exp: s.327(3) requires the firm to account to the client for any commission received.
