business.q: Arranging the sale of shares is excluded if it is a 'necessary part' of legal services.
business.exp: Article 67 RAO excludes activities that are a necessary part of other professional services.

business.q: A solicitor acting as a nominee shareholder is carrying out a regulated activity.
business.exp: Safeguarding and administering investments (Article 40 RAO) is a specified activity.

business.q: To rely on s.327 FSMA, the activity must arise out of or be complementary to legal services.
business.exp: SRA Scope Rule 2 imposes this condition for the 'incidental' exemption.

business.q: Breaching the General Prohibition under s.19 FSMA is a criminal offence.
business.exp: s.23 FSMA makes it an offence to carry on regulated activities without authorisation or exemption.

business.q: The 'Is/Is Not' test applies to identifying the beneficial owner of a company.
business.exp: The 'Is/Is Not' test relates to discretionary trusts; beneficial ownership uses the 25% rule.

business.q: An acquisition of day-to-day control of a company falls within the Article 70 exclusion.
business.exp: Article 70(1)(c) RAO covers transactions for the acquisition of day-to-day control.

business.q: A solicitor can transfer client funds to a charity if the client is missing.
business.exp: SRA Accounts Rules allow payment to charity for small balances if client cannot be traced.

business.q: If a client asks to use the client account like a bank, the solicitor must refuse.
business.exp: Rule 3.3 SRA Accounts Rules prohibits using the client account as a banking facility.

business.q: The threshold for a 'material interest' in a close company is 5%.
business.exp: For tax purposes regarding loans to participators, material interest is >5%.

business.q: A solicitor must verify a client's identity even if they have acted for them for 10 years.
business.exp: Regulation 28(11) requires ongoing monitoring and keeping documents up to date.

business.q: Accepting £2,000 in cash from a client for fees is a high-risk money laundering indicator.
business.exp: Large cash payments are a classic warning sign of money laundering.

business.q: POCA stands for Proceeds of Crime Act.
business.exp: The primary UK anti-money laundering legislation.

business.q: MLR stands for Money Laundering Regulations.
business.exp: Refers to the Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds Regulations 2017.

business.q: CDD stands for Client Due Diligence.
business.exp: It stands for Customer Due Diligence (Regulation 27 MLR).

business.q: MLRO stands for Money Laundering Reporting Officer.
business.exp: The nominated officer responsible for disclosures.

business.q: NCA stands for National Crime Agency.
business.exp: The body to whom SARs (Suspicious Activity Reports) are sent.

business.q: PEP stands for Politically Exposed Person.
business.exp: Individuals entrusted with prominent public functions.

business.q: FSMA stands for Financial Services and Markets Act.
business.exp: The key statute governing financial services in the UK.

business.q: FCA stands for Financial Conduct Authority.
business.exp: One of the two main regulators for financial services.

business.q: PRA stands for Prudential Regulation Authority.
business.exp: The other main regulator for financial services.

business.q: RAO stands for Regulated Activities Order.
business.exp: Secondary legislation defining specified investments and activities.

business.q: SRA stands for Solicitors Regulation Authority.
business.exp: The regulatory body for solicitors in England and Wales.

business.q: FATF stands for Financial Action Task Force.
business.exp: Inter-governmental body dealing with money laundering.

business.q: SAR stands for Suspicious Activity Report.
business.exp: The report made to the NCA regarding money laundering suspicions.

business.q: Placement is the first stage of money laundering.
business.exp: Introducing illegal proceeds into the financial system.

business.q: Layering involves moving funds to distance them from the source.
business.exp: The second stage of money laundering.

business.q: Integration involves re-entering funds into the economy as legitimate.
business.exp: The final stage of money laundering.

business.q: A 'Warning Sign' is an indicator of potential money laundering.
business.exp: Also known as a red flag.

business.q: S.327 POCA creates the offence of concealing criminal property.
business.exp: One of the principal money laundering offences.

business.q: S.328 POCA creates the offence of entering into an arrangement.
business.exp: Involves facilitating the use or control of criminal property.

business.q: S.329 POCA creates the offence of acquiring criminal property.
business.exp: Also covers using or possessing criminal property.

business.q: Criminal Property constitutes a person's benefit from criminal conduct.
business.exp: Defined in s.340 POCA 2002.

business.q: Subjective suspicion is sufficient for a s.330 failure to disclose offence.
business.exp: S.330 includes an objective test: 'reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting'.

business.q: The 'General Prohibition' prevents carrying on regulated activities without authorisation.
Shares are a 'Specified Investment' under the RAO.
business.exp: Article 76 RAO lists shares as a specified investment.

business.q: Land is a 'Specified Investment' under the RAO.
business.exp: Direct ownership of land is not a specified investment (though mortgages are).

business.q: A new partner is automatically liable for debts incurred before they joined.
business.exp: s.17(1) PA 1890; a new partner does not become liable for pre-existing debts.

business.q: A retiring partner remains liable for debts incurred while they were a partner.
business.exp: s.17(2) PA 1890; retirement does not automatically discharge existing liabilities.

business.q: Notice in the London Gazette protects a retiring partner from liability to existing customers.
business.exp: s.36(1) PA 1890; actual notice is required for those who dealt with the firm before.

business.q: A non-partner can be liable for firm debts if they are 'held out' as a partner.
business.exp: s.14 PA 1890; liability arises if credit is given on the faith of the representation.

business.q: A partner binds the firm to any contract they sign, regardless of the business type.
business.exp: s.5 PA 1890; the act must be for carrying on business of the kind carried on by the firm.

business.q: A firm is bound by an unauthorized act if the third party did not know of the restriction.
business.exp: s.5 PA 1890; firm is bound unless the third party knew of the lack of authority or did not believe them to be a partner.

business.q: Partners are jointly and severally liable for contractual debts of the firm.
business.exp: s.9 PA 1890; partners are 'jointly' liable for debts/contracts (Joint & Several applies to torts s.10/12).

business.q: Introducing a new partner requires a majority vote under the PA 1890 default rules.
business.exp: s.24(7) PA 1890; unanimous consent of all existing partners is required.

business.q: A majority of partners can expel a partner for misconduct under the PA 1890.
business.exp: s.25 PA 1890; no majority can expel a partner unless the power is expressly conferred by agreement.

business.q: A partnership at will can be dissolved by notice at any time.
business.exp: s.26 PA 1890; any partner can determine the partnership by giving notice.

business.q: Property bought with partnership money is deemed to be partnership property.
business.exp: s.21 PA 1890; unless a contrary intention appears.

business.q: Partners contributing unequal capital are entitled to unequal profits under PA 1890.
business.exp: s.24(1) PA 1890; partners share capital and profits equally unless agreed otherwise.

business.q: A partner managing the business is entitled to a salary under default rules.
business.exp: s.24(6) PA 1890; no partner is entitled to remuneration for acting in the partnership business.

business.q: Changing the nature of the partnership business requires unanimous consent.
business.exp: s.24(8) PA 1890; ordinary matters are majority decided, but nature changes require unanimity.

business.q: An LLP member is considered an employee of the LLP for employment law purposes.
business.exp: s.4(4) LLPA 2000; a member is not employed by the LLP unless they would be if it were a partnership.

business.q: An LLP must have at least two designated members.
business.exp: s.8 LLPA 2000; required for administrative compliance (filing, signing accounts).

business.q: LLP members share capital and profits equally by default.
business.exp: Reg 7(1) LLP Regulations 2001; default provision in absence of agreement.

business.q: An LLP member can be expelled by majority vote under the default regulations.
business.exp: Reg 8 LLP Regulations 2001; no implied power to expel.

business.q: Money withdrawn by LLP members within 2 years of winding up can be clawed back.
business.exp: s.214A Insolvency Act 1986; applies specifically to LLPs.

business.q: An LLP is taxed as a body corporate.
business.exp: LLPs are tax transparent; members are taxed as partners.

business.q: A written partnership agreement overrides s.24 PA 1890 default provisions.
business.exp: s.19 PA 1890; rights and duties may be varied by consent (express or implied).

business.q: Death of a partner automatically dissolves a general partnership subject to agreement.
business.exp: s.33 PA 1890; dissolution occurs unless there is an agreement to the contrary.

business.q: A partner carrying on a competing business must account for profits.
business.exp: s.30 PA 1890; duty not to compete without consent.

business.q: Ordinary decision making in an LLP requires unanimity under default rules.
business.exp: Reg 7(6) LLP Regulations 2001; ordinary matters are decided by a majority.

business.q: An LLP needs to file a confirmation statement annually.
business.exp: LLPs are subject to the continuing registration regime like companies.

business.q: A general partnership is a separate legal entity.
business.exp: It is a relationship between persons, not a separate entity (unlike an LLP).

business.q: An LLP is a body corporate.
business.exp: s.1(2) LLPA 2000; it has legal personality separate from its members.

business.q: Partners in a general partnership have unlimited personal liability.
business.exp: They are personally liable for the firm's debts.

business.q: LLP members have limited liability.
business.exp: s.1(4) LLPA 2000; liability is limited to their capital contribution (usually).

business.q: The term 'Firm' refers to the partners collectively.
business.exp: s.4 PA 1890; persons entering partnership are called the firm.

business.q: PA 1890 stands for Partnership Act 1890.
business.exp: The primary legislation governing traditional partnerships.

business.q: LLPA 2000 stands for Limited Liability Partnerships Act 2000.
business.exp: The primary legislation creating LLPs.

business.q: A 'sleeping partner' is not liable for firm debts.
business.exp: All partners, active or sleeping, are liable for firm debts.

business.q: 'Joint and several' liability allows a creditor to sue one partner for the whole debt.
business.exp: Applies to torts (s.10/12 PA 1890); creditor can pursue any partner for full amount.

business.q: 'Tax transparency' means the entity itself pays no tax.
business.exp: Profits flow through to the partners who are taxed individually.

business.q: Form LL IN01 is used to incorporate an LLP.
business.exp: The prescribed form sent to Companies House.

business.q: A 'Designated Member' has administrative responsibilities in an LLP.
business.exp: Includes signing accounts and filing returns.

business.q: Partners owe fiduciary duties to each other.
business.exp: Duty of good faith, honesty, and disclosure (s.28-30).

business.q: 'Holding out' creates liability for non-partners.
business.exp: s.14 PA 1890; representing oneself as a partner creates liability.

business.q: 'Dissolution' brings a partnership to an end.
business.exp: The legal termination of the partnership relationship.

business.q: A 'Partnership at Will' has no fixed duration.
business.exp: s.26 PA 1890; can be terminated by notice at any time.

business.q: 'Novation' transfers liability from an outgoing to a new partner.
business.exp: A tripartite agreement between creditor, old partner, and new partner (s.17(3)).

business.q: 'Indemnity' protects a partner from personal loss incurred for the firm.
business.exp: s.24(2) PA 1890; firm must indemnify partners for proper payments.

business.q: 'Capital' is the money invested by partners.
business.exp: Distinct from income/profits.

business.q: 'Drawings' are advance payments of profit.
business.exp: Partners take drawings against expected profits.

business.q: Partners have a duty to render true accounts.
business.exp: s.28 PA 1890; duty to provide full information.

business.q: LLP members have a duty not to compete under default rules.
business.exp: Reg 7(9) LLP Regulations 2001; must account for profits from competing business.

business.q: A general partnership can create a floating charge.
business.exp: Only companies and LLPs can grant floating charges (unincorporated partnerships cannot).

business.q: An LLP must file annual accounts at Companies House.
business.exp: Unlike general partnerships, LLPs are subject to public filing requirements.

business.q: An LLP needs a PSC Register.
business.exp: LLPs must maintain a register of People with Significant Control.

business.q: A contract made before incorporation binds the company automatically.
business.exp: s.51 CA 2006; the promoter is personally liable unless agreed otherwise.

business.q: Private companies can pass a written resolution to remove a director.
business.exp: s.288(2)(a) CA 2006; removal of a director cannot be done by written resolution.

business.q: Short notice for a GM requires 90% consent for a private company with Model Articles.
business.exp: s.307(5) CA 2006; majority in number holding 90% of shares (unless articles say higher).

business.q: On a show of hands, a shareholder with 51% of shares has one vote.
business.exp: s.284(2) CA 2006; one vote per person present, regardless of shareholding.

business.q: Shareholders holding 3% of voting capital can require directors to call a GM.
business.exp: s.303 CA 2006; the threshold is 5% of paid-up voting share capital.

business.q: A special resolution requires a majority of exactly 75%.
business.exp: s.283 CA 2006; requires a majority of 'not less than 75%'.

business.q: The quorum for a valid board meeting under Model Articles is one director.
business.exp: MA 11(2); the quorum is two (unless fixed otherwise or a sole director company).

business.q: To change a company name, form NM01 must be filed.
business.exp: Standard form for notice of change of name by resolution.

business.q: A company must file a copy of every ordinary resolution at Companies House.
business.exp: s.29/30 CA 2006; generally only Special Resolutions must be filed (with exceptions).

business.q: 14 clear days' notice means the day of the meeting is included.
business.exp: s.360 CA 2006; excludes day of notice and day of meeting.

business.q: If a written resolution receives 51% approval, it passes immediately.
business.exp: s.296 CA 2006; passes when the required majority is reached.

business.q: A shelf company conversion requires transferring the subscriber share.
business.exp: The share held by the formation agent must be transferred to the client.

business.q: Under s.33, a member can sue the company to enforce outsider rights.
business.exp: Eley v Positive Government Security; only membership rights are enforceable.

business.q: A company secretary is mandatory for a private limited company.
business.exp: s.270 CA 2006; optional for private companies, mandatory for public.

business.q: Directors can change the company's articles without shareholder approval.
business.exp: s.21 CA 2006; articles are amended by Special Resolution of shareholders.

business.q: Abstaining on a written resolution counts as a vote against.
business.exp: Majority is of 'total voting rights of eligible members', not just those responding.

business.q: A poll vote can be demanded by a member holding 10% of voting rights.
business.exp: s.321 / MA 44; 10% is the statutory threshold to demand a poll.

business.q: If notice is emailed, it is deemed served 24 hours later.
business.exp: s.1147 CA 2006; deemed service is 48 hours after sending.

business.q: A company must have an 'appropriate email address' registered.
business.exp: s.9(5)(aa) CA 2006 (added by ECCTA 2023); mandatory requirement.

business.q: Directors must register for PAYE only if the company has 5 employees.
business.exp: Must register if any employee is paid above the NI Lower Earnings Limit.

business.q: A PO Box can be used as a registered office address.
business.exp: s.86 CA 2006; must be an 'appropriate address' where delivery can be acknowledged.

business.q: A written resolution lapses after 28 days by default.
business.exp: s.297 CA 2006; 28 days unless articles specify otherwise.

business.q: The first accounting reference period ends on the anniversary of incorporation.
business.exp: s.391(4); ends on the last day of the month of the anniversary.

business.q: Companies House form AP01 is used to terminate a director's appointment.
business.exp: TM01 is for termination; AP01 is for appointment.

business.q: Corporate shareholders must appoint a representative to vote at meetings.
business.exp: s.323 CA 2006; allows appointment of corporate representatives.

business.q: Memorandum of Association acts as the company's rulebook.
business.exp: The Articles are the rulebook; the Memorandum is a historic snapshot.

business.q: Articles of Association form a contract between company and members.
business.exp: s.33 CA 2006; creates a statutory contract.

business.q: Model Articles are the default constitution for new companies.
business.exp: s.20 CA 2006; apply if no other articles registered.

business.q: Form IN01 is the application to register a company.
business.exp: The prescribed form for incorporation.

business.q: Certificate of Incorporation proves the company exists.
business.exp: Conclusive evidence of registration (s.15 CA 2006).

business.q: Promoter is the person who sets up the company.
business.exp: Takes procedural steps for formation.

business.q: Board Resolution is a decision of the directors.
business.exp: Taken at a board meeting.

business.q: Ordinary Resolution requires a simple majority (>50%).
Special Resolution requires at least 75%.
Quorum is the minimum number of people to hold a meeting.
business.exp: Business cannot be validly transacted without it.

business.q: Poll vote is one vote per share.
business.exp: s.284 CA 2006; reflects financial stake.

business.q: Show of hands is one vote per person.
business.exp: s.284 CA 2006; default voting method at GM.

business.q: Written Resolution is for private companies only.
General Meeting is a meeting of shareholders.
business.exp: Where shareholder resolutions are passed.

business.q: Proxy is a person appointed to vote for a shareholder.
Ultra Vires means acting beyond capacity.
business.exp: Historic doctrine; now restricted by s.31 CA 2006.

business.q: Entrenched articles require more than a special resolution to change.
business.exp: s.22 CA 2006; specific conditions for amendment.

business.q: PSC Register records People with Significant Control.
business.exp: Transparency requirement (s.790 CA 2006).

business.q: Statement of Capital details the shares issued.
business.exp: s.10 CA 2006 requirement on formation.

business.q: s.172 duty is to promote the success of the company.
business.exp: Primary director duty.

business.q: Subscriber is a first shareholder of the company.
business.exp: Signatory to the Memorandum.

business.q: Company Seal is mandatory for executing documents.
business.exp: Optional; documents can be signed by directors.

business.q: Shareholder Agreement is a private contract.
business.exp: Between shareholders; supplements articles.

business.q: Chairman usually has a casting vote under Model Articles.
business.exp: MA 13; to resolve deadlocks at board level.

business.q: Companies House is the UK registrar of companies.
business.exp: Maintains the public register.

business.q: A shadow director is exempt from the duties in the Companies Act 2006.
business.exp: s.251 CA 2006; duties generally apply to shadow directors.

business.q: Shareholders can remove a director using a written resolution.
business.exp: s.288(2)(a) CA 2006; removal must be at a meeting to allow the director to speak.

business.q: Special Notice of 28 days is required to remove a director.
business.exp: s.168(2) CA 2006; notice given to the company at least 28 days before the meeting.

business.q: The board must place a removal resolution on the agenda if Special Notice is received.
business.exp: Pedley v Inland Waterways; directors are not bound to place it on the agenda.

business.q: A Bushell v Faith clause gives weighted voting rights to a director-shareholder on removal.
business.exp: Valid mechanism to protect directors from removal by simple majority.

business.q: Under s.188, a service contract of exactly 2 years requires shareholder approval.
business.exp: s.188 CA 2006; approval is required for a guaranteed term of *more* than 2 years.

business.q: A wholly-owned subsidiary needs shareholder approval for a director's long-term service contract.
business.exp: s.188(6)(b) CA 2006; wholly-owned subsidiaries are exempt.

business.q: If s.188 is breached, the entire service contract is void.
business.exp: s.189(a) CA 2006; only the specific provision is void; it becomes terminable on reasonable notice.

business.q: A non-cash asset worth £90,000 is always a Substantial Property Transaction.
business.exp: s.191 CA 2006; if between £5k-£100k, it is only substantial if >10% of Net Asset Value.

business.q: A director's brother is a 'connected person' for SPT purposes.
business.exp: s.253 CA 2006; siblings are NOT connected persons.

business.q: A director's step-child is a 'connected person' for SPT purposes.
business.exp: s.253(2)(c) CA 2006; children and step-children are connected.

business.q: An SPT entered into without approval is voidable by the company.
business.exp: s.195(2) CA 2006; voidable unless restitution is impossible or third rights intervene.

business.q: Private companies (standalone) need shareholder approval to lend to a director.
business.exp: s.197 CA 2006; loan to a director requires Ordinary Resolution.

business.q: Private companies (standalone) need shareholder approval to lend to a director's spouse.
business.exp: s.200 CA 2006 (connected persons) applies to Public companies or their associates.

business.q: Expenditure on company business up to £50,000 is exempt from s.197 approval.
business.exp: s.204 CA 2006; exception for business expenditure.

business.q: s.172 requires a director to act in a way that *objectively* promotes success.
business.exp: s.172 CA 2006; the test is subjective ('act in the way *he considers*').

business.q: A director can rely on the s.175(3) exception for a transaction *with* the company.
business.exp: s.175(3) CA 2006; conflicts arising from transactions with the company fall under s.177, not s.175.

business.q: Directors of a private company can authorize a s.175 conflict.
business.exp: s.175(5) CA 2006; provided the constitution does not invalidate it.

business.q: Under Model Articles, an interested director can vote on the transaction.
business.exp: MA 14; interested directors cannot vote or count in the quorum.

business.q: Shareholders can ratify a director's negligence by ordinary resolution.
business.exp: s.239 CA 2006; the director and connected members cannot vote.

business.q: A director must declare an interest in a proposed transaction to the shareholders.
business.exp: s.177 CA 2006; the declaration is made to the *other directors*.

business.q: Accepting a benefit from a third party (s.176) can be authorized by the board.
business.exp: s.176 CA 2006; requires shareholder approval (no board authorization provision).

business.q: A director acts in breach of s.171 if they use powers for an improper purpose.
business.exp: s.171(b) CA 2006; duty to exercise powers only for the purposes conferred.

business.q: s.174 duty of care is judged purely by an objective standard.
business.exp: s.174 CA 2006; dual test (objective minimum + subjective upgrade for special skill).

business.q: A director's resignation must be accepted by the board to be effective.
business.exp: MA 18(f); resignation takes effect in accordance with its terms upon notification.

business.q: De jure directors are validly appointed at law.
business.exp: Standard appointed directors .

business.q: Minimum age for a director is 16.
Public companies must have at least two directors.
Private companies must have a company secretary.
business.exp: Optional under s.270 CA 2006 .

business.q: Shadow directors are professional advisors.
business.exp: s.251(2) CA 2006; advice given in professional capacity excluded .

business.q: s.171 is the duty to act within powers.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: s.172 is the duty to promote the success of the company.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: s.173 is the duty to exercise independent judgment.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: s.174 is the duty to exercise reasonable care, skill and diligence.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: s.175 is the duty to avoid conflicts of interest.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: s.176 is the duty not to accept benefits from third parties.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: s.177 is the duty to declare an interest in a proposed transaction.
business.exp: General duty .

business.q: A Substantial Property Transaction involves a non-cash asset >£100,000.
Asset value >£5,000 can be Substantial if >10% NAV.
A guarantee given for a director is a regulated transaction under s.197.
business.exp: Requires shareholder approval .

business.q: Quasi-loans involve the company paying a sum the director must reimburse.
Credit transactions involve supplying goods/services on credit.
s.168 CA 2006 requires an Ordinary Resolution to remove a director.
business.exp: Standard removal procedure .

business.q: Special Notice must be given to the company 28 days before the GM.
Directors' residential addresses are open to public inspection.
business.exp: Kept on a private register; service address is public .

business.q: Form AP01 is used to appoint a director.
business.exp: Companies House form .

business.q: Form TM01 is used to terminate a director.
business.exp: Companies House form .

business.q: Long-term service contracts require Ordinary Resolution approval.
The 'Guaranteed Term' excludes notice periods.
business.exp: It includes the notice period (s.188(3)(b)) .

business.q: Ratification of a breach of duty requires a Special Resolution.
business.exp: Ordinary Resolution (s.239) .

business.q: Shareholders can remove a director using the written resolution procedure.
business.exp: s.288(2)(a) CA 2006; removal must be at a meeting to allow the director to make representations .

business.q: A director who is also a shareholder can vote on their own removal resolution.
business.exp: Directors act in their capacity as shareholders and are entitled to vote in their own interest .

business.q: The board must place a removal resolution on the agenda if they receive Special Notice.
business.exp: Pedley v Inland Waterways Association; directors are not bound to place it on the agenda .

business.q: Shareholders holding 4% of voting capital can require directors to call a GM.
business.exp: s.303(1) CA 2006; the threshold is at least 5% of the paid-up voting share capital .

business.q: If directors accept a s.303 request, they must hold the GM within 28 days.
business.exp: s.304(1) CA 2006; they must *call* it within 21 days, to be *held* within 28 days of the notice .

business.q: Shareholders calling a GM under s.305 can recover expenses from the company.
business.exp: s.305(6) CA 2006; the company then recoups this from the defaulting directors' fees .

business.q: A Bushell v Faith clause requires a special resolution to remove a director.
business.exp: It gives weighted voting rights on an ordinary resolution, making it harder to pass .

business.q: A member can enforce a right to be the company solicitor under s.33 CA 2006.
business.exp: Eley v Positive Government Security; outsider rights are not enforceable under s.33 .

business.q: A Shareholders' Agreement can validly require unanimity to remove a director.
business.exp: It creates personal obligations between shareholders, though it cannot fetter the company's statutory powers .

business.q: A derivative claim can be brought in respect of a proposed act.
business.exp: s.260(3) CA 2006; covers actual or proposed acts or omissions .

business.q: A new shareholder cannot bring a derivative claim for a breach occurring before they joined.
business.exp: s.260(4) CA 2006; it is immaterial whether the cause of action arose before they became a member .

business.q: The court must refuse a derivative claim if the act has been validly ratified.
business.exp: s.263(2)(c) CA 2006; ratification is an absolute bar to continuing the claim .

business.q: Unfair prejudice (s.994) requires proof of bad faith by the directors.
business.exp: There is no requirement to show bad faith or conscious intent .

business.q: A minority discount is usually applied to shares in a quasi-partnership valuation.
business.exp: Courts generally do not impose a discount for minority shareholdings in quasi-partnerships .

business.q: Negligent management is automatic grounds for an unfair prejudice petition.
business.exp: Only if it amounts to serious/repeated mismanagement putting the share value at risk .

business.q: A s.303 request must state the text of the resolution.
business.exp: It must state the general nature of business; including the text is optional but recommended .

business.q: Directors must be given notice of a removal resolution even if it's not put on the agenda.
business.exp: s.169(1) CA 2006; company must send a copy to the director 'forthwith' .

business.q: A derivative claim can be brought against a third party.
business.exp: s.260(3) CA 2006; cause of action may be against the director or another person .

business.q: Compensation for loss of office to a director always requires shareholder approval.
business.exp: s.217 CA 2006; exceptions exist, e.g., payments by a wholly-owned subsidiary .

business.q: If a s.303 request is valid, directors have 28 days to call the meeting.
business.exp: s.304(1)(a) CA 2006; they have 21 days to *call* the meeting .

business.q: A Shareholders' Agreement can be altered by a 75% majority.
business.exp: It is a contract requiring unanimous approval to vary, unlike Articles .

business.q: s.994 petitions are the primary method for resolving valuation disputes.
business.exp: Courts encourage out-of-court independent valuation to save costs .

business.q: The court must dismiss a derivative claim if a hypothetical director acting under s.172 would not pursue it.
business.exp: s.263(2)(a) CA 2006; this is an absolute bar to permission .

business.q: A director removed under s.168 loses their right to compensation for loss of office.
business.exp: s.168(5) CA 2006; removal does not deprive them of compensation/damages payable .

business.q: Just and Equitable Winding Up is a remedy of first resort.
business.exp: It is a drastic remedy; courts prefer alternative orders under s.996 .

business.q: s.168 CA 2006 allows removal of a director by Ordinary Resolution.
business.exp: Statutory power of shareholders .

business.q: Special Notice requires 28 clear days.
s.33 CA 2006 creates a contract between company and members.
business.exp: Statutory contract regarding the constitution .

business.q: Foss v Harbottle established the proper claimant rule.
business.exp: The company is the proper claimant for wrongs done to it .

business.q: A Derivative Claim is brought by a shareholder on behalf of the company.
Unfair Prejudice is a claim under s.994 CA 2006.
business.exp: Personal claim by a member .

business.q: s.122 Insolvency Act 1986 covers Just and Equitable Winding Up.
business.exp: Drastic remedy for shareholders .

business.q: Bushell v Faith clauses provide weighted voting rights.
business.exp: Used to protect directors from removal .

business.q: Quasi-partnership companies often involve legitimate expectations.
business.exp: Expectations of management involvement .

business.q: s.303 allows shareholders to request a General Meeting.
business.exp: Requires 5% shareholding .

business.q: Share Purchase Order is a common remedy for Unfair Prejudice.
business.exp: Court orders purchase of petitioner's shares .

business.q: s.260 claims require court permission.
business.exp: Two-stage permission process .

business.q: Ratification can bar a derivative claim.
s.169 gives directors a right to protest removal.
business.exp: Right to speak and make written representations .

business.q: Shareholders' Agreements are public documents.
business.exp: They are private contracts, unlike Articles .

business.q: s.172 relates to the duty to promote success.
business.exp: Key factor in court's decision on derivative claims .

business.q: A member can bring a derivative claim for negligence.
business.exp: s.260(3) includes negligence, default, breach of duty .

business.q: Majority Rule dictates that 51% usually controls the company.
business.exp: General principle of company law .

business.q: s.305 allows shareholders to call a GM at the company's expense.
business.exp: If directors fail to call it .

business.q: Membership rights include the right to a declared dividend.
business.exp: Enforceable under s.33 .

business.q: Special Notice is sent to the shareholders.
business.exp: Sent to the *company* (board) .

business.q: A Director has a right to be heard at the removal meeting.
s.996 grants the court wide remedial powers.
business.exp: Power to make 'such order as it thinks fit' .

business.q: Clean Hands are required for s.994 petitions.
business.exp: Petitioner's conduct is relevant but not a strict bar .

business.q: s.260 applies to shadow directors.
business.exp: Statutory definition includes shadow directors .

business.q: Private companies with one class of shares need shareholder authority to allot.
business.exp: s.550 CA 2006; directors have automatic authority to allot shares.

business.q: Pre-emption rights apply to the issue of preference shares with capped rights.
business.exp: s.560(1) CA 2006; definition of 'equity securities' excludes shares with capped dividend/capital rights.

business.q: A specific disapplication of pre-emption rights requires a written statement from directors.
business.exp: s.571(6) CA 2006; must explain reasons and justify amount to be paid.

business.q: Companies incorporated under CA 1985 need an Ordinary Resolution to remove the authorised capital cap.
business.exp: The 1985 authorised capital became a provision in the articles; removable by OR under transitional rules.

business.q: A private company is prohibited from giving security for a loan to buy its own shares.
business.exp: s.678/679 CA 2006; prohibition applies to Public companies (or their private subsidiaries).

business.q: A public subsidiary is prohibited from guaranteeing a loan to buy shares in its private holding company.
business.exp: s.679 CA 2006; public subsidiaries of private targets are caught by financial assistance rules.

business.q: Paying due diligence fees for a buyer constitutes prohibited financial assistance.
business.exp: Chaston v SWP Group; 'smoothing the path' of acquisition is assistance.

business.q: Buyback of shares out of capital requires a Special Resolution.
business.exp: s.716 CA 2006; payment out of capital requires SR (plus OR for the contract).

business.q: Public companies can use capital to fund a buyback of shares.
business.exp: s.709 CA 2006; permissible capital payment is available to private companies only.

business.q: Payment for a buyback out of capital must occur within 7 weeks of the resolution.
business.exp: s.723 CA 2006; payment window is 5 to 7 weeks after the resolution.

business.q: Shareholders selling shares back to the company can vote on the approval resolution.
business.exp: s.695/s.717 CA 2006; selling shareholders are disenfranchised for the approval vote.

business.q: Advising a client on the merits of buying specific shares is a specified activity.
business.exp: Article 53(1) RAO; advising on merits of specified investments is regulated.

business.q: The Article 70 RAO exclusion applies to the sale of 30% of voting shares without control.
business.exp: Article 70 requires 50% voting shares OR acquisition of day-to-day control.

business.q: Solicitors can retain financial services commission without client consent.
business.exp: SRA Codes; commission must be accounted for unless informed consent is given.

business.q: Interim dividends constitute a legally binding debt once declared by directors.
business.exp: Potel v IRC; interim dividends can be rescinded any time before payment.

business.q: Final dividends must be declared by ordinary resolution.
business.exp: Standard Articles (MA 30); shareholders declare final dividends upon director recommendation.

business.q: Preference shares are non-cumulative unless stated otherwise.
business.exp: Presumption is that preference shares are cumulative regarding dividends.

business.q: Stamp duty is payable if the consideration is exactly £1,000.
business.exp: Stamp duty is payable only if consideration *exceeds* £1,000.

business.q: A company must file Form SH01 within 2 months of allotment.
business.exp: s.555 CA 2006; return of allotment must be filed within one month.

business.q: A Directors' Statement of Solvency for buyback must be made no earlier than 1 week before the meeting.
business.exp: s.714(6) CA 2006; strict timeframe for solvency statement validity.

business.q: Failure to register a charge within 21 days makes the money immediately repayable.
business.exp: s.859H CA 2006; debt becomes immediately payable and security is void against liquidator.

business.q: A floating charge holder usually ranks ahead of preferential creditors.
business.exp: Preferential creditors (e.g., employees, HMRC) rank ahead of floating charge holders.

business.q: Legal title to shares passes on execution of the stock transfer form.
business.exp: s.112 CA 2006; title passes on entry into the Register of Members.

business.q: Private companies can offer shares to the public.
business.exp: s.755 CA 2006; strict prohibition on public offers by private companies.

business.q: Transmission of shares on death requires a stock transfer form.
business.exp: Shares vest in PRs by operation of law; no stock transfer form needed for transmission.

business.q: 'Equity Finance' involves raising funds by issuing shares.
business.exp: Selling ownership stakes in exchange for capital.

business.q: 'Debt Finance' involves borrowing money.
business.exp: E.g., loans or bonds, creating a creditor-debtor relationship.

business.q: 'Nominal Value' is the minimum subscription price for a share.
business.exp: Shares cannot be issued at a discount to nominal value (s.580).

business.q: 'Share Premium' is the excess paid over the nominal value.
business.exp: Must be credited to the share premium account (s.610).

business.q: 'Pre-emption Right' is a right of first refusal for existing shareholders.
business.exp: s.561 CA 2006; protection against dilution.

business.q: 'Equity Securities' includes ordinary shares with uncapped rights.
business.exp: s.560 CA 2006; generally ordinary shares (vs fixed-rate preference shares).

business.q: 'Rights Issue' offers new shares to existing shareholders.
business.exp: Usually at a discount, pro-rata to holdings.

business.q: 'Bonus Issue' capitalises reserves to issue free shares.
business.exp: Turning reserves into share capital; no cash raised.

business.q: 'Treasury Shares' are shares bought back and held by the company.
business.exp: Company holds its own shares instead of cancelling them.

business.q: 'Financial Assistance' includes gifts, loans, and guarantees.
business.exp: s.677 CA 2006 definition; assistance for purchasing own shares.

business.q: 'Distributable Profits' are accumulated realised profits less losses.
business.exp: s.830 CA 2006; funds available for dividends.

business.q: 'Redeemable Shares' are issued with an intention to be bought back.
business.exp: Terms of redemption are set at issue.

business.q: 'Maintenance of Capital' prevents returning capital to shareholders generally.
business.exp: Fundamental principle to protect creditors.

business.q: 'Stamp Duty' is a tax on documents transferring shares.
business.exp: 0.5% on stock transfer forms.

business.q: 'FCA' stands for Financial Conduct Authority.
business.exp: UK financial regulator.

business.q: 'PRA' stands for Prudential Regulation Authority.
business.exp: Regulator for banks/insurers.

business.q: 'RAO' stands for Regulated Activities Order.
business.exp: Defines what activities/investments are regulated under FSMA.

business.q: 'General Prohibition' bans regulated activities without authorisation.
'Specified Investment' includes shares and bonds.
business.exp: Part III RAO lists these instruments.

business.q: 'Specified Activity' includes advising on the merits of investments.
business.exp: Part II RAO.

business.q: 'Article 67' RAO provides the 'necessary part' exclusion.
business.exp: Exclusion for activities incidental to a profession (e.g., law).

business.q: 'Article 70' RAO provides the 'sale of body corporate' exclusion.
business.exp: Exclusion for corporate transactions (50% shares/control).

business.q: 'Term Sheet' is a legally binding loan document.
business.exp: Generally non-binding statement of intent (subject to contract).

business.q: 'Gearing' is the ratio of debt to equity.
business.exp: Measure of financial leverage/risk.

business.q: 'Event of Default' allows a lender to call in a loan early.
business.exp: Contractual breach triggering repayment.

business.q: The Personal Allowance is reduced by £1 for every £2 of net income above £100,000.
business.exp: Income Tax Act 2007; the allowance is tapered for high earners.

business.q: An additional rate taxpayer is entitled to a Personal Savings Allowance of £500.
business.exp: Additional rate taxpayers receive a Personal Savings Allowance of £0.

business.q: Dividend income is taxed before savings income in the tax computation.
business.exp: The strict order is: Non-savings income, then Savings income, then Dividend income.

business.q: A higher rate taxpayer pays 24% Capital Gains Tax on the sale of shares.
business.exp: The CGT rate for higher rate taxpayers on shares is 24% (2025/26 rates).

business.q: Business Asset Disposal Relief (BADR) taxes qualifying gains at 10%.
business.exp: The BADR rate is 14% for the 2025/26 tax year.

business.q: Transfers of assets between spouses are made on a no gain/no loss basis.
business.exp: s.58 TCGA 1992; allows tax-free inter-spousal transfers.

business.q: A disposal to a connected person is treated as being made at market value.
business.exp: s.18 TCGA 1992; actual consideration is ignored if parties are connected.

business.q: The CGT Annual Exemption can be carried forward to the next tax year if unused.
business.exp: The CGT Annual Exemption is 'use it or lose it' and cannot be carried forward.

business.q: Rollover Relief allows a company to defer tax on a gain by buying a replacement asset.
business.exp: s.152 TCGA 1992; the gain is rolled into the base cost of the new asset.

business.q: A Potentially Exempt Transfer (PET) becomes fully exempt after 3 years.
business.exp: A PET becomes exempt only if the transferor survives for 7 years.

business.q: Lifetime Chargeable Transfers (LCTs) incur an immediate IHT charge of 20%.
business.exp: Entry charge for transfers into relevant property trusts is 20% (half death rate).

business.q: Business Property Relief (BPR) is available on assets owned for 1 year.
business.exp: The minimum ownership period for BPR is 2 years.

business.q: Quoted shares qualify for 100% Business Property Relief.
business.exp: Quoted shares generally do not qualify; unquoted shares qualify for 100% BPR.

business.q: The IHT Annual Exemption of £3,000 can be carried forward for one year only.
business.exp: Unused IHT annual exemption can be carried forward to the next year only.

business.q: Trading losses can be carried back to the previous three tax years.
business.exp: General rule is carry back 1 year (though temporary extensions existed for COVID).

business.q: Dividends received by individuals are paid gross.
business.exp: Since 2016, dividends are paid without deduction of tax at source.

business.q: The Residence Nil Rate Band (RNRB) applies to transfers to siblings.
business.exp: RNRB applies only to transfers to direct descendants (children/grandchildren).

business.q: A gift into a discretionary trust is a PET.
business.exp: It is a Lifetime Chargeable Transfer (LCT), immediately chargeable.

business.q: Capital losses must be set off against gains in the same year.
business.exp: Current year losses must be used before the Annual Exemption.

business.q: A painting sold for £4,000 is exempt from CGT under the Chattels Exemption.
business.exp: Tangible movable property sold for £6,000 or less is exempt.

business.q: Hold-Over Relief (s.165) applies to gifts of investment property.
business.exp: Relief applies to business assets (trading), not pure investments.

business.q: The IHT death rate is 40%.
business.exp: Standard rate on the estate above the Nil Rate Band.

business.q: Indexation Allowance is available to individuals for CGT.
business.exp: Indexation Allowance was frozen and abolished for individuals; available to companies only (frozen 2017).

business.q: Pension contributions increase the basic rate tax band.
business.exp: Relief at source extends the basic rate band by the gross contribution.

business.q: Entrepreneurs' Relief has been renamed Business Asset Disposal Relief.
business.exp: Renamed by Finance Act 2020.

business.q: Income Tax is a direct tax.
business.exp: Levied directly on the person's income.

business.q: VAT is an indirect tax.
business.exp: Levied on transactions, not income.

business.q: HMRC stands for HM Revenue and Customs.
business.exp: The UK tax authority.

business.q: The Tax Year ends on 31 March.
business.exp: The tax year for individuals ends on 5 April.

business.q: Domicile is the same concept as Residence.
business.exp: Residence is where you live; Domicile is your permanent home country.

business.q: CGT stands for Capital Gains Tax.
business.exp: Tax on profit from disposal of assets.

business.q: IHT stands for Inheritance Tax.
business.exp: Tax on transfers of value (death/lifetime).

business.q: PET stands for Potentially Exempt Transfer.
business.exp: A lifetime gift to an individual.

business.q: LCT stands for Lifetime Chargeable Transfer.
business.exp: A lifetime gift into a trust.

business.q: NRB stands for Nil Rate Band.
business.exp: The amount chargeable to IHT at 0%.

business.q: RNRB stands for Residence Nil Rate Band.
business.exp: Additional threshold for passing a home to descendants.

business.q: Taper Relief reduces the tax payable on death.
business.exp: Reduces IHT on gifts made 3-7 years before death.

business.q: Chattels are tangible movable property.
business.exp: e.g., paintings, antiques, racehorses.

business.q: BPR stands for Business Property Relief.
business.exp: IHT relief for business assets.

business.q: APR stands for Agricultural Property Relief.
business.exp: IHT relief for farms/agricultural land.

business.q: Total Income is income before any deductions.
business.exp: The aggregate of all income sources.

business.q: Net Income is Total Income minus reliefs.
business.exp: e.g., minus pension contributions.

business.q: Taxable Income is Net Income minus Personal Allowance.
business.exp: The final figure to which tax rates are applied.

business.q: Self-Assessment is the system for reporting personal tax.
business.exp: Individuals file a tax return annually.

business.q: Dividend Allowance is a 0% tax band for dividends.
business.exp: Currently applied to the first £500 of dividend income.

business.q: Personal Savings Allowance is a 0% tax band for interest.
business.exp: Applied to savings income based on tax bracket.

business.q: Capital Allowances are deductions for capital expenditure.
business.exp: Used in place of depreciation for tax purposes.

business.q: Principal Private Residence (PPR) is the taxpayer's main home.
business.exp: Qualifies for CGT relief on disposal.

business.q: Connected Persons includes spouses and siblings.
business.exp: Statutory definition for tax anti-avoidance.

business.q: 7-Year Rule applies to IHT lifetime gifts.
business.exp: Gifts are exempt if donor survives 7 years.

business.q: A company must register for VAT if taxable supplies exceed £90,000 in 12 months.
business.exp: VAT registration threshold (2024/25) .

business.q: Input tax incurred on exempt supplies is generally recoverable.
business.exp: Input tax attributable to exempt supplies cannot be recovered .

business.q: A business using the Flat Rate Scheme cannot normally recover input tax.
business.exp: Flat rate percentage accounts for input tax; separate recovery is not allowed .

business.q: The VAT element of a £120 gross price at standard rate is £24.
business.exp: The VAT fraction is 1/6; £120 / 6 = £20 VAT .

business.q: Client entertainment expenditure is a deductible expense for Corporation Tax.
business.exp: Business entertainment expenditure is prohibited by statute .

business.q: Dividends received by a UK company are generally subject to Corporation Tax.
business.exp: Dividend income is generally exempt from Corporation Tax .

business.q: A company with TTP of £40,000 pays Corporation Tax at 19%.
business.exp: The small profits rate (19%) applies to profits £50,000 or less .

business.q: Companies can claim an Annual Investment Allowance of £1 million.
business.exp: Allows 100% deduction for qualifying P&M expenditure up to £1m .

business.q: Indexation Allowance can be used to increase a capital loss.
business.exp: Indexation Allowance cannot create or increase a loss (frozen Dec 2017) .

business.q: Trading losses can be set off against capital gains in the same year.
business.exp: Trading losses can be set against profits of any description (income & gains) .

business.q: Capital losses can be carried back to the previous accounting period.
business.exp: Capital losses can only be carried forward to future periods .

business.q: Rollover Relief applies if the new asset is bought 4 years after disposal.
business.exp: Reinvestment must be within 1 year before to 3 years after disposal .

business.q: Substantial Shareholding Exemption requires a 10% holding for 12 months.
business.exp: Exempts gain on sale of shares if conditions met .

business.q: A large company with profits >£1.5m must pay tax 9 months after year end.
business.exp: Large companies must pay by quarterly instalments .

business.q: A loan to a participator in a close company triggers a tax charge on the company.
business.exp: Company pays tax (s.455) if loan not repaid within 9 months .

business.q: Tax paid on a close company loan is never refundable.
business.exp: Tax is refunded if the loan is repaid or written off .

business.q: Writing off a loan to a participator is tax-free for the individual.
business.exp: The participator is deemed to receive a taxable dividend .

business.q: Zero-rated supplies allow a business to recover input tax.
business.exp: Zero-rated supplies are taxable supplies (at 0%), allowing recovery .

business.q: The Cash Accounting Scheme is available if turnover exceeds £2 million.
business.exp: Turnover limit is £1.35 million .

business.q: Depreciation is a deductible expense for Corporation Tax.
business.exp: Depreciation is disallowed; Capital Allowances are used instead .

business.q: Companies pay Capital Gains Tax on their gains.
business.exp: Companies pay Corporation Tax on chargeable gains .

business.q: Full Expensing allows 100% deduction for new plant and machinery.
business.exp: Temporary allowance introduced April 2023 .

business.q: Rollover Relief is available on the sale of shares.
business.exp: Shares are not 'qualifying assets' (e.g. land, goodwill) .

business.q: A company must file its tax return within 9 months of year end.
business.exp: Filing deadline is 12 months; payment is 9 months 1 day (small co) .

business.q: A close company is controlled by 5 or fewer participators.
business.exp: Statutory definition of a close company .

business.q: Output Tax is VAT charged on sales.
business.exp: Tax on supplies made by the business .

business.q: Input Tax is VAT paid on purchases.
business.exp: Tax on supplies received by the business .

business.q: Standard Rate VAT is 20%.
business.exp: Current standard rate .

business.q: Reduced Rate VAT is 5%.
business.exp: Applies to domestic fuel etc .

business.q: TTP stands for Taxable Total Profits.
business.exp: The sum of income profits and chargeable gains .

business.q: The Financial Year starts on 6 April.
business.exp: The Financial Year for companies starts on 1 April .

business.q: AIA stands for Annual Investment Allowance.
business.exp: Capital allowance for P&M .

business.q: TWDV stands for Tax Written Down Value.
business.exp: Value of asset pool after allowances .

business.q: SSE stands for Substantial Shareholding Exemption.
business.exp: Relief for companies selling shares .

business.q: Rollover Relief defers Capital Gains Tax.
business.exp: Deferral by reinvestment .

business.q: Participator includes a shareholder.
business.exp: Person with share/interest in company .

business.q: Associate includes a spouse or parent.
business.exp: Close relative definition for close companies .

business.q: Corporation Tax is a direct tax.
business.exp: Tax on company profits .

business.q: VAT is an indirect tax.
business.exp: Tax on transactions .

business.q: Exempt supplies attract no VAT.
business.exp: e.g. insurance, finance .

business.q: Zero-rated supplies are taxed at 0%.
business.exp: e.g. books, food .

business.q: HMRC stands for HM Revenue and Customs.
business.exp: UK tax authority .

business.q: Interest on business loans is a deductible expense.
business.exp: Reduces taxable profit .

business.q: Income receipts arise from everyday trading.
business.exp: vs capital one-off receipts .

business.q: Capital expenditure is for long-term assets.
business.exp: e.g. buying machinery/premises .

business.q: VAT Returns are usually submitted quarterly.
business.exp: Standard reporting period .

business.q: A Taxable Person is registered for VAT.
business.exp: Or required to be registered .

business.q: The Main Rate of Corporation Tax is 25%.
business.exp: For profits >£250,000 .

business.q: Close Company rules are anti-avoidance legislation.
business.exp: Prevents tax advantages for small companies .

business.q: A dividend is a distribution of profit.
business.exp: Paid to shareholders .

business.q: Income tax is calculated in the order: Non-savings, Savings, Dividends.
business.exp: Strict statutory order of taxation is required to apply bands correctly.

business.q: The Personal Allowance is reduced to zero if Net Income hits £125,140.
business.exp: Reduced by £1 for every £2 over £100,000; £12,570 * 2 = £25,140 taper range.

business.q: A basic rate taxpayer pays 8.75% tax on dividend income.
business.exp: The basic rate for dividends is 8.75% (2025/26 rates).

business.q: Capital Gains Tax is payable on 31 January following the tax year end.
business.exp: Same payment deadline as income tax self-assessment.

business.q: Gifts to a discretionary trust are Potentially Exempt Transfers (PETs).
business.exp: They are Lifetime Chargeable Transfers (LCTs) subject to immediate 20% tax.

business.q: Business Property Relief (BPR) is available on assets held for 18 months.
business.exp: The transferor must have owned the assets for at least 2 years.

business.q: Shares in a quoted company qualify for 100% Business Property Relief.
business.exp: Quoted shares qualify for 50% relief, and only if the transferor had control.

business.q: If a PET fails, the tax is recalculated using the Nil Rate Band at death.
business.exp: The NRB applicable at the date of death is used, not the date of the gift.

business.q: A company can deregister for VAT if taxable supplies fall below £88,000.
business.exp: The deregistration threshold is £88,000.

business.q: Reduced rate VAT (5%) applies to children's car seats.
business.exp: Listed as a reduced rate supply along with domestic heating.

business.q: The sale of a new commercial building is automatically exempt from VAT.
business.exp: Sale of *new* commercial buildings is standard rated; old ones are exempt.

business.q: A VAT invoice must be issued within 30 days of the supply.
business.exp: Mandatory time limit for taxable business supplies.

business.q: Dividends paid by a company are a tax-deductible expense.
business.exp: Dividends are an appropriation of profit after tax, not an expense.

business.q: Capital allowances at 18% are calculated on a straight-line basis.
business.exp: They are calculated on a 'reducing balance' basis.

business.q: Full Expensing allows a 100% deduction for new plant and machinery.
business.exp: Temporary allowance uncapped for new/unused P&M.

business.q: Trading losses can be carried forward against trading profits only.
business.exp: Post-2017 losses can be carried forward against 'taxable total profits'.

business.q: Rollover Relief allows deferral of tax on the sale of goodwill.
business.exp: Goodwill is a qualifying asset for Rollover Relief.

business.q: A close company must pay tax on a loan to a participator within 9 months.
business.exp: Payable 9 months and 1 day after the accounting period end.

business.q: Benefits in kind to a participator in a close company are treated as distributions.
business.exp: Extended definition of distribution for close companies.

business.q: Large companies pay Corporation Tax in four instalments.
business.exp: Applies to companies with TTP over £1.5 million.

business.q: Indexation Allowance was frozen in December 2017.
business.exp: No relief for inflation after Dec 2017.

business.q: A private motor car is an exempt asset for CGT.
business.exp: Specifically excluded from Chargeable Assets.

business.q: Stamp Duty of 0.5% is payable on share transfers over £1,000.
business.exp: Rounded up to the nearest £5.

business.q: Partners are jointly and severally liable for partnership tax.
business.exp: Each partner is personally liable only for their own tax.

business.q: LLPs are tax transparent.
business.exp: Members are taxed as partners, the LLP is not taxed .

business.q: PA stands for Personal Allowance.
business.exp: Tax-free income threshold.

business.q: PSA stands for Personal Savings Allowance.
business.exp: Nil rate band for savings interest.

business.q: DA stands for Dividend Allowance.
business.exp: Nil rate band for dividend income.

business.q: CGT stands for Capital Gains Tax.
business.exp: Tax on disposal gains.

business.q: BADR stands for Business Asset Disposal Relief.
business.exp: Reduces CGT on business assets.

business.q: IHT stands for Inheritance Tax.
business.exp: Tax on transfers of value.

business.q: PET stands for Potentially Exempt Transfer.
business.exp: Lifetime gift between individuals.

business.q: LCT stands for Lifetime Chargeable Transfer.
business.exp: e.g., gift into trust.

business.q: NRB stands for Nil Rate Band.
business.exp: Threshold for 0% IHT.

business.q: RNRB stands for Residence Nil Rate Band.
business.exp: Additional threshold for family home.

business.q: BPR stands for Business Property Relief.
business.exp: Relief from IHT for business assets.

business.q: VAT stands for Value Added Tax.
business.exp: Indirect tax on supplies.

business.q: TTP stands for Taxable Total Profits.
business.exp: Corporate tax base.

business.q: FY stands for Financial Year.
business.exp: 1 April to 31 March.

business.q: AIA stands for Annual Investment Allowance.
business.exp: 100% relief for capital spend.

business.q: WDA stands for Writing Down Allowance.
business.exp: Standard capital allowance rate.

business.q: TWDV stands for Tax Written Down Value.
business.exp: Value of asset pool after allowances.

business.q: SSE stands for Substantial Shareholding Exemption.
business.exp: Exemption for companies selling shares.

business.q: CT stands for Corporation Tax.
business.exp: Tax on company profits.

business.q: HMRC stands for His Majesty's Revenue and Customs.
business.exp: Tax collection authority.

business.q: PAYE stands for Pay As You Earn.
business.exp: Deduction of tax from salary.

business.q: AE stands for Annual Exemption.
business.exp: Tax-free allowance for CGT.

business.q: IR stands for Investors' Relief.
business.exp: CGT relief for unlisted shares.

business.q: TNRB stands for Transferable Nil Rate Band.
business.exp: Unused NRB transferred to spouse.

business.q: P&M stands for Plant and Machinery.
business.exp: Assets qualifying for capital allowances.

business.q: Taking out a long-term loan increases a company's net assets.
business.exp: Net assets remain unchanged; assets (cash) increase, but liabilities increase by the same amount .

business.q: Issuing shares at a premium increases the Share Capital account by the full issue price.
business.exp: Share Capital increases by nominal value; the excess goes to the Share Premium Account .

business.q: A company must register a charge at Companies House within 14 days of creation.
business.exp: s.859A CA 2006; the period allowed for registration is 21 days .

business.q: Failure to register a charge makes the debt immediately payable.
business.exp: s.859H CA 2006; the security is void and the money becomes immediately repayable .

business.q: A floating charge holder ranks ahead of preferential creditors in a winding up.
business.exp: Preferential creditors (e.g., employees, HMRC) are paid before floating charge holders .

business.q: Depreciation using the straight-line method results in a higher charge in earlier years.
business.exp: Straight-line depreciation spreads the cost evenly; reducing balance charges more in early years .

business.q: An accrual is recorded as a current liability on the balance sheet.
business.exp: It represents a debt owed for goods/services received but not yet paid for .

business.q: A prepayment is recorded as an expense in the profit and loss account.
business.exp: Prepayments reduce the expense in the P&L and appear as a current asset on the balance sheet .

business.q: Increasing the provision for doubtful debts increases the business's profits.
business.exp: An increase in the provision is treated as an expense, reducing profit .

business.q: A declared final dividend is recorded as a liability if unpaid at year-end.
business.exp: Once declared, a final dividend is a binding debt and appears in current liabilities .

business.q: Interim dividends are recorded in the Profit and Loss account.
business.exp: Dividends are an appropriation of profit, not an expense; they appear in the SoCIE .

business.q: A guarantee given by a subsidiary for its parent's loan is an 'upstream' guarantee.
business.exp: Guarantee flows up the corporate chain from subsidiary to holding company .

business.q: A private company can offer bonds to the public.
business.exp: s.755 CA 2006 prohibits private companies from offering securities to the public .

business.q: High gearing means a company has a high proportion of equity compared to debt.
business.exp: High gearing means a high ratio of debt (liabilities) to equity .

business.q: The 'net book value' of an asset is its cost minus accumulated depreciation.
business.exp: Standard accounting formula for asset valuation on the balance sheet .

business.q: Revaluation of assets creates a distributable reserve.
business.exp: The revaluation reserve is an unrealised profit and is a capital (undistributable) reserve .

business.q: A fixed charge allows the borrower to deal with the asset freely.
business.exp: The lender controls the asset; the borrower cannot dispose of it without consent .

business.q: Crystallisation converts a fixed charge into a floating charge.
business.exp: It converts a floating charge into a fixed charge upon specific events .

business.q: Bad debts written off are treated as an expense in the Profit and Loss account.
business.exp: Written off debts are a cost to the business and reduce profit .

business.q: A 1:10 bonus issue increases the cash assets of the company.
business.exp: Bonus issues capitalize reserves; no cash is received from shareholders .

business.q: The share premium account can be used to pay dividends.
business.exp: It is a capital reserve and cannot be distributed as dividends .

business.q: A specific provision for doubtful debts reduces the receivables figure on the balance sheet.
business.exp: The provision is deducted from the gross receivables asset .

business.q: Interest on a loan is paid out of post-tax profits.
business.exp: Interest is an expense deducted *before* tax (P&L); dividends are post-tax .

business.q: A term loan is repayable on demand.
business.exp: Term loans are for a fixed period; overdrafts are repayable on demand .

business.q: The prescribed part fund is set aside for secured creditors.
business.exp: It is set aside for *unsecured* creditors from floating charge assets .

business.q: Equity Finance involves issuing shares.
business.exp: Raising funds by selling ownership stakes .

business.q: Debt Finance involves borrowing money.
business.exp: Raising funds through loans or debt securities .

business.q: A Debenture is a document creating security.
business.exp: Common term for a security document registering charges .

business.q: Overdraft is an on-demand loan facility.
business.exp: Repayable immediately upon request by the lender .

business.q: Bond is a type of debt security.
business.exp: A tradeable instrument acknowledging a debt .

business.q: Gearing is the ratio of debt to equity.
business.exp: Also known as leverage; measures financial risk .

business.q: Fixed Charge attaches to specific identifiable assets.
business.exp: e.g., machinery or land; lender controls disposal .

business.q: Floating Charge floats over a class of assets.
business.exp: e.g., stock; borrower can deal freely until crystallisation .

business.q: Crystallisation fixes a floating charge.
business.exp: Converts floating charge to fixed upon default/insolvency .

business.q: Negative Pledge prohibits creating further security.
business.exp: Clause preventing borrower from charging assets to others .

business.q: Profit and Loss Account shows income and expenses.
business.exp: Summarises financial performance over a period .

business.q: Balance Sheet shows assets, liabilities, and equity.
business.exp: Snapshot of financial position at a specific date .

business.q: Fixed Assets are long-term assets.
business.exp: Held for use in the business (e.g., buildings, machinery) .

business.q: Current Assets include stock and cash.
business.exp: Assets expected to be realized within a year .

business.q: Current Liabilities are debts due within one year.
business.exp: e.g., trade creditors, overdrafts .

business.q: Depreciation spreads the cost of an asset.
business.exp: Allocates cost over useful life in accounts .

business.q: Accruals are expenses incurred but not yet paid.
business.exp: Matched to the period they relate to .

business.q: Prepayments are expenses paid in advance.
business.exp: Benefit received in future period .

business.q: Bad Debt is a debt that will never be paid.
business.exp: Written off as an expense .

business.q: Share Premium is the excess over nominal value.
business.exp: Capital reserve from issuing shares above par .

business.q: Retained Earnings are accumulated past profits.
business.exp: Revenue reserve available for distribution .

business.q: SoCIE stands for Statement of Changes in Equity.
business.exp: Shows movement in reserves and dividends .

business.q: Representations are statements of fact in a loan agreement.
business.exp: Legal/commercial facts confirmed by borrower .

business.q: Undertakings are promises to do or not do something.
business.exp: Also known as covenants in loan agreements .

business.q: Event of Default triggers the right to demand repayment.
business.exp: Breach of loan terms allowing acceleration of debt .

business.q: A company failing to pay a statutory demand of £800 is deemed insolvent.
business.exp: s.123(1)(a) IA 1986; threshold is >£750 .

business.q: Interest on a bank loan must be paid during a CIGA moratorium.
business.exp: Debts involving financial services are excluded from the payment holiday .

business.q: A CVA is approved if 51% of creditors by value vote in favour.
business.exp: Requires 75% of creditors by value to approve .

business.q: A Restructuring Plan can bind secured creditors without their consent.
business.exp: The court can sanction a cross-class cram down binding dissenting classes .

business.q: The primary objective of administration is to realise property for secured creditors.
business.exp: Primary objective is rescuing the company as a going concern .

business.q: Directors must give 5 business days' notice to a QFCH to appoint an administrator.
business.exp: Sch B1 para 26 IA 1986; notice of intention to appoint must be served .

business.q: A landlord can forfeit a lease without court permission during administration.
business.exp: The moratorium prevents forfeiture without consent of administrator or court .

business.q: A fixed charge receiver owes their primary duty to the company.
business.exp: Primary duty is owed to the appointing creditor (charge holder) .

business.q: Disposition of property after a winding up petition is void unless validated.
business.exp: s.127 IA 1986; avoids dissipation of assets pending the order .

business.q: A Declaration of Solvency is required for a Creditors' Voluntary Liquidation.
business.exp: Required only for a Members' Voluntary Liquidation (MVL) .

business.q: Employee wages are preferential debts up to £800.
business.exp: Schedule 6 IA 1986; wages capped at £800 per employee .

business.q: The Prescribed Part fund is distributed to floating charge holders.
business.exp: It is ring-fenced for unsecured creditors .

business.q: A floating charge holder can claim shortfall from the Prescribed Part.
business.exp: Expressly prohibited from sharing in the Prescribed Part for the shortfall .

business.q: A creditor can petition for bankruptcy if the debt is at least £750.
business.exp: The bankruptcy petition threshold is £5,000 .

business.q: A Trustee in Bankruptcy can challenge a transaction at an undervalue from 4 years ago.
business.exp: s.339 IA 1986; look-back period is 5 years .

business.q: Insolvency is presumed if a transaction at an undervalue is with an associate.
business.exp: s.339 IA 1986; burden shifts to the associate to prove solvency .

business.q: An IVA requires the approval of 50% of creditors by value.
business.exp: Requires 75% of creditors by value to approve .

business.q: Secured creditors are bound by an IVA without their consent.
business.exp: Secured creditors must consent to be bound .

business.q: A bankrupt is generally discharged after 3 years.
business.exp: Automatic discharge occurs after 1 year .

business.q: A CIGA moratorium initially lasts for 20 business days.
business.exp: Initial period is 20 business days .

business.q: HMRC VAT arrears are unsecured debts.
business.exp: HMRC debts are now secondary preferential debts .

business.q: The 'Relevant Date' for the Prescribed Part is 15 September 2003.
business.exp: Applies to floating charges created on/after this date .

business.q: Fixed charge creditors are paid before the liquidator's general expenses.
business.exp: They pay only the costs of realising their specific asset .

business.q: Shareholders are paid before interest on unsecured debts in liquidation.
business.exp: Interest on debts ranks above shareholders .

business.q: A desire to prefer is presumed in a bankruptcy preference to an associate.
business.exp: s.340 IA 1986; rebuttable presumption of desire to prefer .

business.q: IA 1986 stands for Insolvency Act 1986.
business.exp: Main statute for insolvency .

business.q: Cash flow test checks if a company can pay debts as they fall due.
Balance sheet test checks if liabilities exceed assets.
CVA stands for Company Voluntary Arrangement.
business.exp: Formal compromise with creditors .

business.q: Nominee is an insolvency practitioner supervising a CVA proposal.
business.exp: Becomes Supervisor upon approval .

business.q: Supervisor implements an approved CVA.
business.exp: Role after CVA approval .

business.q: Moratorium is a freeze on creditor action.
business.exp: Breathing space for the company .

business.q: Restructuring Plan is a court-sanctioned compromise.
business.exp: Part 26A CA 2006 (CIGA 2020) .

business.q: Cross-class cram down binds dissenting creditor classes.
business.exp: Feature of Restructuring Plans .

business.q: Administration is a collective insolvency procedure.
business.exp: Acts for all creditors .

business.q: QFCH stands for Qualifying Floating Charge Holder.
business.exp: Holder of security over whole/substantially whole property .

business.q: Administrative Receiver is appointed by a floating charge holder.
business.exp: Rare procedure now (pre-2003 charges) .

business.q: LPA Receiver is a fixed charge receiver.
business.exp: Appointed under Law of Property Act / security .

business.q: Compulsory Liquidation is court-ordered winding up.
business.exp: Started by petition .

business.q: MVL stands for Members' Voluntary Liquidation.
business.exp: Solvent liquidation .

business.q: CVL stands for Creditors' Voluntary Liquidation.
business.exp: Insolvent liquidation initiated by members .

business.q: Declaration of Solvency confirms the company can pay debts in 12 months.
business.exp: Required for MVL .

business.q: Preferential Creditors include employees and HMRC.
business.exp: Paid before floating charge holders .

business.q: Prescribed Part is a fund ring-fenced for unsecured creditors.
Pari passu means ranking equally.
business.exp: Unsecured creditors share pro rata .

business.q: IVA stands for Individual Voluntary Arrangement.
business.exp: Alternative to bankruptcy .

business.q: Bankruptcy Order declares an individual insolvent.
business.exp: Court order .

business.q: Trustee in Bankruptcy administers the bankrupt's estate.
business.exp: Assets vest in them .

business.q: Official Receiver is a civil servant and officer of the court.
business.exp: Acts as trustee initially .

business.q: Discharge releases a bankrupt from debts.
business.exp: Usually after 1 year .

business.q: Wrongful trading liability arises if directors knew insolvent liquidation was inevitable.
business.exp: s.214(2) IA 1986; the 'point of no return' test .

business.q: Resigning is a recommended step to avoid wrongful trading liability.
business.exp: Resigning might itself be an act of wrongful trading; directors should stay to minimize loss .

business.q: Fraudulent trading requires proof of actual dishonesty.
business.exp: Subjective dishonesty must be proven (Ivey v Genting Casinos) .

business.q: Only formally appointed directors can be liable for wrongful trading.
business.exp: Liability extends to shadow and de facto directors .

business.q: Insolvency is presumed in a Transaction at an Undervalue with a connected person.
business.exp: s.240(2) IA 1986; burden shifts to the connected person to prove solvency .

business.q: The 'relevant time' for a preference given to an unconnected person is 2 years.
business.exp: s.239(2) IA 1986; the period is 6 months for unconnected persons .

business.q: A desire to prefer is presumed when giving a preference to an associate.
business.exp: s.239(6) IA 1986; rebuttable presumption of desire to prefer applies .

business.q: Granting a floating charge for no new consideration is valid if within 12 months of insolvency.
business.exp: s.245 IA 1986; generally void if created within 12 months with no new money .

business.q: s.423 claims for transactions defrauding creditors require the company to be insolvent.
business.exp: s.423 IA 1986; insolvency is not a requirement .

business.q: New money paid into an overdraft can validate a floating charge.
business.exp: Re Yeovil Glove Co; operations on an overdraft can constitute 'new money' .

business.q: Wrongful trading claims can be assigned to a third party.
business.exp: Allowed under SBEEA 2015 to raise funds for the estate .

business.q: The court can impose punitive damages for fraudulent trading.
business.exp: Compensation is compensatory only, not punitive .

business.q: Blind-eye knowledge is insufficient for fraudulent trading liability.
business.exp: Knowledge includes a suspicion and a deliberate decision to avoid confirmation .

business.q: The 'Every Step' defence applies to fraudulent trading claims.
business.exp: It is a specific statutory defence for Wrongful Trading (s.214(3)) .

business.q: Misfeasance proceedings (s.212) create a new statutory liability.
business.exp: s.212 is procedural; it enforces existing duties .

business.q: The relevant time for a Transaction at an Undervalue is always 2 years.
business.exp: s.240(1)(a) IA 1986; 2 years regardless of connection .

business.q: A dividend can be challenged as a Transaction at an Undervalue.
business.exp: BTI v Sequana SA; dividends can be transactions at an undervalue .

business.q: Commercial pressure negates the 'desire to prefer' in a preference claim.
business.exp: Re MC Bacon; action taken to avoid calling in a loan is not a preference .

business.q: A floating charge granted to a connected person is vulnerable for 2 years.
business.exp: s.245(3)(a) IA 1986; extended period for connected persons .

business.q: The 'onset of insolvency' in a compulsory liquidation is the date of the winding-up order.
business.exp: It is the date of the presentation of the petition .

business.q: Wrongful Trading applies to companies in administration.
business.exp: s.246ZB IA 1986 applies wrongful trading to administration .

business.q: A person liable for fraudulent trading faces up to 10 years imprisonment.
business.exp: s.993 CA 2006 provides criminal sanctions .

business.q: A subsequent purchaser in good faith is protected from TUV avoidance orders.
business.exp: s.241(2) IA 1986 protects third parties acting in good faith for value .

business.q: Wrongful trading liability is judged on the 'cash flow' test of insolvency.
business.exp: Judged solely on the 'Balance Sheet' test .

business.q: A bank can be liable for fraudulent trading.
business.exp: Morris v State Bank of India; 'any person' includes banks .

business.q: s.213 IA 1986 covers Fraudulent Trading.
business.exp: Statutory provision for liquidation .

business.q: s.214 IA 1986 covers Wrongful Trading.
business.exp: Statutory provision for liquidation .
