business.q: s.238 IA 1986 covers Transactions at an Undervalue.
business.exp: Statutory provision .

business.q: s.239 IA 1986 covers Preferences.
business.exp: Statutory provision .

business.q: s.245 IA 1986 covers Avoidance of Floating Charges.
business.exp: Statutory provision .

business.q: s.423 IA 1986 covers Transactions Defrauding Creditors.
business.exp: Statutory provision .

business.q: TUV stands for Transaction at an Undervalue.
business.exp: Common acronym .

business.q: TDC stands for Transaction Defrauding Creditors.
business.exp: Common acronym .

business.q: CDDA stands for Company Directors Disqualification Act.
business.exp: Legislation governing disqualification .

business.q: The 'Relevant Time' is the look-back period before insolvency.
'Connected Person' includes a director.
'Associate' includes a spouse or relative.
'Onset of Insolvency' includes the date of winding up resolution.
'Misfeasance' is the misapplication of company property.
'Point of No Return' is when insolvent liquidation is inevitable.
business.exp: Trigger for wrongful trading liability .

business.q: 'Restoration Order' restores the company's position.
business.exp: Remedy for voidable transactions .

business.q: 'New Money' validates a floating charge.
business.exp: Fresh consideration under s.245 .

business.q: 'Reasonably Diligent Person' is the test for wrongful trading.
business.exp: s.214(4) IA 1986 standard .

business.q: 'Shadow Director' is subject to wrongful trading laws.
business.exp: Included in definition of director .

business.q: 'Liquidator' can bring a wrongful trading claim.
'Administrator' can bring a fraudulent trading claim.
'Insolvency' generally means inability to pay debts.
'Civil Liability' requires contribution to company assets.
business.exp: Remedy for wrongful/fraudulent trading .

business.q: 'Criminal Liability' involves fines or imprisonment.
business.exp: Applies to fraudulent trading .

business.q: 'Office-holder' refers to a liquidator or administrator.
business.exp: Person empowered to bring claims .

dispute.q: Limitation Period (Contract): 6 years.
dispute.exp: Limitation Act 1980.

dispute.q: Limitation Period (Personal Injury): 3 years.
dispute.exp: From injury/knowledge.

dispute.q: Small Claims Track limit is generally £10,000.
dispute.exp: For standard claims.

dispute.q: Overriding Objective: Deal with cases justly.
dispute.exp: And at proportionate cost (CPR 1.1).

dispute.q: Claim Form valid for service: 4 months.
dispute.exp: Must be served within this window.

dispute.q: Default Judgment available if no Defence filed.
dispute.exp: Procedural victory.

dispute.q: Part 36 offers are 'without prejudice save as to costs'.
dispute.exp: Court cannot see until end.

dispute.q: Hearsay evidence is admissible in civil proceedings.
dispute.exp: Weight may vary, notice required.

dispute.q: Small Claims costs are generally recoverable.
dispute.exp: Strictly limited to fixed costs.

dispute.q: Injunctions are a discretionary remedy.
dispute.exp: Equitable remedy.

dispute.q: Summary Judgment test: 'No real prospect of success'.
dispute.exp: Early disposal of weak cases.

dispute.q: Norwich Pharmacal Order identifies a wrongdoer.
dispute.exp: Disclosure order against third party.

dispute.q: Standard Disclosure requires 'reasonable search'.
dispute.exp: Duty to search for documents.

dispute.q: Permission to appeal is usually required.
dispute.exp: General rule in civil courts.

dispute.q: Taking Control of Goods involves bailiffs.
dispute.exp: Enforcement method.

dispute.q: Pre-action protocols are optional guidance.
dispute.exp: Court imposes sanctions for non-compliance.

dispute.q: Particulars of Claim service: 14 days after Claim Form.
dispute.exp: If not served with it.

dispute.q: Defence (Standard) deadline: 14 days.
dispute.exp: After service of Particulars.

dispute.q: Tomlin Order stays proceedings on agreed terms.
dispute.exp: Contractual settlement mechanism.

dispute.q: Security for Costs protects the Defendant.
dispute.exp: Against claimant inability to pay.

dispute.q: Fast Track value band: £10k–£25k.
dispute.exp: Standard track allocation.

dispute.q: Intermediate Track value band: £25k–£100k.
dispute.exp: New track for moderate complexity.

dispute.q: Case Management Conference (CMC) is for Multi-Track.
dispute.exp: To set directions.

dispute.q: Expert evidence requires court permission.
dispute.exp: CPR 35 restriction.

dispute.q: Expert's duty is to the client paying them.
dispute.exp: Primary duty is to the Court.

dispute.q: Without Prejudice privilege hides settlement docs.
dispute.exp: Encourages settlement.

dispute.q: Legal Advice Privilege covers lawyer-client comms.
dispute.exp: Confidentiality protection.

dispute.q: Litigation Privilege requires litigation in prospect.
dispute.exp: Dominant purpose test.

dispute.q: Costs generally follow the event.
dispute.exp: Loser pays winner's costs.

dispute.q: QOCS applies to breach of contract claims.
dispute.exp: Qualified One-Way Costs Shifting is for PI only.

dispute.q: Charging Order secures debt against land.
dispute.exp: Enforcement method.

dispute.q: Third Party Debt Order freezes bank accounts.
dispute.exp: Enforcement method.

dispute.q: Denton test applies to Relief from Sanctions.
dispute.exp: 3 stage test for non-compliance.

dispute.q: Witness statement stands as evidence-in-chief.
dispute.exp: Usually, to save court time.

dispute.q: Part 20 Claim includes Counterclaims.
dispute.exp: Or claims against third parties.

dispute.q: Judicial Review is a private law remedy.
dispute.exp: Public law remedy.

dispute.q: County Court hears claims >£100,000.
dispute.exp: High Court jurisdiction usually.

dispute.q: Service by email is permitted without indication.
dispute.exp: Must have indicated willingness to accept.

dispute.q: Unless Order carries automatic sanctions.
dispute.exp: Strict compliance required.

dispute.q: American Cyanamid test is for Interim Injunctions.
dispute.exp: Balance of convenience test.

dispute.q: Freezing Injunction acts in personam.
dispute.exp: Acts on the person, not the asset.

dispute.q: Search Order requires Defendant to be absent.
dispute.exp: Must be served on Defendant to allow entry.

dispute.q: Civil Burden of Proof: Beyond reasonable doubt.
dispute.exp: Balance of probabilities.

dispute.q: Claim 'issued' on receipt by court.
dispute.exp: Stops limitation clock.

dispute.q: Interest is automatically 8% on all debts.
dispute.exp: 8% applies to Judgment Debts.

dispute.q: Refusing ADR can lead to cost penalties.
dispute.exp: Halsey principles.

dispute.q: Skeleton arguments are oral submissions.
dispute.exp: Written summaries of arguments.

dispute.q: Precedent H is a Costs Budget.
dispute.exp: Required in Multi-track.

dispute.q: Summary Assessment happens at 1 day hearing.
dispute.exp: Immediate cost decision.

dispute.q: Detailed Assessment requires separate hearing.
dispute.exp: For larger/complex costs.

dispute.q: A personal injury claim valued at £40,000 must be issued in the County Court.
dispute.exp: Personal injury claims valued under £50,000 must be commenced in the County Court.

dispute.q: A non-personal injury claim valued at £80,000 may be issued in the High Court.
dispute.exp: Non-personal injury claims must be worth more than £100,000 to be issued in the High Court.

dispute.q: The High Court is bound by decisions of the Privy Council.
dispute.exp: Privy Council decisions are persuasive but not binding on English courts.

dispute.q: Solicitors automatically have rights of audience in the High Court.
dispute.exp: Solicitors generally require Higher Rights of Audience to appear in the High Court.

dispute.q: A Conditional Fee Agreement can provide for a success fee of up to 100%.
dispute.exp: The maximum success fee uplift is 100% of the solicitor's normal fees.

dispute.q: In a personal injury case, the CFA success fee cap is 25% of damages.
dispute.exp: The success fee is capped at 25% of general damages and past pecuniary loss.

dispute.q: A Damages Based Agreement (DBA) allows a lawyer to take 50% of damages in employment cases.
dispute.exp: The DBA cap for employment tribunal cases is 35%.

dispute.q: The DBA cap for general commercial litigation is 50% of damages.
dispute.exp: Lawyers can take up to 50% of damages in non-PI, non-employment cases.

dispute.q: ATE insurance premiums are generally recoverable from the losing opponent.
dispute.exp: ATE premiums are generally not recoverable (except for specific clinical negligence reports).

dispute.q: The Supreme Court is bound by its own previous decisions.
dispute.exp: Under the Practice Statement 1966, it may depart when 'it appears right to do so'.

dispute.q: The Court of Appeal (Civil Division) is bound by its own previous decisions.
dispute.exp: Subject to the limited exceptions in Young v Bristol Aeroplane Co Ltd.

dispute.q: A decision made 'per incuriam' is binding on the Court of Appeal.
dispute.exp: Per incuriam (ignorance of statute/binding authority) is an exception to stare decisis.

dispute.q: Civil Legal Aid is available for most breach of contract claims.
dispute.exp: Civil CLS funding is restricted to very limited categories (e.g., family, homelessness).

dispute.q: A claim for judicial review is heard in the Chancery Division.
dispute.exp: Judicial review is heard in the Administrative Court (King's Bench Division).

dispute.q: Bankruptcy petitions are heard in the King's Bench Division.
dispute.exp: Insolvency matters are dealt with in the Chancery Division.

dispute.q: The Technology and Construction Court is part of the King's Bench Division.
dispute.exp: It is a specialist court within the KBD.

dispute.q: The 'General Rule' on costs is that the loser pays the winner's costs.
dispute.exp: Costs follow the event (CPR 44.2(2)).

dispute.q: The court will generally allow a successful party to recover 100% of their costs.
dispute.exp: Recovery is limited to reasonable and proportionate costs (often approx. 60%).

dispute.q: A CFA success fee is recoverable from the opponent.
dispute.exp: The success fee is paid by the client, usually from damages.

dispute.q: Before The Event (BTE) insurance is purchased after a dispute arises.
dispute.exp: BTE is existing cover (e.g., in home insurance); ATE is purchased after the dispute.

dispute.q: The 'Business List' is found in the King's Bench Division.
dispute.exp: The Business List is in the Chancery Division.

dispute.q: A Circuit Judge sits in the County Court.
dispute.exp: Circuit Judges and District Judges sit in the County Court.

dispute.q: Third-party funders can take control of the litigation from the solicitors.
dispute.exp: Code of Conduct prohibits funders from taking control of litigation.

dispute.q: The Commercial Court handles domestic breach of contract claims valued at £25,000.
dispute.exp: It handles complex/international business disputes; lower value claims go to County Court.

dispute.q: Solicitors can carry out advocacy in the Supreme Court without extra qualifications.
dispute.exp: Solicitors are not authorised for Higher Courts without Higher Rights of Audience.

dispute.q: 'Litigation' refers to resolving disputes through court proceedings.
dispute.exp: Distinct from Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR).

dispute.q: The 'Claimant' is the party who starts civil proceedings.
dispute.exp: They seek a remedy against the Defendant.

dispute.q: 'Stare Decisis' means 'stand by what has been decided'.
dispute.exp: The principle of binding precedent.

dispute.q: A 'Tort' is a type of criminal offence.
dispute.exp: A tort is a civil wrong (e.g., negligence).

dispute.q: 'Inter Partes' costs are costs payable between parties.
dispute.exp: As opposed to solicitor-own client costs.

dispute.q: A 'Retainer' is the contract between solicitor and client.
dispute.exp: It governs the professional relationship and funding.

dispute.q: 'CFA' stands for Conditional Fee Agreement.
dispute.exp: Commonly known as 'no win, no fee'.

dispute.q: 'DBA' stands for Damages Based Agreement.
dispute.exp: The lawyer receives a percentage of the damages recovered.

dispute.q: 'Disbursements' are fees paid to third parties.
dispute.exp: Expenses like court fees or expert witness fees.

dispute.q: 'KBD' stands for King's Bench Division.
dispute.exp: One of the three divisions of the High Court.

dispute.q: A 'Master' is a judge in the County Court.
dispute.exp: Masters sit in the High Court; District Judges sit in the County Court.

dispute.q: 'Precedent' is a judgment binding on lower courts.
dispute.exp: The core of the common law system.

dispute.q: 'Ratio Decidendi' is the binding reasoning of a decision.
dispute.exp: The legal principle on which the decision is based.

dispute.q: 'Obiter Dicta' are binding parts of a judgment.
dispute.exp: They are persuasive comments, not binding.

dispute.q: 'Per Incuriam' means a decision made through lack of care.
dispute.exp: Usually ignorance of a relevant statute or precedent.

dispute.q: 'Directions' are court orders managing the case timetable.
dispute.exp: Setting deadlines for evidence and trial steps.

dispute.q: 'Allocation' assigns a claim to a case management track.
dispute.exp: Small Claims, Fast, Intermediate, or Multi-track.

dispute.q: 'Disclosure' is the exchange of relevant documents.
dispute.exp: A key evidence stage in civil litigation.

dispute.q: 'Statements of Case' include the Claim Form and Defence.
dispute.exp: Documents setting out the factual case.

dispute.q: 'Enforcement' occurs before judgment.
dispute.exp: Enforcement happens post-trial to compel compliance with an order.

dispute.q: 'Interim Application' is a request for a court order before trial.
dispute.exp: E.g., for an extension of time or specific disclosure.

dispute.q: 'CLS' stands for Community Legal Service.
dispute.exp: The body formerly providing civil legal aid.

dispute.q: 'Success Fee' is an uplift payable in a CFA.
dispute.exp: A percentage added to basic fees if the case is won.

dispute.q: The 'Overriding Objective' is to generate maximum profit.
dispute.exp: It is to deal with cases justly and at proportionate cost.

dispute.q: The limitation period for a simple breach of contract claim is 12 years.
dispute.exp: s.5 Limitation Act 1980; the limitation period for simple contract is 6 years from the breach.

dispute.q: The limitation period for a personal injury claim is 3 years from the date of injury or knowledge.
dispute.exp: s.11 Limitation Act 1980; 3 years from the cause of action accruing or date of knowledge.

dispute.q: In the tort of negligence, the cause of action accrues when the duty of care is breached.
dispute.exp: Actionable negligence requires damage; the cause of action accrues when damage occurs, not just breach.

dispute.q: A 'longstop' limitation period of 15 years applies to latent damage claims in negligence.
dispute.exp: s.14B Limitation Act 1980; bars claims 15 years after the negligent act, regardless of knowledge.

dispute.q: Contractual damages are designed to punish the contract breaker.
dispute.exp: Contract damages are compensatory (Robinson v Harman); punitve damages are not available in contract.

dispute.q: Specific performance is a discretionary remedy available as of right for breach of contract.
dispute.exp: It is an equitable discretionary remedy, only granted if damages are inadequate (e.g., land sales).

dispute.q: A claimant has a duty to mitigate their loss in both contract and tort.
dispute.exp: British Westinghouse v Underground Electric; claimants cannot recover for avoidable losses.

dispute.q: The 'remoteness' test in contract is narrower than in the tort of negligence.
dispute.exp: The Wagon Mound (tort) is 'reasonable foreseeability'; Hadley v Baxendale (contract) requires loss to be in 'contemplation'.

dispute.q: Pure economic loss is generally recoverable in a negligence claim regarding a defective product.
dispute.exp: Spartan Steel; pure economic loss is generally not recoverable in tort (unlike contract).

dispute.q: Contributory negligence is a complete defence to a claim in tort.
dispute.exp: Law Reform (Contributory Negligence) Act 1945; it is a partial defence reducing damages.

dispute.q: An exclusion clause for death or personal injury caused by negligence is void.
dispute.exp: s.2(1) UCTA 1977 and s.65 CRA 2015; liability for death/PI cannot be excluded.

dispute.q: A claim for breach of a deed must be brought within 12 years of the breach.
dispute.exp: s.8 Limitation Act 1980; the limitation period for a specialty (deed) is 12 years.

dispute.q: Pre-action protocols are optional guidance that courts generally ignore.
dispute.exp: Practice Direction - Pre-Action Conduct; non-compliance can lead to cost sanctions.

dispute.q: A 'Letter of Claim' should be sent before issuing proceedings.
dispute.exp: Standard requirement of Pre-Action Protocols to define the dispute and encourage settlement.

dispute.q: Vicarious liability requires the tortfeasor to be an employee acting in the course of employment.
dispute.exp: Lister v Hesley Hall; 'close connection' test applies to the course of employment.

dispute.q: Rescission for misrepresentation is available if the claimant has affirmed the contract.
dispute.exp: Affirmation is a bar to rescission (Long v Lloyd).

dispute.q: In a 'battle of the forms', the first set of terms proposed usually prevails.
dispute.exp: Butler Machine Tool; the 'last shot' rule means the final terms sent before acceptance prevail.

dispute.q: Silence can constitute acceptance of an offer in contract law.
dispute.exp: Felthouse v Bindley; acceptance must be communicated.

dispute.q: A variation to a contract is valid without consideration if made in writing.
dispute.exp: Stilk v Myrick; variation requires fresh consideration (or practical benefit - Williams v Roffey) unless by deed.

dispute.q: Interest on a debt can be claimed under the Late Payment of Commercial Debts (Interest) Act 1998.
dispute.exp: Applies to B2B contracts for the supply of goods and services.

dispute.q: The burden of proof in a civil contract claim is 'beyond reasonable doubt'.
dispute.exp: The standard is the 'balance of probabilities'.

dispute.q: Third parties can enforce a contract term if the contract expressly provides for it.
dispute.exp: s.1 Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999.

dispute.q: A claim for defamation must be brought within 3 years.
dispute.exp: s.4A Limitation Act 1980; the period is 1 year.

dispute.q: Damages in tort aim to put the claimant in the position they were in before the tort occurred.
dispute.exp: Livingstone v Rawyards Coal Co; 'restitutio in integrum'.

dispute.q: An interim injunction is granted before the trial to maintain the status quo.
dispute.exp: American Cyanamid guidelines apply.

dispute.q: 'Tort' is a civil wrong independent of contract.
dispute.exp: Derived from the Latin 'tortum' (twisted/wrong).

dispute.q: 'Contract' requires offer, acceptance, consideration, and intent.
dispute.exp: The four essential elements for a binding agreement.

dispute.q: 'Limitation Period' is the time limit for bringing a claim.
dispute.exp: Set by the Limitation Act 1980.

dispute.q: 'Damages' refers to financial compensation.
dispute.exp: The primary remedy in civil litigation.

dispute.q: 'Injunction' is a court order to do or stop doing an act.
dispute.exp: An equitable remedy.

dispute.q: 'Specific Performance' compels a party to fulfill a contract.
dispute.exp: Used when damages are inadequate.

dispute.q: 'Breach of Contract' is a failure to perform a contractual term.
dispute.exp: Gives rise to a right to claim damages.

dispute.q: 'Negligence' is the breach of a duty of care causing loss.
dispute.exp: The most common tort (Donoghue v Stevenson).

dispute.q: 'Duty of Care' is a legal obligation to avoid causing harm.
dispute.exp: Caparo test establishes if a duty exists.

dispute.q: 'Causation' links the breach to the damage.
dispute.exp: The 'but for' test (Barnett v Chelsea).

dispute.q: 'Remoteness' limits the damages recoverable.
dispute.exp: Damage must be reasonably foreseeable.

dispute.q: 'Mitigation' is the duty to minimize loss.
dispute.exp: Claimant cannot recover for losses they could have avoided.

dispute.q: 'Consideration' is the price paid for a promise.
dispute.exp: Must be sufficient but need not be adequate.

dispute.q: 'Privity of Contract' means only parties can sue.
dispute.exp: General rule preventing third parties from enforcing terms.

dispute.q: 'Rescission' unwinds the contract ab initio.
dispute.exp: Remedy for misrepresentation; restores parties to pre-contract position.

dispute.q: 'Void' means the contract never existed legally.
dispute.exp: Of no legal effect from the start.

dispute.q: 'Voidable' means the contract is valid until set aside.
dispute.exp: One party has the option to rescind.

dispute.q: 'Invitation to Treat' invites offers.
dispute.exp: Not an offer itself (e.g., shop display).

dispute.q: 'Counter-offer' terminates the original offer.
dispute.exp: Hyde v Wrench; rejects the old offer and creates a new one.

dispute.q: 'Deed' is a document signed, witnessed, and delivered.
dispute.exp: Required for certain transactions (e.g., land) and extends limitation to 12 years.

dispute.q: 'Quantum' refers to the amount of damages.
dispute.exp: The calculation of the monetary value of the claim.

dispute.q: 'Liability' is legal responsibility for an act or omission.
dispute.exp: Determined before quantum.

dispute.q: 'Vicarious Liability' makes an employer liable for employees.
dispute.exp: Strict liability for torts in the course of employment.

dispute.q: 'Pre-Action Protocol' sets out conduct before court proceedings.
dispute.exp: Encourages exchange of information and settlement.

dispute.q: A defendant has 14 days to file a Defence if they do not file an Acknowledgment of Service.
dispute.exp: CPR 15.4; the period is 14 days after service of the Particulars of Claim.

dispute.q: Parties can agree to extend the deadline for filing a Defence by up to 56 days without court permission.
dispute.exp: CPR 15.5; parties can agree an extension of up to 28 days (total 56 days from service).

dispute.q: Filing an Acknowledgment of Service extends the period for filing a Defence to 28 days.
dispute.exp: CPR 15.4(1)(b); extends time to 28 days after service of Particulars of Claim.

dispute.q: A claimant can obtain default judgment if the defendant files an Acknowledgment of Service but no Defence.
dispute.exp: CPR 12.3(2); default judgment is available if the Defence time limit has expired.

dispute.q: The court *must* set aside a default judgment if it was entered after the Defence was filed.
dispute.exp: CPR 13.2; mandatory set aside if judgment was wrongly entered (e.g., Defence was filed on time).

dispute.q: The court *may* set aside a default judgment if the defendant has a 'real prospect of success'.
dispute.exp: CPR 13.3; discretionary set aside grounds.

dispute.q: A defendant seeking to set aside default judgment must act 'promptly'.
dispute.exp: CPR 13.3(2); promptness is a key factor in discretionary set aside applications.

dispute.q: Summary judgment is available in proceedings for possession of residential premises.
dispute.exp: CPR 24.3(2); summary judgment does not apply to certain possession claims.

dispute.q: A claimant can apply for summary judgment before the defendant has filed an Acknowledgment of Service.
dispute.exp: CPR 24.4(1); claimant must wait until AoS or Defence has been filed (unless court gives permission).

dispute.q: The test for summary judgment is whether the respondent has 'no arguable case'.
dispute.exp: CPR 24.2; the test is 'no real prospect of succeeding/defending'.

dispute.q: A counterclaim must always be filed with the Defence.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.4; it can be filed later with the court's permission.

dispute.q: If a defendant admits part of a claim, the claimant can enter judgment for that amount.
dispute.exp: CPR 14.3; judgment on admission.

dispute.q: A default judgment must be set aside if the claim form was not served correctly.
dispute.exp: CPR 13.2; improper service means the judgment was wrongly entered.

dispute.q: An application for summary judgment automatically stays the proceedings.
dispute.exp: It does not automatically stay proceedings, but hearing dates may be adjusted.

dispute.q: If a Defence is filed late but before the claimant requests judgment, default judgment cannot be entered.
dispute.exp: CPR 12.3(2); the Defence prevents default judgment even if late, provided it is filed before the request.

dispute.q: A 'Request' for default judgment is used for claims for a specified amount of money.
dispute.exp: CPR 12.4(1); administrative process for specified sums.

dispute.q: An 'Application' for default judgment is required if the claim is for an unspecified amount.
dispute.exp: A Request is still used, but the court will enter judgment for an amount 'to be decided' (CPR 12.4(2)).

dispute.q: A defendant has 14 days to file an Acknowledgment of Service.
dispute.exp: CPR 10.3; 14 days after service of the claim form (or Particulars if served separately).

dispute.q: A defendant acting in person cannot be issued a default judgment.
dispute.exp: Default judgment applies to litigants in person just as it does to represented parties.

dispute.q: The court can grant summary judgment of its own initiative.
dispute.exp: CPR 24.2; the court has case management powers to summarily dispose of weak issues.

dispute.q: Admitting the claim within 14 days allows the defendant to ask for time to pay.
dispute.exp: CPR 14.2; admission form (N9A) allows proposals for payment by instalments.

dispute.q: A reply to a defence must be filed within 21 days.
dispute.exp: There is no fixed time in CPR 15; it is usually set by Directions (often with Directions Questionnaire).

dispute.q: Disputing the court's jurisdiction requires an application within 14 days of filing the AoS.
dispute.exp: CPR 11(4); strict deadline to challenge jurisdiction after acknowledging service.

dispute.q: A summary judgment hearing requires 14 days' notice to the respondent.
dispute.exp: CPR 24.4(3); respondent must have at least 14 days' notice.

dispute.q: Default judgment is available in Part 8 claims.
dispute.exp: CPR 12.2; Part 8 procedure does not allow for default judgment.

dispute.q: 'AoS' stands for Acknowledgment of Service.
dispute.exp: Form N9; indicates intention to defend or dispute jurisdiction.

dispute.q: 'Default Judgment' is judgment entered without a trial.
dispute.exp: Because the defendant failed to file an AoS or Defence.

dispute.q: 'Summary Judgment' is judgment entered because the case has no real prospect of success.
dispute.exp: CPR 24; early disposal of weak cases.

dispute.q: 'Set Aside' means to cancel a court order or judgment.
dispute.exp: Restores the position to before the judgment was entered.

dispute.q: 'Defence' is the document setting out the defendant's case.
dispute.exp: A statement of case responding to the Particulars of Claim.

dispute.q: 'Counterclaim' is a claim brought by the defendant against the claimant.
dispute.exp: CPR 20; enables cross-claims in the same proceedings.

dispute.q: 'Admission' confirms the truth of the claimant's case.
dispute.exp: Can be full or partial admission of liability/quantum.

dispute.q: 'Specified Amount' is a fixed sum of money.
dispute.exp: A debt or liquidated sum (e.g., £10,000 invoice).

dispute.q: 'Unspecified Amount' requires the court to decide the value.
dispute.exp: Damages to be assessed (e.g., personal injury compensation).

dispute.q: 'Real Prospect of Success' is the test for Summary Judgment.
dispute.exp: More than merely arguable; a realistic chance of winning.

dispute.q: 'Mandatory Set Aside' means the court has no choice but to cancel judgment.
dispute.exp: Applies when judgment was wrongly entered (CPR 13.2).

dispute.q: 'Discretionary Set Aside' allows the court to choose whether to cancel judgment.
dispute.exp: Applies when the defendant has a real prospect of defending (CPR 13.3).

dispute.q: 'Reply' is the claimant's response to the Defence.
dispute.exp: Optional statement of case to deal with new points in the Defence.

dispute.q: 'Form N9A' is the Admission Form.
dispute.exp: Used to admit the claim and offer payment.

dispute.q: 'Form N9B' is the Defence and Counterclaim Form.
dispute.exp: Used to defend the claim.

dispute.q: 'Form N244' is the Application Notice.
dispute.exp: Standard form for interim applications (e.g., set aside, summary judgment).

dispute.q: 'Stay of Execution' pauses the enforcement of a judgment.
dispute.exp: Often requested alongside an application to set aside.

dispute.q: 'Unless Order' imposes a sanction if not complied with.
dispute.exp: E.g., 'Unless the Defence is filed by 4pm, judgment will be entered'.

dispute.q: 'Part 20 Claim' includes counterclaims and third-party claims.
dispute.exp: Claims other than the main claim between C and D.

dispute.q: 'Denton Principles' apply to relief from sanctions.
dispute.exp: Three-stage test for compliance failures (often cited in set-aside cases).

dispute.q: 'Statement of Case' refers to formal pleadings.
dispute.exp: Claim Form, Particulars, Defence, Reply, Counterclaim.

dispute.q: 'Legal Burden' is the obligation to prove a fact.
dispute.exp: Usually rests on the Claimant.

dispute.q: 'Judgment in Default' is governed by CPR Part 12.
dispute.exp: The specific rule for default judgments.

dispute.q: 'Cheque Rule' prevents a set-off defence against a dishonoured cheque claim.
dispute.exp: Cheques are treated as cash; defenses like set-off rarely apply.

dispute.q: 'Determining the Rate of Payment' sets instalment amounts.
dispute.exp: Court officer decides repayment rate if parties disagree on an admission.

dispute.q: A defendant requires court permission to file a counterclaim with their Defence.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.4; permission is not required if the counterclaim is filed with the Defence.

dispute.q: A counterclaim can continue even if the main claim is stayed or discontinued.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.3; a counterclaim is treated as a separate claim and survives the main action.

dispute.q: A defendant must seek permission to issue an additional claim against a third party 6 months after filing their Defence.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.7; permission is required if the additional claim is not issued before or with the Defence.

dispute.q: The limitation period for a contribution claim under the 1978 Act is 6 years.
dispute.exp: s.10 Limitation Act 1980; the period is 2 years from the date of judgment or settlement.

dispute.q: A party added to a claim after the limitation period is deemed to have been a party from the original issue date.
dispute.exp: s.35 Limitation Act 1980; the claim 'relates back' to the original issue date (doctrine of relation back).

dispute.q: The court can substitute a party after limitation expires to correct a mistake as to liability.
dispute.exp: CPR 19.6; substitution is only allowed for a mistake as to the *name* of the party, not their identity/liability.

dispute.q: A defendant can seek contribution from a co-defendant by filing a notice without permission.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.6; permission is not needed if the notice is filed with the Defence.

dispute.q: Default judgment can be entered on a Part 20 claim against a third party.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.3; default judgment rules apply to third party claims (but special rules apply to contribution notices).

dispute.q: An additional claim is deemed served on a third party when it is issued.
dispute.exp: It must be served along with the appropriate forms (CPR 20.12) within 14 days of issue (CPR 7.5 does not apply exactly the same).

dispute.q: The court will grant permission to add a party if it is merely 'desirable' after limitation has expired.
dispute.exp: Post-limitation, the addition must be 'necessary' (s.35 LA 1980), not just desirable.

dispute.q: A claimant can bring a counterclaim against a defendant's counterclaim.
dispute.exp: This is technically a 'Reply and Defence to Counterclaim', not a distinct counterclaim-on-counterclaim.

dispute.q: A third party becomes a party to the proceedings when the Third Party Notice is issued.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.7; they become a party upon the issuing of the additional claim.

dispute.q: A defendant issuing a counterclaim against the claimant must pay a court fee.
dispute.exp: Counterclaims attract an issue fee based on the value of the counterclaim.

dispute.q: In a contribution claim, the court must apportion liability equally.
dispute.exp: Civil Liability (Contribution) Act 1978; court apportions based on what is 'just and equitable'.

dispute.q: If a defendant settles with the claimant, they cannot seek contribution from a third party.
dispute.exp: s.1(4) CL(C)A 1978; a settling party can still seek contribution if they would have been liable.

dispute.q: Adding a new cause of action after limitation is permitted if it arises from the same facts.
dispute.exp: s.35(5) LA 1980; allowed if the new claim arises out of substantially the same facts.

dispute.q: A mistake as to the name of a party includes suing a subsidiary instead of the holding company.
dispute.exp: Adelson case; this can be a mistake as to name if the description was clear but the name wrong.

dispute.q: Service of a Part 20 claim form on a third party follows the same rules as a standard claim form.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.12; standard service rules (CPR 6) apply.

dispute.q: Before limitation expires, the court can add a party if it is desirable to resolve the dispute.
dispute.exp: CPR 19.2(2); the 'desirable' test applies pre-limitation.

dispute.q: A counterclaiming defendant is referred to as the 'Part 20 Claimant'.
dispute.exp: They remain the 'Defendant'; 'Part 20 Claimant' usually refers to D suing a Third Party.

dispute.q: Permission to make an additional claim can be sought without notice.
dispute.exp: Although the court often directs an on-notice hearing, the application can be made without notice initially.

dispute.q: A person cannot be added as a claimant unless they give their consent in writing.
dispute.exp: CPR 19.4(4); nobody can be compelled to be a claimant.

dispute.q: If a proposed claimant refuses consent, they must be added as a defendant.
dispute.exp: CPR 19.4; necessary parties who refuse to join as claimants are joined as defendants.

dispute.q: A counterclaim must serve the same purpose as a defence.
dispute.exp: A defence resists the claim; a counterclaim is an independent sword seeking its own remedy.

dispute.q: A defendant can use a counterclaim to set off damages against the claimant's claim.
dispute.exp: Equitable set-off is often pleaded alongside a counterclaim.

dispute.q: 'Part 20 Claim' encompasses counterclaims and third-party claims.
dispute.exp: The generic term for additional claims under CPR 20.

dispute.q: 'Counterclaim' is a claim by a defendant against a claimant.
dispute.exp: A cross-action in the same proceedings.

dispute.q: 'Third Party' is a person not originally part of the proceedings.
dispute.exp: Joined via a Part 20 claim by a defendant.

dispute.q: 'Contribution' is sharing the burden of liability.
dispute.exp: Recovering a share of damages paid from another liable party.

dispute.q: 'Indemnity' is the right to recover 100% of the loss from another.
dispute.exp: Complete reimbursement, distinct from partial contribution.

dispute.q: 'Part 20 Defendant' is the target of an additional claim.
dispute.exp: Can be the original claimant (in a counterclaim) or a third party.

dispute.q: 'Limitation Act 1980 s.35' governs new claims in pending actions.
dispute.exp: The statutory rules for adding parties/claims post-limitation.

dispute.q: 'Relation Back' treats a new claim as starting on the original issue date.
dispute.exp: Prevents the limitation defence for the new party/claim.

dispute.q: 'Set-Off' reduces the amount owed to the claimant.
dispute.exp: A defence that subtracts the defendant's claim from the claimant's.

dispute.q: 'Substitution' replaces one party with another.
dispute.exp: Used when the original party was named by mistake.

dispute.q: 'Addition' joins a new party alongside existing ones.
dispute.exp: CPR 19.2; adding a party to resolve matters in dispute.

dispute.q: 'Mistake as to Name' is a specific ground for substitution.
dispute.exp: The only ground to change parties after limitation (Sardinia Sulcis).

dispute.q: 'Contribution Notice' is used between co-defendants.
dispute.exp: CPR 20.6; formally claiming contribution from an existing party.

dispute.q: 'Joint Liability' means parties are liable together for the whole.
dispute.exp: Claimant can sue one or all for the full amount.

dispute.q: 'Several Liability' means parties are liable only for their share.
dispute.exp: Distinct from joint liability.

dispute.q: 'Civil Liability (Contribution) Act 1978' governs contribution.
dispute.exp: Statutory basis for claiming shares of liability.

dispute.q: 'Same Damage' is a requirement for contribution.
dispute.exp: The parties must be liable for the same damage to the claimant.

dispute.q: 'Necessary' is the test for adding parties post-limitation.
dispute.exp: s.35 LA 1980; stricter than the 'desirable' pre-limitation test.

dispute.q: 'Consolidation' combines two separate claims into one.
dispute.exp: Case management power to manage linked cases.

dispute.q: 'Directions Questionnaire' is used to allocate the track.
dispute.exp: Standard case management form.

dispute.q: 'Permission' is leave of the court.
dispute.exp: Required for many steps, including late counterclaims.

dispute.q: 'Defence to Counterclaim' must be filed by the claimant.
dispute.exp: Usually within 14 days of the counterclaim.

dispute.q: 'Reply' is optional.
dispute.exp: Claimant's response to defence; not mandatory.

dispute.q: 'Default Judgment' is not available in Part 8 claims.
dispute.exp: CPR 12.2; Part 8 is for disputes of law, not fact.

dispute.q: 'Acknowledgment of Service' extends time for Defence.
dispute.exp: From 14 days to 28 days.

dispute.q: An application notice must be served at least 3 clear days before the hearing.
dispute.exp: CPR 23.7(1)(b); the general rule is 3 clear days unless a different period is specified.

dispute.q: Evidence in support of an interim application is usually provided by affidavit.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.6; evidence is usually by Witness Statement, though affidavits are used for freezing/search orders.

dispute.q: A Master can grant an interim injunction in the High Court.
dispute.exp: PD 2B; Masters (and District Judges) generally cannot grant injunctions (except in limited circumstances like consents).

dispute.q: The 'American Cyanamid' guidelines apply to final injunctions.
dispute.exp: American Cyanamid applies to *interim* injunctions; final injunctions are decided on the merits at trial.

dispute.q: To obtain an interim payment, the claimant must show a 'real prospect of success'.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.7; the test is 'satisfied that the claimant *would* obtain judgment' (a higher burden).

dispute.q: Security for costs can be ordered against a claimant resident in the UK.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.13; residence outside the jurisdiction (Hague/Lugano conventions notwithstanding) is the ground; UK residence bars it.

dispute.q: Impecuniosity of a corporate claimant is a ground for security for costs.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.13(2)(c); security can be ordered if there is reason to believe the company cannot pay costs.

dispute.q: An interim payment cannot exceed a 'reasonable proportion' of the likely final damages.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.7(4); the court must not award more than a reasonable proportion.

dispute.q: If an interim application is made without notice, the applicant has a duty of full and frank disclosure.
dispute.exp: The applicant must disclose all material facts, including those adverse to their case.

dispute.q: A freezing order creates a proprietary interest in the frozen assets.
dispute.exp: A freezing order operates *in personam* to prevent dissipation; it does not give the claimant priority over creditors.

dispute.q: A cross-undertaking in damages is mandatory for a search order.
dispute.exp: The applicant must undertake to pay damages to the respondent if the order turns out to be wrongly granted.

dispute.q: The first stage of American Cyanamid is to establish a 'prima facie case'.
dispute.exp: The test is whether there is a 'serious issue to be tried', which is a lower threshold than prima facie case.

dispute.q: Security for costs can be ordered against an individual claimant who is impecunious.
dispute.exp: Impecuniosity alone is not a ground against an individual (unlike a company); other grounds must exist.

dispute.q: An application for an interim payment can be made before the Defence is filed.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.6; the claimant cannot apply until the time for filing Acknowledgement of Service has expired.

dispute.q: Costs 'in any event' means the winner of the application gets paid regardless of the trial outcome.
dispute.exp: The party is entitled to those costs whatever the final result of the proceedings.

dispute.q: If an order is silent as to costs, 'costs in the case' is implied.
dispute.exp: CPR 44.10; if the order is silent, no party is entitled to costs of that application.

dispute.q: A 'Freezing Order' requires a 'good arguable case' on the merits.
dispute.exp: This is a higher threshold than the 'serious issue to be tried' for standard injunctions.

dispute.q: The court can grant security for costs if the claimant has taken steps to put assets beyond reach.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.13(2)(g); applies if the claimant has dissipated assets to evade enforcement.

dispute.q: Unless declared 'totally without merit', a respondent can re-apply to set aside a without notice order.
dispute.exp: CPR 23.10; a person served with an order made without notice may apply to set it aside within 7 days.

dispute.q: The 'Balance of Convenience' is considered before the 'Adequacy of Damages' in American Cyanamid.
dispute.exp: Adequacy of damages is considered *first*; if damages are adequate, no injunction is granted.

dispute.q: A telephone hearing is the default for applications expected to last less than 1 hour.
dispute.exp: PD 23A; unless the court orders otherwise or it involves oral evidence.

dispute.q: Interim payment can be ordered if the defendant has admitted liability.
dispute.exp: CPR 25.7(1)(a); admission of liability is one of the grounds for an interim payment.

dispute.q: An applicant for a search order must show a risk of 'serious' harm.
dispute.exp: Anton Piller KG v Manufacturing Processes; must show potential for 'very serious' harm.

dispute.q: Security for costs effectively stays the claim until the money is paid into court.
dispute.exp: The order usually imposes a stay of proceedings pending payment.

dispute.q: A consent order must be approved by a judge to be binding.
dispute.exp: CPR 40.6; simply agreeing is not enough, the court must seal the order.

dispute.q: 'Interim Application' is a request for a court order pending trial.
dispute.exp: Used to manage the case or protect positions before final judgment.

dispute.q: 'Applicant' is the party making the application.
dispute.exp: Usually the Claimant or Defendant.

dispute.q: 'Respondent' is the party answering the application.
dispute.exp: The party against whom the order is sought.

dispute.q: 'Without Notice' means the respondent is not warned.
dispute.exp: Formerly 'ex parte'; used for urgency or secrecy (e.g., freezing orders).

dispute.q: 'On Notice' means the application is served on the respondent.
dispute.exp: The standard procedure ensuring fairness.

dispute.q: 'Form N244' is the Application Notice.
dispute.exp: The standard form used to apply for an interim order.

dispute.q: 'Interim Injunction' preserves the status quo until trial.
dispute.exp: Prevents irreversible harm before the main dispute is resolved.

dispute.q: 'Freezing Order' prevents the disposal of assets.
dispute.exp: Formerly 'Mareva injunction'; secures funds for potential judgment.

dispute.q: 'Search Order' allows entry to premises to preserve evidence.
dispute.exp: Formerly 'Anton Piller order'; prevents destruction of evidence.

dispute.q: 'Security for Costs' protects the defendant against unrecoverable costs.
dispute.exp: Money paid into court by the claimant to cover the defendant's costs if the defence wins.

dispute.q: 'Interim Payment' is an advance payment of damages.
dispute.exp: Paid by a defendant on account of any damages they will be liable for.

dispute.q: 'Cross-undertaking' is a promise to pay damages to the respondent.
dispute.exp: Price of an interim injunction; compensates respondent if the injunction was wrong.

dispute.q: 'American Cyanamid' sets the test for interim injunctions.
dispute.exp: The leading case establishing the 'balance of convenience' test.

dispute.q: 'Costs in the Case' means the winner at trial gets the application costs.
dispute.exp: Costs follow the final judgment.

dispute.q: 'Costs Reserved' means the decision on costs is deferred.
dispute.exp: The trial judge will decide who pays the application costs later.

dispute.q: 'Costs in Any Event' means the winner of the application gets costs now.
dispute.exp: Paid regardless of who wins the final trial.

dispute.q: 'Summarily Assessed' means costs are calculated by the judge on the day.
dispute.exp: Standard for interim hearings lasting less than a day.

dispute.q: 'Consent Order' records an agreement between parties.
dispute.exp: Binding order made with the agreement of both sides.

dispute.q: 'Full and Frank Disclosure' is the duty to reveal all material facts.
dispute.exp: Essential for 'without notice' applications to ensure fairness.

dispute.q: 'Status Quo' refers to the existing state of affairs.
dispute.exp: Preserving the status quo is a key aim of interim injunctions.

dispute.q: 'Return Date' is the date for a full hearing after a without notice order.
dispute.exp: When the respondent can present their arguments against the order.

dispute.q: 'Penal Notice' warns of imprisonment for disobedience.
dispute.exp: Must be attached to injunctions for contempt proceedings to follow.

dispute.q: 'Prohibitory Injunction' forbids an act.
dispute.exp: Orders a party to refrain from doing something.

dispute.q: 'Mandatory Injunction' requires an act to be done.
dispute.exp: Orders a party to actively do something (higher threshold than prohibitory).

dispute.q: 'Just and Convenient' is the statutory basis for injunctions.
dispute.exp: s.37 Senior Courts Act 1981.

dispute.q: A claim for £80,000 with a 4-day trial estimate is allocated to the Multi-track.
dispute.exp: CPR 26.9; claims between £25k-£100k with trial ≤3 days are usually Intermediate Track.

dispute.q: In the Small Claims Track, the court will generally order the loser to pay the winner's legal costs.
dispute.exp: CPR 27.14; costs are severely restricted in the Small Claims Track (fixed costs only).

dispute.q: Parties must file a Directions Questionnaire to assist the court in allocating the claim.
dispute.exp: CPR 26.3; Form N181 is used to provide case management information.

dispute.q: Failure to file a costs budget on time restricts the party to recovering court fees only.
dispute.exp: CPR 3.14; automatic sanction limits recoverable costs to applicable court fees.

dispute.q: On the Standard Basis, any doubt as to reasonableness is resolved in favour of the receiving party.
dispute.exp: CPR 44.3; on the Standard Basis, doubt is resolved in favour of the *paying* party.

dispute.q: The court will not depart from an approved costs budget unless there is a good reason.
dispute.exp: CPR 3.18; the approved budget binds the assessment unless there is 'good reason'.

dispute.q: A claimant with a personal injury claim is protected by Qualified One-Way Costs Shifting (QOCS).
dispute.exp: CPR 44.13; QOCS protects PI claimants from paying defendant costs if the claim fails.

dispute.q: If a PI claimant is found to be fundamentally dishonest, QOCS protection is lost.
dispute.exp: CPR 44.16; the court can enforce a full costs order against a dishonest claimant.

dispute.q: Costs on the Indemnity Basis must be proportionate to the matters in issue.
dispute.exp: CPR 44.3; proportionality does not apply to Indemnity Basis costs, only reasonableness.

dispute.q: Summary assessment of costs usually takes place at the conclusion of a one-day hearing.
dispute.exp: PD 44; summary assessment is the norm for fast track trials and hearings ≤1 day.

dispute.q: Detailed assessment proceedings must be commenced within 6 months of judgment.
dispute.exp: CPR 47.7; the deadline is 3 months from the date of the judgment/order.

dispute.q: A claim allocated to the Fast Track is expected to last no longer than one day.
dispute.exp: CPR 26.9; Fast Track is for claims >£10k-£25k with a trial estimate of ≤1 day.

dispute.q: Expert evidence in the Fast Track is usually limited to one expert per party in any field.
dispute.exp: CPR 28.3; expert evidence is usually limited to *one joint expert* in the Fast Track.

dispute.q: A Costs Management Conference is mandatory for all Multi-track cases.
dispute.exp: It is not mandatory if the court orders otherwise or for claims involving minors/life expectancy.

dispute.q: If a party beats their own Part 36 offer at trial, they may be awarded indemnity costs.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17; indemnity costs apply from the date the relevant period expired.

dispute.q: Fixed Recoverable Costs (FRC) apply to most Fast Track claims.
dispute.exp: CPR 45; FRC applies to the majority of Fast Track and Intermediate Track claims.

dispute.q: The Denton test is used when applying for relief from sanctions.
dispute.exp: Denton v TH White; the three-stage test for relief from sanctions (CPR 3.9).

dispute.q: A request to revise a budget due to 'significant developments' must be made promptly.
dispute.exp: PD 3E; revision allows updating budgets for unforeseen major costs.

dispute.q: Solicitors must notify the court of the outcome of a stay for settlement within 7 days.
dispute.exp: Usually the court sets a specific date; no automatic 7-day rule exists in the CPR.

dispute.q: Interim payments on account of costs are rarely ordered before detailed assessment.
dispute.exp: CPR 44.2(8); the court *will* generally order a reasonable sum on account.

dispute.q: The Intermediate Track has a normal trial limit of 5 days.
dispute.exp: CPR 26.9; Intermediate Track trials should not exceed 3 days.

dispute.q: In assessment of costs, a 'Point of Dispute' is filed by the receiving party.
dispute.exp: Points of Dispute are filed by the *paying* party; Replies are filed by the receiving party.

dispute.q: A non-party can be ordered to pay costs if they control the litigation.
dispute.exp: s.51 SCA 1981; Non-Party Costs Orders (NPCO) are possible for funders/controllers.

dispute.q: Unless Orders take effect without further action from the court.
dispute.exp: The sanction applies automatically upon non-compliance (e.g., striking out).

dispute.q: Costs budgets (Precedent H) must be filed 21 days before the CMC for claims over £50,000.
dispute.exp: CPR 3.13; 21 days for >£50k; 7 days for <£50k.

dispute.q: 'Allocation' assigns a case to a management track.
dispute.exp: Small Claims, Fast, Intermediate, or Multi-track.

dispute.q: 'Directions Questionnaire' (N181) provides info for allocation.
dispute.exp: Filed by parties after the defence is served.

dispute.q: 'Small Claims Track' is usually for claims under £10,000.
dispute.exp: Designed for simple disputes with limited cost recovery.

dispute.q: 'Fast Track' is for claims between £10,000 and £25,000.
dispute.exp: For straightforward cases with short trials.

dispute.q: 'Intermediate Track' is for claims between £25,000 and £100,000.
dispute.exp: Introduced in 2023 for moderately complex cases.

dispute.q: 'Multi-Track' is for complex claims or those over £100,000.
dispute.exp: The most flexible and managed track.

dispute.q: 'CMC' stands for Case Management Conference.
dispute.exp: A hearing to set directions and budgets.

dispute.q: 'Precedent H' is the form for a Costs Budget.
dispute.exp: Must be filed before the CMC.

dispute.q: 'Precedent R' is the Budget Discussion Report.
dispute.exp: Used to agree or dispute the opponent's budget phases.

dispute.q: 'Costs Management Order' (CMO) approves the budgets.
dispute.exp: The court records the agreed/approved figures.

dispute.q: 'Standard Basis' costs must be reasonable and proportionate.
dispute.exp: The default basis for assessment.

dispute.q: 'Indemnity Basis' costs need only be reasonable.
dispute.exp: Proportionality is not required; doubt favors the receiver.

dispute.q: 'Summary Assessment' happens at the end of a hearing.
dispute.exp: The judge assesses costs immediately.

dispute.q: 'Detailed Assessment' is a separate procedure to quantify costs.
dispute.exp: Used for large costs bills after trial.

dispute.q: 'QOCS' stands for Qualified One-Way Costs Shifting.
dispute.exp: Protects PI claimants from adverse costs.

dispute.q: 'Fundamental Dishonesty' removes QOCS protection.
dispute.exp: If the claimant has been dishonest about a core element.

dispute.q: 'Proportionality' links costs to the value/complexity of the claim.
dispute.exp: Costs should not exceed what is reasonable for the dispute.

dispute.q: 'Statement of Costs' (N260) is used for summary assessment.
dispute.exp: Must be filed 24 hours before the hearing.

dispute.q: 'Relief from Sanctions' asks the court to forgive a mistake.
dispute.exp: CPR 3.9; applies when a rule/order has been breached.

dispute.q: 'Unless Order' specifies a sanction for non-compliance.
dispute.exp: Final warning before striking out.

dispute.q: 'Stay of Proceedings' pauses the case.
dispute.exp: Often used to allow for settlement or ADR.

dispute.q: 'Points of Dispute' challenge a detailed bill of costs.
dispute.exp: Served by the paying party in detailed assessment.

dispute.q: 'Default Costs Certificate' is issued if no Points of Dispute are filed.
dispute.exp: The receiving party gets the full amount claimed.

dispute.q: 'Sanderson Order' makes the loser pay the successful co-defendant.
dispute.exp: Direct costs order between defendants.

dispute.q: 'Bullock Order' makes the claimant pay the winner and reclaim from the loser.
dispute.exp: Indirect costs reimbursement in multi-defendant cases.

dispute.q: A party must disclose a document that adversely affects their own case.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.6(b); standard disclosure requires disclosing documents that adversely affect your own case.

dispute.q: A document is only 'in your control' if you have physical possession of it.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.8; control includes physical possession, a right to possession, or a right to inspect/take copies.

dispute.q: Copies of documents must be disclosed even if they contain no new modifications.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.9; you need not disclose more than one copy of the same document unless it contains a modification/marking.

dispute.q: Legal Advice Privilege protects communications between a client and their accountant for legal advice.
dispute.exp: R (Prudential) v Special Commissioner; LAP applies only to lawyers, not other professionals.

dispute.q: Litigation Privilege protects communications with third parties if litigation is merely 'possible'.
dispute.exp: USA v Philip Morris; litigation must be 'reasonably prospective' (pending or contemplated), not just a mere possibility.

dispute.q: A document created for two purposes is privileged if litigation was the 'dominant' purpose.
dispute.exp: Waugh v British Railways Board; the dominant purpose test applies to litigation privilege.

dispute.q: A party can redact irrelevant commercial information from a disclosed document.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.6 / GE Capital v Bankers Trust; irrelevant parts can be redacted (blanked out) to protect confidentiality.

dispute.q: The duty of disclosure ends once the List of Documents is served.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.11; the duty of disclosure is continuous until the proceedings are concluded.

dispute.q: A solicitor who signs a disclosure statement without honest belief commits contempt of court.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.23; false disclosure statements can lead to contempt proceedings.

dispute.q: Without Prejudice privilege is automatically waived if the settlement offer is rejected.
dispute.exp: Privilege remains to protect the negotiation; it is not lost simply because the offer is rejected.

dispute.q: A party can inspect a document mentioned in the opponent's witness statement.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.14; a party may inspect a document mentioned in a statement of case, witness statement, or affidavit.

dispute.q: Internal client notes discussing legal advice are protected by Legal Advice Privilege.
dispute.exp: Three Rivers (No 5); repetition of legal advice internally within the client organization keeps privilege.

dispute.q: If a privileged document is inadvertently disclosed, the recipient can always use it.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.20; the court can forbid use if the mistake was obvious (Al Fayed v Commissioner of Police).

dispute.q: A 'reasonable search' requires looking at every single backup tape.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.7; reasonableness depends on the number of documents, complexity, and proportionality (cost).

dispute.q: In-house lawyers are not covered by Legal Advice Privilege.
dispute.exp: Alfred Crompton v Customs & Excise; in-house lawyers are covered, provided they are acting in a legal capacity.

dispute.q: Specific disclosure can be ordered if the initial standard disclosure was inadequate.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.12; the court may make an order for specific disclosure or inspection.

dispute.q: Privilege cannot be claimed for a document that evidences fraud.
dispute.exp: The 'iniquity' exception (R v Cox and Railton); privilege does not cover communications furthering crime/fraud.

dispute.q: Waiver of privilege in a partial document usually waives privilege for the whole document.
dispute.exp: Great Atlantic Insurance v Home Insurance; 'cherry picking' is not allowed (collateral waiver).

dispute.q: A party can withhold inspection of a document on the grounds of disproportionate cost.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.3(2); inspection can be withheld if it is disproportionate to the issues in the case.

dispute.q: Metadata of electronic documents is never disclosable.
dispute.exp: PD 31B; metadata is part of the document and can be relevant/disclosable.

dispute.q: A solicitors' attendance note of a meeting with the client is privileged.
dispute.exp: Protected by Legal Advice Privilege as part of the continuum of communication.

dispute.q: Employees are always considered 'the client' for Legal Advice Privilege.
dispute.exp: Three Rivers (No 5); 'client' is narrowly defined to those authorized to instruct/receive advice.

dispute.q: Without Prejudice Save as to Costs documents can be seen by the trial judge before judgment.
dispute.exp: They can only be seen *after* judgment on liability, when deciding costs.

dispute.q: Disclosure generally takes place 14 days after the CMC.
dispute.exp: Dates are set at the CMC; there is no automatic 14-day rule (often 4-6 weeks).

dispute.q: A party must search for documents held by their agent.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.8; documents with an agent are under the party's 'right to possession' (control).

dispute.q: 'Standard Disclosure' requires disclosing documents you rely on.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.6(a); the first limb of standard disclosure.

dispute.q: 'Adverse Documents' hurt your own case.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.6(b); documents which adversely affect your own case.

dispute.q: 'Supportive Documents' help the other side's case.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.6(b); documents which support another party's case.

dispute.q: 'Inspection' is the right to see and copy disclosed documents.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.3; usually follows the exchange of lists.

dispute.q: 'List of Documents' (N265) identifies disclosed items.
dispute.exp: Form used to categorize documents (e.g., inspectable vs. privileged).

dispute.q: 'Disclosure Statement' confirms the extent of the search.
dispute.exp: Signed by the party (not the solicitor) certifying the search was reasonable.

dispute.q: 'Privilege' allows a party to withhold inspection.
dispute.exp: The document is disclosed (listed) but not inspected.

dispute.q: 'Legal Advice Privilege' protects confidential lawyer-client comms.
dispute.exp: For the purpose of giving or receiving legal advice.

dispute.q: 'Litigation Privilege' covers third-party communications.
dispute.exp: Only if the dominant purpose is pending or contemplated litigation.

dispute.q: 'Without Prejudice' protects genuine settlement negotiations.
dispute.exp: Encourages parties to settle without fear of admissions being used in court.

dispute.q: 'Redaction' involves blanking out parts of a document.
dispute.exp: Used for irrelevant or privileged information within a relevant document.

dispute.q: 'Reasonable Search' is the standard for finding documents.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.7; determined by complexity, value, and significance.

dispute.q: 'Specific Disclosure' is a court order for particular documents.
dispute.exp: Used when a party believes the other has failed to disclose relevant documents.

dispute.q: 'Control' includes the right to possession.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.8; physical possession is not the only criteria.

dispute.q: 'Electronic Disclosure' covers emails and metadata.
dispute.exp: PD 31B; special rules for e-disclosure.

dispute.q: 'Dominant Purpose' is the main reason a document was created.
dispute.exp: The test for Litigation Privilege (Waugh v British Railways Board).

dispute.q: 'Waiver' is the voluntary surrender of privilege.
dispute.exp: Can be express or implied (e.g., by reading part of it in court).

dispute.q: 'Inadvertent Disclosure' is accidental revelation of privileged documents.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.20 provides a mechanism to correct this.

dispute.q: 'Solicitor's Lien' allows holding documents until fees are paid.
dispute.exp: A right to retain property as security for debt.

dispute.q: 'Norwich Pharmacal Order' requires a third party to disclose info.
dispute.exp: Used to identify a wrongdoer involved in misconduct.

dispute.q: 'Pre-Action Disclosure' occurs before proceedings start.
dispute.exp: s.33 SCA 1981 / CPR 31.16; to assist settlement or save costs.

dispute.q: 'Continuing Duty' means disclosure obligations last until judgment.
dispute.exp: New relevant documents found later must be disclosed immediately.

dispute.q: 'Document' includes anything on which information is recorded.
dispute.exp: CPR 31.4; includes tapes, discs, emails, and photos.

dispute.q: 'Confidentiality' is the same as Privilege.
dispute.exp: Confidentiality is a duty; Privilege is a right to withhold inspection (a stronger protection).

dispute.q: 'Three Rivers' defined the 'client' for privilege.
dispute.exp: Narrow definition restricting 'client' to those authorised to instruct lawyers.

dispute.q: Failure to serve a witness statement on time automatically prevents the witness from giving oral evidence.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.10; the witness may not be called unless the court gives permission (relief from sanctions).

dispute.q: A party must give 7 days' notice to challenge the authenticity of a disclosed document.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.19; notice must be served by the latest date for serving witness statements or within 7 days of disclosure.

dispute.q: Written questions to an expert must be put within 28 days of service of the report.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.6; questions can be put once only within 28 days to clarify the report.

dispute.q: Answers to written questions to an expert do not form part of the expert's report.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.6(3); the answers are treated as part of the expert's report.

dispute.q: A witness summons is binding if served less than 7 days before the trial.
dispute.exp: CPR 34.6; a witness summons is only binding if served at least 7 days before the date on which the witness is required.

dispute.q: Hearsay evidence is generally inadmissible in civil proceedings.
dispute.exp: s.1 Civil Evidence Act 1995; in civil proceedings evidence shall not be excluded on the ground that it is hearsay.

dispute.q: A hearsay notice is mandatory if the witness is to be called to give oral evidence.
dispute.exp: CPR 33.2; notice is only required if the party intends to rely on the hearsay *without* calling the maker of the statement.

dispute.q: The court can direct that expert evidence be given by a Single Joint Expert.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.7; the court has the power to direct that evidence is given by one expert only.

dispute.q: An agreement between experts in a joint statement is automatically binding on the parties.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.12(5); the agreement is not binding unless the parties expressly agree to be bound by it.

dispute.q: A Notice to Admit Facts must be served no later than 21 days before trial.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.18; creates cost consequences if the fact is later proved.

dispute.q: A conviction in a UK court is admissible as evidence that the person committed the offence.
dispute.exp: s.11 Civil Evidence Act 1968; a subsisting conviction is admissible evidence.

dispute.q: A witness statement can be used as evidence in chief even if the witness is not called.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.5(1); but it will be treated as hearsay evidence (s.1 CEA 1995).

dispute.q: Parties require the court's permission to call an expert witness.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.4; no party may call an expert or put in a report without the court's permission.

dispute.q: Conduct money (travel expenses) must be offered when serving a witness summons.
dispute.exp: CPR 34.7; the witness is not obliged to attend unless paid a sum to cover travel/expenses.

dispute.q: The weight of hearsay evidence is reduced if it is multiple hearsay.
dispute.exp: s.4 Civil Evidence Act 1995; multiple hearsay is one of the factors reducing weight.

dispute.q: Instructions to a Single Joint Expert are privileged from the other party.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.8; instructions must be sent to the other instructing parties.

dispute.q: A witness can be cross-examined on the contents of their witness statement.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.11; where a witness is called, they can be cross-examined on their statement.

dispute.q: An expert's fees can be contingent on the outcome of the case.
dispute.exp: Civil Justice Council Guidance; experts must be independent, and contingent fees undermine this.

dispute.q: Evidence of plans and photographs is admissible without notice.
dispute.exp: CPR 33.6; evidence is not receivable unless notice (or the item itself) is given by the witness statement deadline.

dispute.q: A party can amplify a witness statement at trial without permission.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.5(3); permission is required to give evidence arising from new matters or to amplify.

dispute.q: The court can limit the issues on which expert evidence is directed.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.4; the court restricts expert evidence to what is reasonably required.

dispute.q: If an expert changes their view, they must notify all parties in writing.
dispute.exp: PD 35; the duty to the court requires communicating any material change of view.

dispute.q: Draft expert reports are usually privileged.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.10(4) implies drafts are privileged/not inspectable (unless substance is not in final report).

dispute.q: A witness giving evidence by video link does not require court permission.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.3; the court may allow video link evidence (VCF) but permission is required.

dispute.q: If a party attacks the character of an opposing witness, they can introduce evidence of bad character.
dispute.exp: Common law rule; credibility can be challenged ('credit').

dispute.q: 'Hearsay' is an out of court statement repeated to prove the truth of its contents.
dispute.exp: s.1(2) Civil Evidence Act 1995.

dispute.q: 'Evidence in Chief' is the initial questioning of a witness by the calling party.
dispute.exp: Usually stands as the witness statement in civil trials (CPR 32.5).

dispute.q: 'Cross-examination' is questioning by the opposing party.
dispute.exp: Used to test the evidence and credibility.

dispute.q: 'Re-examination' occurs after cross-examination.
dispute.exp: Used to clarify points raised in cross-examination.

dispute.q: 'Expert Witness' provides opinion evidence.
dispute.exp: Qualified to give opinion on matters within their expertise (CPR 35).

dispute.q: 'Witness of Fact' gives evidence on what they perceived.
dispute.exp: Cannot generally give opinion evidence.

dispute.q: 'Single Joint Expert' (SJE) acts for both parties.
dispute.exp: Instructed jointly to save costs (CPR 35.7).

dispute.q: 'Witness Summons' compels a witness to attend court.
dispute.exp: CPR 34; failure to attend is contempt.

dispute.q: 'Conduct Money' covers the witness's travel expenses.
dispute.exp: Must be paid at the time of service of the summons.

dispute.q: 'Notice to Admit' asks a party to admit facts or documents.
dispute.exp: CPR 32.18; saves costs of proving undisputed facts.

dispute.q: 'Affidavit' is a sworn written statement.
dispute.exp: Signed under oath/affirmation; used in freezing orders/search orders.

dispute.q: 'Witness Statement' is a signed written statement of fact.
dispute.exp: The standard form of written evidence in civil proceedings (CPR 32.4).

dispute.q: 'Civil Evidence Act 1995' abolished the rule against hearsay.
dispute.exp: Made hearsay generally admissible in civil proceedings.

dispute.q: 'Standard of Proof' in civil cases is the balance of probabilities.
dispute.exp: More likely than not (>50%).

dispute.q: 'Burden of Proof' lies on the person asserting the fact.
dispute.exp: Usually the claimant ('he who asserts must prove').

dispute.q: 'Statement of Truth' verifies the content of a witness statement.
dispute.exp: CPR 22; honest belief in the facts stated.

dispute.q: 'Privilege against Self-Incrimination' applies in civil proceedings.
dispute.exp: s.14 Civil Evidence Act 1968; right to refuse to answer incriminating questions.

dispute.q: 'Ikarian Reefer' sets out the duties of an expert.
dispute.exp: National Justice Compania Naviera SA v Prudential Assurance; duty is to the court.

dispute.q: 'Opinion Evidence' is generally inadmissible from factual witnesses.
dispute.exp: s.3(2) CEA 1972; admissible only if it conveys perceived facts.

dispute.q: 'Exhibit' is a document referred to in a witness statement.
dispute.exp: Must be verified and attached to the statement.

dispute.q: 'Hostile Witness' gives evidence adverse to the party calling them.
dispute.exp: Can be cross-examined by their own side with leave.

dispute.q: 'Leading Question' suggests the answer.
dispute.exp: Allowed in cross-examination but not generally in chief.

dispute.q: 'Trial Bundle' contains documents for the court hearing.
dispute.exp: CPR 39.5; must be filed 3-7 days before trial.

dispute.q: 'Similar Fact Evidence' is admissible if relevant.
dispute.exp: O'Brien v Chief Constable of South Wales Police; e.g. previous conduct.

dispute.q: 'Without Prejudice' applies to meetings between experts.
dispute.exp: CPR 35.12(4); discussions are not disclosed unless agreed.

dispute.q: A Part 36 offer must specify a period of at least 21 days for acceptance.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.5(1)(c); the 'relevant period' must be not less than 21 days.

dispute.q: A Part 36 offer can be withdrawn without court permission during the relevant period.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.10; permission is required to withdraw or make the offer less advantageous during the 21 days.

dispute.q: A defendant's Part 36 offer must generally be inclusive of interest.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.5(4); the offer is treated as inclusive of all interest until the relevant period expires.

dispute.q: An offer stating 'this offer is valid for 14 days' is a valid Part 36 offer.
dispute.exp: C v D [2011]; a 'sunset clause' (automatic expiry) makes the offer non-compliant with Part 36.

dispute.q: If a claimant accepts a Part 36 offer late, the defendant is usually entitled to costs from the expiry of the relevant period.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.13(5); the offeree pays the offeror's costs for the period of delay.

dispute.q: A claimant who matches (but does not beat) their own Part 36 offer at trial gets Part 36 rewards.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17(1)(b); the test for a claimant's offer is obtaining a judgment 'at least as advantageous'.

dispute.q: A claimant who matches (but does not beat) a defendant's Part 36 offer must pay the defendant's costs.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17(1)(a); for a defendant's offer, the claimant must obtain judgment 'better than' the offer.

dispute.q: The 'Additional Amount' awarded to a successful claimant is capped at £50,000.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17(4)(d); the cap for the additional amount is £75,000.

dispute.q: An offer to settle 'inclusive of costs' is a valid Part 36 offer.
dispute.exp: Mitchell v James; a Part 36 offer must assume costs are payable in addition (CPR 36.5).

dispute.q: A Part 36 offer can be made in respect of a counterclaim.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.2(3); Part 36 applies to counterclaims and additional claims.

dispute.q: A Tomlin Order schedule is automatically confidential.
dispute.exp: The schedule is not on the court file open to inspection, preserving confidentiality.

dispute.q: Breach of a term in the schedule of a Tomlin Order is contempt of court.
dispute.exp: The schedule is a contract; breach is a breach of contract, not contempt (unlike the main order).

dispute.q: The cost consequences of Part 36 apply fully to the Small Claims Track.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.2; Part 36 rules generally do not override the no-costs rule in Small Claims.

dispute.q: A Part 36 offer accepted before trial stays the proceedings.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.14; the claim is stayed upon acceptance.

dispute.q: An interim payment can be a valid Part 36 offer.
dispute.exp: A Part 36 offer must be an offer to settle the whole or part of the claim, not just an interim payment.

dispute.q: A Part 36 offer made 10 days before trial is invalid.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.5; it is valid, but the 'relevant period' will not expire before trial, affecting cost consequences.

dispute.q: To enforce a Tomlin Order, a fresh claim form must be issued.
dispute.exp: An application is made within the existing proceedings (which are stayed, not concluded).

dispute.q: Indemnity costs awarded under Part 36 carry interest at up to 10% above base rate.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17(4)(c); enhanced interest on costs is one of the rewards.

dispute.q: A Calderbank offer provides automatic cost protection.
dispute.exp: Calderbank offers are a factor for the court's discretion (CPR 44.2), not automatic protection.

dispute.q: A Part 36 offer can be accepted at trial without the court's permission.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.11(3); once the trial has started, permission is required to accept.

dispute.q: The 'Additional Amount' is calculated on the damages awarded including interest.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17(4); 10% of the sum awarded (money claims) inclusive of pre-judgment interest.

dispute.q: If a Part 36 offer is withdrawn, the offeree can never accept it.
dispute.exp: It can be accepted later only if the court gives permission (rare).

dispute.q: A generic offer to 'settle all claims' covers future claims not yet pleaded.
dispute.exp: Normally covers only claims in the proceedings unless expressly drafted to be wider.

dispute.q: A claimant failing to beat a defendant's offer pays costs on the indemnity basis.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17(3); they pay costs on the *standard* basis (unless ordered otherwise).

dispute.q: Part 36 rewards apply to a claimant even if they are awarded £0 damages.
dispute.exp: The claimant must obtain a judgment *at least as advantageous*; £0 is usually a loss.

dispute.q: 'Part 36 Offer' is a settlement offer compliant with CPR Part 36.
dispute.exp: Strict formalities apply to gain cost consequences.

dispute.q: 'Calderbank Offer' is written 'without prejudice save as to costs'.
dispute.exp: Common law offer used where Part 36 is not appropriate.

dispute.q: 'Tomlin Order' stays proceedings on agreed terms.
dispute.exp: Terms are in a confidential schedule.

dispute.q: 'Relevant Period' is the 21-day window for acceptance.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.5; usually 21 days.

dispute.q: 'Without Prejudice' privilege prevents the court seeing the document.
dispute.exp: Until the issue of costs arises.

dispute.q: 'Indemnity Costs' resolve doubt in favour of the receiving party.
dispute.exp: A punitive basis of assessment.

dispute.q: 'Standard Basis' costs must be proportionate.
dispute.exp: The default basis for assessment.

dispute.q: 'Additional Amount' is a bonus for beating your own offer.
dispute.exp: Up to £75,000 extra for claimants.

dispute.q: 'Consent Order' is a judgment agreed by the parties.
dispute.exp: Approved and sealed by the court.

dispute.q: 'Stay of Proceedings' pauses the litigation.
dispute.exp: Used in Tomlin orders or for ADR.

dispute.q: 'Notice of Acceptance' is served to accept a Part 36 offer.
dispute.exp: Creates a binding settlement.

dispute.q: 'Sunset Clause' is an automatic expiry date in an offer.
dispute.exp: Invalid in Part 36 offers.

dispute.q: 'Mediation' uses a facilitator to help parties agree.
dispute.exp: A non-binding form of ADR until settlement is signed.

dispute.q: 'Arbitration' uses a private judge to make a binding decision.
dispute.exp: Governed by the Arbitration Act 1996.

dispute.q: 'Joint Settlement Meeting' (JSM) is a negotiation meeting.
dispute.exp: Usually between lawyers and parties to settle.

dispute.q: 'Form N242A' is the Notice of Offer to Settle.
dispute.exp: Optional form for Part 36 offers.

dispute.q: 'Withdrawal' retracts the offer before acceptance.
dispute.exp: Must be in writing.

dispute.q: 'Clarification' can be requested regarding a Part 36 offer.
dispute.exp: Offeree can ask for details within 7 days.

dispute.q: 'Global Offer' settles multiple claims in one sum.
dispute.exp: Must be clear what it covers.

dispute.q: 'Cost Consequences' trigger when an offer is not beaten.
dispute.exp: CPR 36.17 penalties/rewards.

dispute.q: 'Litigation Risk' is the chance of losing at trial.
dispute.exp: A key factor in settlement value.

dispute.q: 'Quantum' is the amount of damages.
dispute.exp: The value of the claim.

dispute.q: 'Protected Party' lacks capacity to litigate.
dispute.exp: Settlements involving them must be approved by the court.

dispute.q: 'Liberty to Apply' allows parties to return to court.
dispute.exp: Standard clause in Tomlin orders to enforce terms.

dispute.q: 'Full and Final Settlement' ends all claims.
dispute.exp: Prevents future litigation on the same facts.

dispute.q: A decision of a District Judge in the County Court is appealed to a Circuit Judge.
dispute.exp: Access to Justice Act 1999 (Destination of Appeals) Order 2016; standard route is to the next level of judge.

dispute.q: A final decision of a Master in the High Court is appealed to the Court of Appeal.
dispute.exp: Appeals from a Master lie to a High Court Judge, not the Court of Appeal.

dispute.q: An Appellant's Notice must be filed within 21 days of the decision being appealed.
dispute.exp: CPR 52.12; unless the lower court directs a different period.

dispute.q: Permission to appeal is required for all appeals from the County Court.
dispute.exp: CPR 52.3; permission is generally required for all appeals (except committal/liberty cases).
