contract.exp: Affirmation is irrevocable unless a fresh breach occurs.

contract.q: Anticipatory breach allows immediate termination before performance is due.
contract.exp: The innocent party need not wait for the due date to sue (Hochster v De La Tour).

contract.q: Frustration renders a contract void ab initio.
contract.exp: It discharges the contract as to the future; it is not void from the start.

contract.q: An increase in expense is a valid ground for frustration.
contract.exp: Mere hardship or bad bargain is not frustration (Davis Contractors v Fareham UDC).

contract.q: Self-induced frustration allows the party to rely on the frustrating event.
contract.exp: A party cannot rely on frustration if their own act caused it (The Super Servant Two).

contract.q: A force majeure clause generally excludes the doctrine of frustration.
contract.exp: If the parties have allocated the risk, the doctrine of frustration does not apply.

contract.q: Under s.1(2) LR(FC)A 1943, the payee acts as an insurer for expenses.
contract.exp: The court has discretion to allow retention of expenses, but not exceeding the sum paid/payable.

contract.q: Under s.1(2) LR(FC)A 1943, expenses can be recovered even if no money was paid/payable.
contract.exp: Expenses can only be retained out of money paid or payable before the event.

contract.q: Section 1(3) LR(FC)A 1943 values the benefit of the services performed.
contract.exp: It values the 'end product' benefit received by the other party (BP v Hunt).

contract.q: If the 'benefit' is destroyed by the frustrating event, the s.1(3) award may be nil.
contract.exp: The court assesses the benefit after the event; if destroyed, value may be zero (BP v Hunt).

contract.q: Custom-made goods (like boots) are always a 'valuable benefit' under s.1(3).
contract.exp: If they are useless to the recipient post-frustration, there may be no benefit.

contract.q: The court must award the full value of the benefit under s.1(3).
contract.exp: The court awards a 'just sum', which cannot exceed the value of the benefit.

contract.q: Breach of warranty entitles the innocent party to terminate.
contract.exp: It entitles them only to damages; the contract must continue.

contract.q: A 'divisible contract' allows payment for parts completed.
contract.exp: If obligations are separate (e.g., per month), payment is due for each completed part.

contract.q: Frustration applies if the event was foreseeable.
contract.exp: If the event was foreseeable, the parties should have provided for it.

contract.q: A contract for personal services is frustrated by the death of the performer.
contract.exp: Death or incapacity in personal service contracts frustrates the agreement (Condor v The Barron Knights).

contract.q: The closure of the Suez Canal frustrated shipping contracts in Tsakiroglou.
contract.exp: A longer route was possible, so performance was not 'radically different' (Tsakiroglou v Noblee Thorl).

contract.q: Discharge by performance requires exact and precise performance.
contract.exp: The general rule is that performance must match contract terms exactly (Re Moore & Landauer).

contract.q: Tender of performance is equivalent to actual performance.
contract.exp: If performance is rejected, the tenderer is discharged from liability (Startup v Macdonald).

contract.q: Time is always of the essence in commercial contracts.
contract.exp: It is not automatic unless stipulated, implied, or notice is given.

contract.q: A contract can be discharged by agreement.
contract.exp: Parties can agree to release each other (bilateral discharge) or use a deed.

contract.q: Accord and satisfaction requires consideration.
contract.exp: To release a party from obligations, new consideration (satisfaction) is needed.

contract.q: Frustration occurs when performance becomes impossible.
contract.exp: Impossibility is a classic ground for frustration (Taylor v Caldwell).

contract.q: Illegality can frustrate a contract.
contract.exp: Supervening illegality (e.g., wartime trading ban) frustrates the contract (Fibrosa).

contract.q: Frustration discharges past obligations.
contract.exp: At common law, rights accrued before the event remain (Chandler v Webster) - modified by statute.

contract.q: The Law Reform (Frustrated Contracts) Act 1943 applies to insurance contracts.
contract.exp: Section 2(5) excludes insurance contracts from the Act.

contract.q: Repudiation is a serious breach of contract.
contract.exp: It involves a breach of condition or refusal to perform.

contract.q: Damages are the only remedy for frustration.
contract.exp: Frustration results in automatic discharge; LR(FC)A 1943 provides restitutionary remedies.

contract.q: Section 1(2) LR(FC)A deals with money paid before discharge.
contract.exp: It allows recovery of money paid prior to the frustrating event.

contract.q: Section 1(3) LR(FC)A deals with non-monetary benefits.
contract.exp: It allows the court to award a 'just sum' for valuable benefits conferred.

contract.q: A waiver involves giving up legal rights.
contract.exp: A party may waive their right to strict performance.

contract.q: The de minimis rule ignores microscopic deviations.
contract.exp: The law does not concern itself with trifles (Arcos v Ronaasen).

contract.q: Quantum meruit means 'as much as he has earned'.
contract.exp: A remedy for the value of work done where no price is fixed.

contract.q: An innocent party must mitigate loss after accepting a repudiation.
contract.exp: The duty to mitigate arises once the contract is terminated.

contract.q: Frustration is automatic.
contract.exp: It operates by law, regardless of the parties' wishes (Hirji Mulji).

contract.q: The destruction of the subject matter frustrates the contract.
contract.exp: As seen in Taylor v Caldwell (burning down of the music hall).

contract.q: Commercial purpose must be completely destroyed for frustration.
contract.exp: The non-occurrence of an event must destroy the foundation of the contract (Krell v Henry).

contract.q: Herne Bay Steamboat v Hutton was a case of frustration.
contract.exp: The contract was not frustrated as part of the purpose (seeing the fleet) remained.

contract.q: Severable contracts can be discharged in part.
contract.exp: Obligations are independent; breach of one does not necessarily discharge the whole.

contract.q: Affirmation requires knowledge of the breach and the right to terminate.
contract.exp: The innocent party must know the facts giving rise to the right to elect.

contract.q: A contract is discharged by expiry at the end of a fixed term.
contract.exp: The contract ends automatically according to its own terms.

contract.q: Breach of an innominate term always leads to discharge.
contract.exp: Only if the breach deprives the party of substantially the whole benefit (Hong Kong Fir).

contract.q: The 'expectation interest' aims to put the claimant in the position as if the contract was performed.
contract.exp: This is the primary measure of damages in contract law (Robinson v Harman).

contract.q: Reliance damages aim to put the claimant in the position they were in before the contract was made.
contract.exp: It recovers wasted expenditure incurred in reliance on the contract (Anglia TV v Reed).

contract.q: A claimant can recover both expectation loss (gross profit) and reliance loss (expenses) for the same breach.
contract.exp: This would lead to double recovery; they must choose one or the other (Anglia TV v Reed).

contract.q: In Ruxley Electronics v Forsyth, the court awarded the full 'cost of cure' to rebuild the pool.
contract.exp: Cost of cure was refused as wholly disproportionate; 'loss of amenity' was awarded instead.

contract.q: Loss of amenity is available where the value of the property is unaffected but enjoyment is reduced.
contract.exp: It compensates for the loss of subjective consumer surplus (Ruxley Electronics).

contract.q: Damages for mental distress are generally recoverable in commercial contracts.
contract.exp: General rule is no recovery for distress/anguish (Addis v Gramophone Co).

contract.q: Mental distress damages are recoverable if the contract's object is pleasure or relaxation.
contract.exp: This is the exception for 'holiday' type cases (Jarvis v Swan Tours).

contract.q: Loss of a chance is recoverable even if the chance was less than 50%.
contract.exp: The court assesses the value of the lost chance, e.g., 25% of the prize (Chaplin v Hicks).

contract.q: To recover 'loss of chance', the chance must depend on the actions of a third party.
contract.exp: If it depends on the defendant, it is a standard causation issue, not loss of chance.

contract.q: Factual causation is usually decided by the 'but for' test.
contract.exp: The loss would not have occurred 'but for' the breach (Galoo v Bright Grahame Murray).

contract.q: An intervening act (novus actus interveniens) breaks the chain of causation.
contract.exp: A new event can remove the defendant's liability for subsequent loss (Lambert v Lewis).

contract.q: Under Hadley v Baxendale Limb 1, losses must arise naturally from the breach.
contract.exp: They must be in the usual course of things.

contract.q: Under Hadley Limb 2, the specific loss must be in the actual knowledge of the defendant.
contract.exp: It requires actual knowledge OR that it should have been in their reasonable contemplation.

contract.q: In Victoria Laundry, the claimant recovered the loss of the lucrative government contract.
contract.exp: It was too remote as the defendant did not know of this special contract (Limb 2 failed).

contract.q: The 'Achilleas' test looks at whether the defendant assumed responsibility for the loss.
contract.exp: This is an alternative approach where the standard Hadley test leads to unquantifiable liability.

contract.q: The duty to mitigate requires the claimant to do everything possible to reduce loss.
contract.exp: They need only take 'reasonable steps' to mitigate (British Westinghouse).

contract.q: If mitigation increases the loss, the defendant is liable for the increased amount.
contract.exp: Reasonable attempts to mitigate that fail are recoverable expenses.

contract.q: Benefits gained from mitigation must be accounted for (reducing damages).
contract.exp: Avoided loss is deducted from the damages award (British Westinghouse).

contract.q: Contributory negligence is always a defence in contract law.
contract.exp: It applies only if the breach is also a tort (negligence) (Vesta v Butcher).

contract.q: Under the CRA 2015, the short-term right to reject goods lasts for 14 days.
contract.exp: The short-term right to reject is 30 days (s.22 CRA 2015).

contract.q: A consumer can demand a price reduction for a failed service under CRA 2015.
contract.exp: If repeat performance is impossible or not done in reasonable time (s.56 CRA).

contract.q: Under CRA 2015, a trader has multiple attempts to repair goods before the consumer can reject.
contract.exp: The trader generally has one opportunity to repair/replace before the final right to reject arises (s.24).

contract.q: The claimant must prove the defendant failed to mitigate.
contract.exp: The burden of proof is on the defendant to show the claimant failed to mitigate.

contract.q: Nominal damages are awarded when no actual loss is proven.
contract.exp: They acknowledge the legal right but award a token sum (e.g., £1).

contract.q: Loss of reputation is recoverable in an unfair dismissal claim.
contract.exp: Generally not recoverable (Addis), except in limited 'stigma' cases (Malik).

contract.q: Damages are the primary remedy for breach of contract.
contract.exp: They are available of right; specific performance is discretionary.

contract.q: The aim of damages is to punish the contract breaker.
contract.exp: The aim is compensation, not punishment.

contract.q: Remoteness limits the recoverability of damages.
contract.exp: Losses that are too remote are not recoverable.

contract.q: Mitigation acts as a limit on recoverable damages.
contract.exp: A party cannot recover for losses they could have reasonably avoided.

contract.q: The 'market rule' is often used to calculate expectation loss in sale of goods.
contract.exp: Difference between contract price and market price at the time of breach (s.50/51 SGA 1979).

contract.q: Pecuniary loss refers to financial loss.
contract.exp: e.g., loss of profit, cost of repair.

contract.q: Non-pecuniary loss includes pain and suffering.
contract.exp: Losses not directly measurable in money.

contract.q: Restitutionary damages aim to strip the defendant of their gain.
contract.exp: Available in exceptional cases (AG v Blake).

contract.q: Liquidated damages are a pre-estimate of loss agreed in the contract.
contract.exp: Fixed sum payable upon breach.

contract.q: A penalty clause is enforceable in English law.
contract.exp: Penalty clauses are generally unenforceable.

contract.q: Specific performance is a common law remedy.
contract.exp: It is an equitable remedy.

contract.q: Injunctions can be prohibitory or mandatory.
contract.exp: Stopping an act or compelling an act.

contract.q: Causation requires a link between breach and loss.
contract.exp: The breach must cause the loss.

contract.q: The 'But For' test is used for legal causation.
contract.exp: It is used for factual causation.

contract.q: A 'bad bargain' allows a claimant to claim reliance loss to escape the contract.
contract.exp: The cap on reliance loss prevents escaping a bad bargain (C & P Haulage).

contract.q: Cost of cure is a method of calculating expectation loss.
contract.exp: The cost to put the defect right.

contract.q: Difference in value is a method of calculating expectation loss.
contract.exp: Value expected minus value received.

contract.q: The Consumer Rights Act 2015 applies to B2B contracts.
contract.exp: It applies to Trader-Consumer contracts (B2C).

contract.q: Digital content is covered by the Consumer Rights Act 2015.
contract.exp: It is a distinct category of contract under the Act.

contract.q: Repeat performance is a remedy for faulty goods.
contract.exp: It is a remedy for faulty services; goods get repair/replace.

contract.q: The burden of proving the loss lies on the claimant.
contract.exp: He who asserts must prove.

contract.q: Reasonable contemplation is an objective test.
contract.exp: What a reasonable person would realize.

contract.q: Loss of enjoyment is a non-pecuniary loss.
contract.exp: Subjective loss of pleasure.

contract.q: Damages are calculated at the date of breach.
contract.exp: Generally assessed at the time the breach occurred.

contract.q: A claimant can recover for losses that were unforeseeable.
contract.exp: Remoteness rules prevent recovery for unforeseeable losses.

contract.q: The penalty rule applies to primary obligations in a contract.
contract.exp: The rule only applies to secondary obligations triggered by a breach (Cavendish v Makdessi).

contract.q: A clause allowing a price reduction for early payment is subject to the penalty rule.
contract.exp: This is a primary obligation (price adjustment mechanism), not a secondary one triggered by breach.

contract.q: A clause requires the party alleging it is a penalty to prove it.
contract.exp: The burden of proof lies on the party seeking to strike down the clause.

contract.q: A parking fine of £85 can be enforceable even if the land owner suffers no loss.
contract.exp: Deterrence can be a legitimate interest if not extravagant (ParkingEye v Beavis).

contract.q: A clause is a penalty if the detriment is 'extravagant and unconscionable'.
contract.exp: This is the true test for a penalty under Cavendish v Makdessi.

contract.q: Specific performance is available for contracts of personal service.
contract.exp: Courts will not compel individuals to work (De Francesco v Barnum).

contract.q: Specific performance is generally granted for the sale of unique land.
contract.exp: Land is considered unique, so damages are inadequate (Adderley v Dixon).

contract.q: Specific performance is available even if damages are an adequate remedy.
contract.exp: It is only available if damages are not an appropriate/adequate remedy.

contract.q: A prohibitory injunction is used to enforce a positive contractual term.
contract.exp: Prohibitory injunctions enforce negative terms (restraining a party from doing something).

contract.q: An injunction to stop a former employee using a stolen database is likely to be granted.
contract.exp: Damages would be difficult to quantify and reputation damage is irreparable.

contract.q: A guarantee must be in writing and signed to be enforceable.
contract.exp: Requirement under s.4 Statute of Frauds 1677.

contract.q: An indemnity must be in writing to be enforceable.
contract.exp: Indemnities are not covered by the Statute of Frauds 1677.

contract.q: If the main contract is varied, a guarantor is usually discharged.
contract.exp: A guarantee is a secondary obligation dependent on the specific underlying contract.

contract.q: If the main contract is varied, an indemnity holder is discharged.
contract.exp: An indemnity is a primary independent obligation and usually remains in force.

contract.q: If the principal debtor's obligation ceases, the guarantor remains liable.
contract.exp: The guarantee is co-extensive; if the debt vanishes, so does the guarantee.

contract.q: The 'clean hands' doctrine applies to claims for liquidated damages.
contract.exp: Liquidated damages are a common law remedy; 'clean hands' applies to equity.

contract.q: Delay in seeking an injunction can defeat the claim.
contract.exp: Delay defeats equity (Laches).

contract.q: A clause stripping an employee of shares upon breach is always a penalty.
contract.exp: Not if it protects a legitimate commercial interest and is proportionate (Makdessi).

contract.q: Liquidated damages clauses avoid the need to prove the actual amount of loss.
contract.exp: The claimant claims the fixed sum agreed, not unliquidated damages.

contract.q: A court order requiring a party to pull down a wall is a prohibitory injunction.
contract.exp: This is a mandatory injunction (requiring a positive act).

contract.q: An indemnity can arise in a two-party context.
contract.exp: One party can indemnify the other against specific losses/liabilities.

contract.q: Breach of a specific performance order is a contempt of court.
contract.exp: Failure to obey a court order carries criminal/quasi-criminal sanctions.

contract.q: Mutuality of remedy is a factor in granting specific performance.
contract.exp: Courts rarely grant SP to one party if they could not grant it to the other.

contract.q: A guarantee covers the debt only if the principal debtor defaults.
contract.exp: It is a promise to pay *if* the principal does not.

contract.q: In Makdessi, the price adjustment clauses were found to be penalties.
contract.exp: They were primary obligations adjusting the price, so the rule did not apply.

contract.q: A liquidated damages clause fixes the sum payable on breach.
contract.exp: It provides certainty by stipulating the damages in advance.

contract.q: A penalty clause is unenforceable.
contract.exp: If a clause is a penalty, the court will not uphold it.

contract.q: Specific performance is an equitable remedy.
contract.exp: It derives from the Courts of Equity, not the Common Law.

contract.q: Damages are a discretionary remedy.
contract.exp: Damages are available as of right for breach of contract.

contract.q: A guarantee is a primary obligation.
contract.exp: It is a secondary obligation supported by the primary debt.

contract.q: An indemnity is a primary obligation.
contract.exp: The indemnifier promises to pay regardless of the principal's default.

contract.q: Cavendish Square Holding BV v Makdessi is the leading case on penalties.
contract.exp: It restated the law, replacing the strict Dunlop test.

contract.q: The 'legitimate interest' test comes from Dunlop v New Garage.
contract.exp: Dunlop focused on 'genuine pre-estimate of loss'; Makdessi introduced legitimate interest.

contract.q: A negative term is a term requiring a party not to do something.
contract.exp: e.g., 'Do not work for a competitor'.

contract.q: A positive term requires a party to perform an act.
contract.exp: e.g., 'Paint the house'.

contract.q: Equitable remedies are available 'as of right'.
contract.exp: They are discretionary.

contract.q: Contempt of court can result from disobeying an injunction.
contract.exp: It is the sanction for breaching a court order.

contract.q: A guarantee must be supported by consideration (or deed).
contract.exp: Like all contracts, it requires consideration unless in a deed.

contract.q: The Statute of Frauds 1677 requires guarantees to be evidenced in writing.
contract.exp: Section 4 imposes this formality.

contract.q: Loss of reputation can be a legitimate interest.
contract.exp: Protecting brand value can justify a liquidated damages clause.

contract.q: Unconscionable means unreasonably excessive.
contract.exp: In the context of penalties, it means out of all proportion.

contract.q: Specific performance puts the parties in the position as if the contract was performed.
contract.exp: It compels the actual performance promised.

contract.q: An interim injunction is granted before the full trial.
contract.exp: It preserves the status quo pending the final hearing.

contract.q: American Cyanamid sets the guidelines for interim injunctions.
contract.exp: It established the 'balance of convenience' test.

contract.q: A 'secondary obligation' arises upon breach of contract.
contract.exp: e.g., the obligation to pay damages.

contract.q: Specific performance is rarely granted for sale of goods.
contract.exp: Because damages allow the buyer to purchase substitutes (unless goods are unique).

contract.q: Laches is a doctrine regarding delay.
contract.exp: It prevents equitable relief if there is unreasonable delay.

contract.q: A 'guarantor' is also known as a 'surety'.
contract.exp: The terms are generally interchangeable in this context.

contract.q: ParkingEye v Beavis involved a penalty charge of £85.
contract.exp: The court held it was not a penalty despite exceeding the direct loss.

contract.q: Restitutionary damages are the norm for breach of contract.
contract.exp: Compensatory damages are the norm; restitution is exceptional.

tort.q: Caparo test establishes Duty of Care.
Thin Skull Rule: Take victim as you find them.
Pure economic loss is generally recoverable.
Breach judged by reasonable person standard.
Vicarious liability applies to independent contractors.
OLA 1957 covers lawful visitors.
Truth is a complete defence to defamation.
Rylands v Fletcher imposes strict liability.
Contributory Negligence is a partial defence.
Res Ipsa Loquitur reverses burden of proof.
Private Nuisance protects enjoyment of land.
Secondary victims must witness event with own senses.
Volenti non fit injuria is a defence of consent.
Learner drivers are judged by lower standard.
Product liability (CPA 1987) is strict.
Bolam test applies to professionals.
But For test establishes factual causation.
Novus Actus Interveniens breaks chain of causation.
Wagon Mound test determines remoteness.
Employers have non-delegable duty for equipment.
OLA 1984 covers trespassers.
Warning sign always discharges duty.
tort.exp: Must enable visitor to be safe.

tort.q: Public Nuisance is both Crime & Tort.
Libel is permanent form defamation.
Slander is transient form defamation.
Honest Opinion is a defamation defence.
False Imprisonment requires total restraint.
Battery requires hostile intent.
Assault is apprehension of immediate force.
Conversion involves inconsistent dealing with goods.
Deceit involves making a false statement.
Hedley Byrne: Liability for Negligent Misstatement.
Floodgates argument limits psychiatric injury claims.
Primary victim is physically endangered.
Rescuers are treated favorably in tort.
Ex turpi causa (Illegality) is a valid defence.
Emergency situations lower standard of care.
Children judged by standard of reasonable child.
Pure psychiatric harm is not recoverable.
Loss of chance is recoverable in medical negligence.
Vicarious liability requires 'close connection'.
Nuisance claimant must have interest in land.
Prescription (20 years) is nuisance defence.
Statutory Authority is a nuisance defence.
General Damages cover Pain/Suffering.
Special Damages cover Financial Loss.
Provisional Damages allow for future deterioration.
Fatal Accidents Act allows dependents to claim.
Limitation for Defamation: 1 year.
Latent Damage Longstop: 15 years.
Egg Shell Skull Rule: Take victim as found.

landLaw.q: Legal lease >3 years must be by deed.
Curtain principle keeps trusts off register.
Easement is a right to possess land.
Positive covenants run with the land.
landLaw.exp: Burden does not run at law.

landLaw.q: Mortgage power of sale is statutory.
Exchange of contracts creates equitable interest.
Lease <7 years is an Overriding Interest.
Freehold: Fee Simple Absolute in Possession.
Only two legal estates exist in land.
Puisne mortgage is a legal mortgage.
Class F Land Charge protects spouse rights.
Doctrine of Notice applies to Registered Land.
Four Unities: Possession, Interest, Title, Time.
Trustees have powers of absolute owner.
Benefit of covenant runs at law.
Burden of covenant runs at law.
Tulk v Moxhay applies to negative covenants.
Equity of redemption is right to pay off.
First registration is compulsory on sale.

propertyPractice.q: Licenses are assignable.
propertyPractice.exp: Personal right, not property.

propertyPractice.q: SDLT is a tax on the seller.
propertyPractice.exp: Buyer pays.

propertyPractice.q: Lease > 7 years must be registered.
propertyPractice.exp: Trigger for first registration.

propertyPractice.q: Priority Search (OS1) gives 30 days priority.
propertyPractice.exp: Working days.

propertyPractice.q: Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) payment deadline is 14 days.
propertyPractice.exp: From completion.

propertyPractice.q: Notice to Quit (Periodic): 4 weeks minimum.
propertyPractice.exp: Protection from Eviction Act 1977.

propertyPractice.q: Business Lease (1954 Act) Notice: 6-12 months.
Root of Title must be 15 years old.
propertyPractice.exp: Unregistered land.

propertyPractice.q: Register Company Charge: 21 days.
propertyPractice.exp: At Companies House.

propertyPractice.q: Completion date is time of essence.
propertyPractice.exp: Only if notice served or stated.

propertyPractice.q: Notice to Complete makes time of essence (10 days).
propertyPractice.exp: Standard conditions usually 10 days.

propertyPractice.q: Exchange of contracts s.2 LP(MP)A.
propertyPractice.exp: Writing, Terms, Signed.

propertyPractice.q: TR1 form used for transfer.
propertyPractice.exp: Transfer deed.

propertyPractice.q: Assent must be in writing.
propertyPractice.exp: PRs to beneficiary.

propertyPractice.q: Land Contract limitation: 6 years.
propertyPractice.exp: Simple contract.

propertyPractice.q: Deed limitation: 12 years.
propertyPractice.exp: Specialty debt.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor can act in an 'own interest conflict' if the client consents.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.1 prohibits acting in an own interest conflict with no exceptions.

propertyPractice.q: Firms must have systems to identify conflicts of interest.
propertyPractice.exp: CCF 2.1 requires effective systems to identify conflicts.

propertyPractice.q: You can act for buyer and seller if they have a 'substantially common interest'.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.2(a) exception applies if conditions (informed consent, safeguards) are met.

propertyPractice.q: A firm can act for two bidders competing for the same asset in a tender.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.2(b) 'Competing for the same objective' exception applies.

propertyPractice.q: You must verify the identity of a client before the business relationship starts.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 30(2) MLR 2017; verification generally occurs before establishment.

propertyPractice.q: Standard CDD requires identifying the client's beneficial owner.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 28(2) MLR 2017; beneficial owners must be identified.

propertyPractice.q: Managers of an authorised body are severally liable for compliance.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 1.2 SRA Accounts Rules; they are 'jointly and severally' responsible.

propertyPractice.q: Client money must be kept separate from the firm's own money.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 4.1 SRA Accounts Rules.

propertyPractice.q: Acting for a buyer and lender in a residential purchase is usually a conflict.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard mortgage terms usually align interests (Substantially Common Interest).

propertyPractice.q: Enhanced CDD is optional for clients from high-risk third countries.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 33(1)(b) MLR 2017 makes Enhanced CDD mandatory.

propertyPractice.q: Simplified CDD allows adjusting the timing of verification.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 37(2) MLR 2017 allows adjustment of extent/timing.

propertyPractice.q: Receipt of client money is recorded as a Debit in the Client Ledger.
propertyPractice.exp: It is recorded as a Credit in the Client Ledger (and Debit in Cash Sheet).

propertyPractice.q: Payment of client money is recorded as a Credit in the Cash Sheet.
propertyPractice.exp: Double entry: Debit Client Ledger, Credit Cash Sheet.

propertyPractice.q: A beneficial owner owns more than 20% of a company's shares.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 5(1) MLR 2017 sets the threshold at more than 25%.

propertyPractice.q: Occasional transactions under 1,000 Euros are exempt from CDD.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 27(1)(b) MLR 2017 triggers CDD only above 1,000 Euros.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor can rely on a third party's CDD without liability.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 29; the solicitor remains liable for any failure.

propertyPractice.q: Negotiating a commercial lease for landlord and tenant implies a Substantially Common Interest.
propertyPractice.exp: Negotiation usually involves conflict on key terms; SCI requires strong consensus.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor acting for a seller must disclose a higher valuation to a buyer client.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.4 duty of disclosure applies unless prohibited by law/confidentiality.

propertyPractice.q: Confidentiality to Client A overrides the duty of disclosure to Client B.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.3/6.4; you cannot disclose confidential info without consent.

propertyPractice.q: Client account bank statements must be obtained every 7 weeks.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 8.2 SRA Accounts Rules requires statements at least every 5 weeks.

propertyPractice.q: Reconciliations of client accounts must be signed off by the COFA or manager.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 8.3 SRA Accounts Rules.

propertyPractice.q: Issuing a bill of costs creates a Credit entry in the Business Ledger.
propertyPractice.exp: It creates a Debit in the client's Business Ledger (client owes money).

propertyPractice.q: A 'significant risk' of conflict is sufficient to prohibit acting.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.1 and 6.2 apply to actual conflicts and 'significant risk' of them.

propertyPractice.q: Acting for a company and its director always creates a conflict.
propertyPractice.exp: Not always, but requires checking for separate duties/interests.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor can pay a disbursement before issuing a bill to the client.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 4.3 applies to transferring money for the *solicitor's* costs, not disbursements.

propertyPractice.q: 'MLRO' stands for Money Laundering Reporting Officer.
propertyPractice.exp: The nominated officer responsible for disclosures under PoCA.

propertyPractice.q: 'CDD' stands for Client Due Diligence.
propertyPractice.exp: It stands for 'Customer' Due Diligence (Regulation 27 MLR).

propertyPractice.q: 'PEP' stands for Politically Exposed Person.
propertyPractice.exp: Individuals entrusted with prominent public functions.

propertyPractice.q: 'CCS' refers to the Code of Conduct for Solicitors.
propertyPractice.exp: Code of Conduct for Solicitors, RELs and RFLs.

propertyPractice.q: 'CCF' refers to the Code of Conduct for Firms.
propertyPractice.exp: SRA Code of Conduct for Firms.

propertyPractice.q: 'SCI' stands for Substantially Common Interest.
propertyPractice.exp: An exception to conflict of interest under CCS 6.2(a).

propertyPractice.q: 'CSO' stands for Competing for the Same Objective.
propertyPractice.exp: An exception to conflict of interest under CCS 6.2(b).

propertyPractice.q: 'Own Interest Conflict' involves the solicitor's personal interests.
propertyPractice.exp: Conflict between solicitor's interest and client's interest.

propertyPractice.q: 'Client Money' includes money held as a trustee.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 2.1(c) SRA Accounts Rules.

propertyPractice.q: 'Authorised Body' includes recognised sole practices.
propertyPractice.exp: Defined in the SRA Glossary.

propertyPractice.q: 'COLP' stands for Compliance Officer for Legal Practice.
propertyPractice.exp: Responsible for firm's compliance with regulatory obligations.

propertyPractice.q: 'COFA' stands for Compliance Officer for Finance and Administration.
propertyPractice.exp: Responsible for firm's compliance with Accounts Rules.

propertyPractice.q: 'Double Entry' requires one Credit and one Debit.
propertyPractice.exp: Fundamental principle of bookkeeping.

propertyPractice.q: 'Client Ledger' records individual client transactions.
propertyPractice.exp: Separated into client side and business side.

propertyPractice.q: 'Cash Sheet' records the running total of the bank account.
propertyPractice.exp: Rule 8.1(c) SRA Accounts Rules.

propertyPractice.q: 'Manager' includes a partner in a partnership.
propertyPractice.exp: SRA Glossary definition of Manager.

propertyPractice.q: 'Business Relationship' implies an element of duration.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 4 MLR 2017.

propertyPractice.q: 'Occasional Transaction' is outside a business relationship.
propertyPractice.exp: Regulation 3 MLR 2017.

propertyPractice.q: 'Placement' is the first stage of money laundering.
propertyPractice.exp: Introducing illegal proceeds into the financial system.

propertyPractice.q: 'Layering' conceals the source of money.
propertyPractice.exp: Moving funds to distance them from the crime.

propertyPractice.q: A buyer can withdraw from a purchase without penalty before exchange of contracts.
propertyPractice.exp: Until exchange, neither party is contractually bound and can withdraw without penalty.

propertyPractice.q: A seller must disclose physical defects like dry rot to the buyer.
propertyPractice.exp: Under caveat emptor, the seller has no duty to disclose physical defects (Hardy v Griffiths).

propertyPractice.q: Legal title passes to the buyer on the day of completion.
propertyPractice.exp: Legal title passes only upon registration at the Land Registry post-completion.

propertyPractice.q: The maximum number of legal owners for a property is four.
propertyPractice.exp: There is a maximum number of four legal owners (s.34(2) Trustee Act 1925).

propertyPractice.q: A minor (under 18) can be a legal owner of land.
propertyPractice.exp: Legal owners must be over 18.

propertyPractice.q: Co-owners wishing to leave their share by will must hold as Joint Tenants.
propertyPractice.exp: Joint tenancy includes the right of survivorship; Tenants in Common is required to leave shares by will.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor can act for both buyer and lender in a standard residential transaction.
propertyPractice.exp: Permitted as there is usually a 'substantially common interest' and standard mortgage terms.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor can act for both buyer and seller if they agree on the price.
propertyPractice.exp: Price agreement does not constitute 'strong consensus' on all terms; conflict usually exists.

propertyPractice.q: If confidentiality conflicts with the duty of disclosure, disclosure takes precedence.
propertyPractice.exp: Confidentiality (CCS 6.3) overrides disclosure (CCS 6.4) unless consent is given.

propertyPractice.q: A seller must commission an Energy Performance Certificate (EPC) before marketing.
propertyPractice.exp: The seller must commission an EPC before marketing and provide it free of charge.

propertyPractice.q: Capital Gains Tax is payable on the sale of a main residence.
propertyPractice.exp: Private Residence Relief (PRR) usually exempts the main home from CGT.

propertyPractice.q: Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) is paid by the seller.
propertyPractice.exp: SDLT is paid by the buyer post-completion.

propertyPractice.q: An interest-only mortgage ensures the capital is repaid at the end of the term.
propertyPractice.exp: Only interest is paid; capital remains outstanding and requires a separate repayment vehicle.

propertyPractice.q: A Basic Valuation survey is sufficient to protect a buyer's interests.
propertyPractice.exp: It is for the lender's benefit; buyers are advised to obtain a Homebuyer or Structural survey.

propertyPractice.q: Solicitors can act for two bidders competing in a tender process.
propertyPractice.exp: The 'Competing for the same objective' exception (CCS 6.2(b)) applies to auctions/tenders.

propertyPractice.q: If a client discloses mortgage fraud, the solicitor must inform the lender immediately.
propertyPractice.exp: The solicitor must ask for consent; if refused, they must cease acting to avoid breaching confidentiality.

propertyPractice.q: The 'Own Interest Conflict' rule (CCS 6.1) has exceptions for sophisticated clients.
propertyPractice.exp: There are NO exceptions to the ban on acting with an own interest conflict.

propertyPractice.q: Leading questions are best used to obtain a client's initial account.
propertyPractice.exp: Leading questions restrict detail; open questions are better for obtaining an account.

propertyPractice.q: An attendance note should be written in the first person.
propertyPractice.exp: It is common to write attendance notes in the third person (e.g., 'BS advised Mr X').

propertyPractice.q: The deposit paid on exchange is usually 10% of the purchase price.
propertyPractice.exp: The standard deposit paid by the buyer on exchange is 10%.

propertyPractice.q: VAT is payable on the purchase price of all residential properties.
propertyPractice.exp: Existing residential properties are usually VAT exempt.

propertyPractice.q: Beneficial ownership can be held by a minor.
propertyPractice.exp: Unlike legal ownership, there is no age restriction for beneficial owners.

propertyPractice.q: A Full Structural Survey is recommended for listed buildings.
propertyPractice.exp: It is suitable for listed properties or those with extensive renovations.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor must verify a client's identity.
propertyPractice.exp: Identity checks are essential to verify the client is who they claim to be.

propertyPractice.q: Parking an issue in an interview means ignoring it completely.
propertyPractice.exp: It means putting it aside to deal with later, and the client should be informed.

propertyPractice.q: 'Caveat Emptor' translates to 'Seller Beware'.
propertyPractice.exp: It translates to 'Buyer Beware'.

propertyPractice.q: Pre-exchange is the stage where most conveyancing work occurs.
propertyPractice.exp: Investigation of title and searches occur pre-exchange.

propertyPractice.q: Exchange of contracts is when the parties become legally bound.
propertyPractice.exp: Neither party can pull out without consequences after exchange.

propertyPractice.q: Completion is when the buyer receives the keys.
propertyPractice.exp: The buyer gets keys and physical possession on completion.

propertyPractice.q: SDLT stands for Stamp Duty Land Tax.
propertyPractice.exp: The tax paid on land transactions in England.

propertyPractice.q: LTT stands for Land Transaction Tax.
propertyPractice.exp: The tax paid on land transactions in Wales.

propertyPractice.q: Joint Tenants are viewed as a single entity.
propertyPractice.exp: They collectively own the whole beneficial estate.

propertyPractice.q: Right of Survivorship applies to Tenants in Common.
propertyPractice.exp: It applies to Joint Tenants; Tenants in Common pass shares by will.

propertyPractice.q: Capital Repayment Mortgage pays off the loan principal monthly.
propertyPractice.exp: Borrower repays capital and interest monthly.

propertyPractice.q: Equity Finance involves raising capital by selling shares.
propertyPractice.exp: Public companies may use equity finance for commercial purchases.

propertyPractice.q: CCS 6.1 deals with Conflict of Interest between clients.
propertyPractice.exp: CCS 6.1 deals with Own Interest Conflict; CCS 6.2 deals with Client Conflict.

propertyPractice.q: SCI stands for Substantially Common Interest.
propertyPractice.exp: An exception to the conflict rule under CCS 6.2.

propertyPractice.q: CCS 6.3 imposes a duty of confidentiality.
propertyPractice.exp: You must keep affairs of current and former clients confidential.

propertyPractice.q: CCS 6.4 imposes a duty of disclosure.
propertyPractice.exp: You must make the client aware of all material information.

propertyPractice.q: A leading question can be answered with a 'yes' or 'no'.
propertyPractice.exp: Leading questions suggest the answer and allow simple confirmation.

propertyPractice.q: Open questions typically begin with 'who', 'what', 'where', or 'how'.
propertyPractice.exp: They provoke narrative answers and do not limit scope.

propertyPractice.q: Attendance notes should record the date and time engaged.
propertyPractice.exp: Date, fee earner, client, and time engaged are key elements.

propertyPractice.q: VAT is a tax on goods and services.
propertyPractice.exp: Value Added Tax applies to certain property transactions.

propertyPractice.q: Capital Gains Tax (CGT) is a tax on profit from selling assets.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax on the gain in value of assets like land.

propertyPractice.q: A Homebuyer Report is less detailed than a Basic Valuation.
propertyPractice.exp: A Homebuyer Report is *more* detailed than a Basic Valuation.

propertyPractice.q: A sole surviving tenant in common can give a valid receipt for capital money.
propertyPractice.exp: A second trustee must be appointed to overreach beneficial interests (s.27 LPA 1925).

propertyPractice.q: A conveyance dated 1985 must be sealed to be a valid deed.
propertyPractice.exp: Pre-1990 deeds required sealing; LP(MP)A 1989 abolished this for individuals.

propertyPractice.q: A root of title conveyance dated 1 December 1990 triggers compulsory first registration.
propertyPractice.exp: 1 Dec 1990 was the trigger date for all sales to be registered.

propertyPractice.q: If a restrictive covenant is not registered as a D(ii) Land Charge, it binds a buyer for value.
propertyPractice.exp: Unregistered land charges are void against a purchaser for money or money's worth (s.4 LCA 1972).

propertyPractice.q: Positive covenants in the Charges Register are automatically binding on a buyer.
propertyPractice.exp: Positive covenants do not run with the land; they bind via a chain of indemnity.

propertyPractice.q: A buyer should accept a root of title that refers to an earlier plan not included.
propertyPractice.exp: The description must be adequate; missing plans cast doubt on the extent of the land.

propertyPractice.q: Possessory title can be upgraded to Absolute title immediately upon registration.
propertyPractice.exp: Usually requires a period of time without adverse claims (e.g., 12 years) to upgrade.

propertyPractice.q: A surviving joint tenant needs to appoint a second trustee to sell the property.
propertyPractice.exp: Survivorship applies; the survivor becomes the sole legal and beneficial owner.

propertyPractice.q: An assent by personal representatives can be a good root of title.
propertyPractice.exp: It is not a disposition for value, so it does not prove 15 years of ownership investigation.

propertyPractice.q: A puisne mortgage (second mortgage) in unregistered land is protected by keeping the title deeds.
propertyPractice.exp: Only the first mortgagee holds deeds; puisne mortgages must be registered as C(i) Land Charges.

propertyPractice.q: Insurance is the first option for a restrictive covenant breach where the PWB is known.
propertyPractice.exp: Insurance usually requires no contact with the Person With Benefit (PWB).

propertyPractice.q: A conveyance transferring 'beneficial title only' is a good root of title.
propertyPractice.exp: A good root must deal with both legal and beneficial title.

propertyPractice.q: A Form K15 search should be made against the seller's full name for their period of ownership.
propertyPractice.exp: Land Charges searches are name-based and period-specific.

propertyPractice.q: Specific performance is available to enforce a positive covenant against a successor in title.
propertyPractice.exp: Burden of positive covenants does not run with the land (Rhone v Stephens).

propertyPractice.q: A 'Particulars Delivered' stamp is required for a conveyance dated 1920.
propertyPractice.exp: PD stamps are required for conveyances after 1931.

propertyPractice.q: Buying a property with 'Good Leasehold Title' requires no further investigation.
propertyPractice.exp: The landlord's title to grant the lease has not been proven; risk of eviction exists.

propertyPractice.q: A restriction in the proprietorship register always indicates a tenancy in common.
propertyPractice.exp: Restrictions can also relate to mortgages or other consents.

propertyPractice.q: If a deed is not validly stamped, it cannot be used in evidence.
propertyPractice.exp: Stamp Act 1891; unstamped documents are inadmissible in civil courts.

propertyPractice.q: An Index Map Search (SIM) reveals the owner of unregistered land.
propertyPractice.exp: SIM only reveals if land is registered or unregistered; it does not name unregistered owners.

propertyPractice.q: A buyer is bound by an overriding interest even if not mentioned in the contract.
propertyPractice.exp: Overriding interests (Sch 3 LRA 2002) bind without registration.

propertyPractice.q: A gift of land triggers compulsory first registration.
propertyPractice.exp: Since April 1998, gifts trigger registration.

propertyPractice.q: A chain of indemnity is required for a restrictive covenant to bind a successor.
propertyPractice.exp: Restrictive covenants run with the land in equity (Tulk v Moxhay).

propertyPractice.q: A statutory declaration can cure a defect in a root of title description.
propertyPractice.exp: Used to provide evidence of long usage or boundary clarification.

propertyPractice.q: Under the 1989 Act, a witness must be present when the individual signs the deed.
propertyPractice.exp: s.1(3) LP(MP)A 1989 requires attestation by a witness.

propertyPractice.q: A mortgage discharged by a receipted vacate does not need to be in the epitome.
propertyPractice.exp: Post-root mortgages must be included to prove discharge.

propertyPractice.q: The Property Register describes the physical extent of the property.
propertyPractice.exp: It refers to the title plan and describes the land.

propertyPractice.q: The Proprietorship Register names the current legal owners.
propertyPractice.exp: It identifies the registered proprietor.

propertyPractice.q: The Charges Register lists rights benefitting the property.
propertyPractice.exp: It lists burdens (mortgages, covenants); benefits are in the Property Register.

propertyPractice.q: Title Absolute is the best class of title.
propertyPractice.exp: Indicates the Land Registry is satisfied with the title ownership.

propertyPractice.q: Qualified Title indicates a specific defect in the title.
propertyPractice.exp: Granted when the Registrar cannot guarantee a specific aspect.

propertyPractice.q: Possessory Title is often granted for adverse possession.
propertyPractice.exp: Based on physical occupation rather than deeds.

propertyPractice.q: Good Leasehold Title guarantees the landlord's right to grant the lease.
propertyPractice.exp: It means the landlord's title was not produced/inspected.

propertyPractice.q: A root of title must be at least 15 years old.
propertyPractice.exp: s.44 Law of Property Act 1925.

propertyPractice.q: An Epitome of Title is a summary of unregistered title documents.
propertyPractice.exp: Used to deduce title in unregistered land.

propertyPractice.q: Class C(i) Land Charge protects a puisne mortgage.
propertyPractice.exp: A legal mortgage not protected by deposit of deeds.

propertyPractice.q: Class D(ii) Land Charge protects a restrictive covenant.
propertyPractice.exp: Post-1925 restrictive covenants in unregistered land.

propertyPractice.q: Class D(iii) Land Charge protects an equitable easement.
propertyPractice.exp: Created post-1925 in unregistered land.

propertyPractice.q: Class F Land Charge protects matrimonial home rights.
propertyPractice.exp: Family Law Act 1996 rights for non-owning spouse.

propertyPractice.q: Overreaching detaches beneficial interests from the land.
propertyPractice.exp: Interests attach to the purchase money instead.

propertyPractice.q: Caveat Emptor means 'Seller Beware'.
propertyPractice.exp: It means 'Buyer Beware'.

propertyPractice.q: A Deed must be signed, witnessed, and delivered.
propertyPractice.exp: s.1 Law of Property (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1989.

propertyPractice.q: SIM stands for Search of the Index Map.
propertyPractice.exp: Checks if land is registered or unregistered.

propertyPractice.q: Ad valorem stamp duty is based on the value of the transaction.
propertyPractice.exp: Historic tax replaced by SDLT.

propertyPractice.q: A restriction prevents a disposition without compliance.
propertyPractice.exp: Appears in the Proprietorship Register (e.g., 'No disposition by a sole proprietor').

propertyPractice.q: A chain of indemnity protects against positive covenants.
propertyPractice.exp: Ensures the seller is covered if sued by the original covenantee.

propertyPractice.q: Joint Tenants hold the property as a single entity.
propertyPractice.exp: The 'four unities' apply.

propertyPractice.q: Tenants in Common have distinct indivisible shares.
propertyPractice.exp: Can leave their share by will.

propertyPractice.q: A Power of Attorney allows someone to sign deeds for another.
propertyPractice.exp: Must be included in the epitome if used for a root deed.

propertyPractice.q: The 'Right of Survivorship' applies to Tenancies in Common.
propertyPractice.exp: It applies only to Joint Tenancies.

propertyPractice.q: Building works affecting only the interior always require planning permission.
propertyPractice.exp: Internal works are generally not 'development' under s.55 TCPA 1990.

propertyPractice.q: An Article 4 Direction restricts rights under the General Permitted Development Order.
propertyPractice.exp: It removes permitted development rights, requiring express planning permission.

propertyPractice.q: In England, the time limit for building regulations enforcement notices is 12 months.
propertyPractice.exp: Under BSA 2022, the limit in England is 10 years (it is 1 year in Wales).

propertyPractice.q: A local authority has unlimited time to prosecute for building regulations breaches in England.
propertyPractice.exp: Changes under the Building Safety Act 2022 removed the 2-year limit.

propertyPractice.q: A change of use from a betting shop to a restaurant requires planning permission.
propertyPractice.exp: Betting shops are 'Sui Generis'; changes to/from usually require permission.

propertyPractice.q: The LLC1 search reveals pending planning applications.
propertyPractice.exp: LLC1 reveals granted charges; CON29 reveals pending applications.

propertyPractice.q: A Highways Search is required if the property does not abut the public highway.
propertyPractice.exp: Needed to verify access rights if boundaries do not touch adoption lines.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor paying a disbursement as 'agent' must use client money.
propertyPractice.exp: Agency method requires using funds held for the client (Rule 2.1 SRA Accounts Rules).

propertyPractice.q: When paying a disbursement as 'principal', VAT is recorded in the Client Ledger.
propertyPractice.exp: VAT is recorded in the VAT Account and Business Cash Sheet (Principal method).

propertyPractice.q: A seller answering 'not so far as seller is aware' implies reasonable investigations were made.
propertyPractice.exp: This is an implied assertion that records were checked (William Sindall v Cambridgeshire).

propertyPractice.q: Listed Building Consent is required for internal alterations to a listed property.
propertyPractice.exp: Listed status covers the whole building, interior and exterior.

propertyPractice.q: Demolishing an unlisted building in a conservation area in England needs planning permission.
propertyPractice.exp: Conservation area consent was abolished in England; planning permission is now required.

propertyPractice.q: A Coal Mining Search (CON29M) is mandatory for all UK properties.
propertyPractice.exp: Only required if the property is in a designated coal mining area.

propertyPractice.q: Common Land enquiries are part of the standard CON29 search.
propertyPractice.exp: Common Land is Enquiry 22 on the optional CON29O form.

propertyPractice.q: A Report on Title should exclude limitations on the solicitor's liability.
propertyPractice.exp: It should explicitly state limitations (e.g., physical condition not inspected).

propertyPractice.q: Under the Protocol, a buyer's solicitor can raise enquiries about the building's state indiscriminately.
propertyPractice.exp: Enquiries must be specific to issues arising from searches/surveys.

propertyPractice.q: Breach of planning condition (England, pre-2024) has a 10-year enforcement period.
propertyPractice.exp: Breach of condition or use (other than dwelling) was 10 years (s.171B TCPA 1990).

propertyPractice.q: A Regularisation Certificate authorises future building works.
propertyPractice.exp: It is retrospective consent for works already completed without approval.

propertyPractice.q: Tree Preservation Orders are revealed by the CON29 search.
propertyPractice.exp: TPOs are local land charges revealed by the LLC1 search.

propertyPractice.q: A Chancel Repair search is unnecessary if the property is unregistered.
propertyPractice.exp: Liability can still exist; a search or insurance is recommended.

propertyPractice.q: Desktop Environmental Searches assess flood risk based on historical data.
propertyPractice.exp: It uses datasets to predict risk without a site inspection.

propertyPractice.q: The 4-year planning enforcement rule applies to all breaches in Wales.
propertyPractice.exp: It applies to building works and change to single dwelling house only.

propertyPractice.q: A seller can rely on an exclusion clause for fraudulent misrepresentation.
propertyPractice.exp: Liability for fraud or recklessness cannot be excluded (SCS 7.1.1 / SCPC 10.1).

propertyPractice.q: SIM search reveals the owner of the property.
propertyPractice.exp: SIM only reveals if land is registered/unregistered and title numbers.

propertyPractice.q: Companies House searches have a priority period of 21 days.
propertyPractice.exp: Company searches have no priority period; they reflect the register at that moment.

propertyPractice.q: LLC1 stands for Local Land Charges Search.
propertyPractice.exp: Search of the Local Land Charges Register.

propertyPractice.q: CON29 refers to Standard Enquiries of the Local Authority.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard form for planning, building regs, and road adoption info.

propertyPractice.q: TA6 is the Property Information Form.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard protocol form for residential sellers.

propertyPractice.q: TA10 is the Leasehold Information Form.
propertyPractice.exp: TA10 is Fittings and Contents; TA7 is Leasehold Information.

propertyPractice.q: CPSE stands for Commercial Property Standard Enquiries.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard enquiries used in commercial transactions.

propertyPractice.q: GPDO stands for General Permitted Development Order.
propertyPractice.exp: Grants automatic planning permission for certain classes of development.

propertyPractice.q: Sui Generis uses belong to a specific Use Class.
propertyPractice.exp: Sui Generis means 'of its own kind' and falls outside use classes.

propertyPractice.q: Use Class E covers Commercial, Business and Service.
propertyPractice.exp: Broad class introduced in 2020 including retail, offices, and cafes.

propertyPractice.q: Use Class C3 covers Hotels.
propertyPractice.exp: C3 covers Dwelling Houses; C1 covers Hotels.

propertyPractice.q: A Conservation Area preserves special architectural interest.
propertyPractice.exp: Designated by local authority to preserve character.

propertyPractice.q: Building Regulations ensure the structural safety of buildings.
propertyPractice.exp: Statutory instruments governing construction standards and safety.

propertyPractice.q: NLIS stands for National Land Information Service.
propertyPractice.exp: The electronic portal for ordering searches.

propertyPractice.q: SIM stands for Search of the Index Map.
propertyPractice.exp: Used to establish if land is registered or unregistered.

propertyPractice.q: CQS stands for Conveyancing Quality Scheme.
propertyPractice.exp: Law Society accreditation that requires use of the Protocol.

propertyPractice.q: Caveat Emptor places the burden of investigation on the seller.
propertyPractice.exp: It places the burden on the BUYER ('Buyer Beware').

propertyPractice.q: Report on Title is addressed to the seller.
propertyPractice.exp: It is addressed to the buyer (client) explaining investigations.

propertyPractice.q: CCS 6.4 requires disclosing material information to the client.
propertyPractice.exp: Duty to make client aware of all material info known to the solicitor.

propertyPractice.q: Enforcement Notice is a remedy for breach of planning control.
propertyPractice.exp: Requires land to be restored or conditions complied with.

propertyPractice.q: Stop Notice can prohibit use as a dwelling house.
propertyPractice.exp: Stop notices cannot prohibit use as a dwelling house.

propertyPractice.q: Regularisation Certificate applies to unauthorised planning works.
propertyPractice.exp: It applies to unauthorised *building regulations* works.

propertyPractice.q: Input Tax is VAT paid on goods and services obtained.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax paid by a business to suppliers.

propertyPractice.q: Output Tax is VAT charged on supplies made.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax collected by a business from customers.

propertyPractice.q: FENSA is a self-certification scheme for windows.
propertyPractice.exp: Fenestration Self-Assessment Scheme for building regs compliance.

propertyPractice.q: Japanese Knotweed is an invasive plant species.
propertyPractice.exp: Can cause structural damage; addressed in Form TA6.

propertyPractice.q: CON29O contains optional enquiries.
propertyPractice.exp: Optional questions like common land or pipelines.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor acts for both buyer and lender in a residential purchase; if the buyer reveals a discrepancy in the price, the solicitor must always disclose it to the lender.
propertyPractice.exp: Solicitor has a duty to disclose material information to the lender client (CCS 6.4); if the buyer refuses consent, the solicitor must cease acting.

propertyPractice.q: Under the Standard Conditions of Sale (SCS), the risk of damage to the property passes to the buyer on completion.
propertyPractice.exp: Risk passes to the buyer on exchange of contracts (SCS 5.1).

propertyPractice.q: In a commercial transaction using SCPC, the property is deemed to be a standard-rated supply for VAT by default.
propertyPractice.exp: SCPC Condition 2 provides that the property is a standard-rated supply unless altered by special condition.

propertyPractice.q: A seller giving 'Limited Title Guarantee' warrants that the property is free from all incumbrances.
propertyPractice.exp: Limited guarantee warrants only that the seller has not created incumbrances during their period of ownership.

propertyPractice.q: If a deposit is held as 'agent', the seller can demand the money immediately after exchange.
propertyPractice.exp: An agent holds the money for the seller; a stakeholder cannot release it until completion.

propertyPractice.q: Under Law Society Formula B, the exchange becomes binding when the telephone conversation ends.
propertyPractice.exp: Binding contracts are created at the moment the solicitors agree to the exchange over the phone.

propertyPractice.q: A contract for the sale of land signed by only one party is valid if the other party performs.
propertyPractice.exp: s.2 LP(MP)A 1989 requires the contract to be signed by or on behalf of all parties.

propertyPractice.q: Under SCPC, a buyer is deemed to have knowledge of incumbrances revealed by pre-contract searches they failed to make.
propertyPractice.exp: SCPC 4.1.2 deems the buyer to buy subject to matters a 'prudent buyer' would have discovered.

propertyPractice.q: A seller of an old commercial building (over 3 years) must charge VAT if they have opted to tax.
propertyPractice.exp: The option to tax converts an exempt supply into a standard-rated supply.

propertyPractice.q: Law Society Formula A is used when one solicitor holds both parts of the contract.
propertyPractice.exp: Used where one solicitor holds both signed contracts (e.g., the other is away).

propertyPractice.q: If a buyer fails to complete by the contract time, time automatically becomes 'of the essence'.
propertyPractice.exp: Time is not of the essence until a Notice to Complete is served (SCS 6.1.1 / SCPC 9.1.1).

propertyPractice.q: A 'chain' transaction should use Law Society Formula B with a release of the contract.
propertyPractice.exp: The 'release' method ties the transactions together to ensure simultaneous exchange.

propertyPractice.q: A buyer of a new commercial property (under 3 years old) must pay VAT.
propertyPractice.exp: The sale of new commercial freehold buildings is standard-rated.

propertyPractice.q: Under the Standard Conditions of Sale, the deposit must be paid by solicitor's client account cheque or electronic means.
propertyPractice.exp: SCS 2.2.4; personal cheques are not permitted (unlike older editions).

propertyPractice.q: A seller acting as an administrator usually gives 'Full Title Guarantee'.
propertyPractice.exp: Administrators/Liquidators typically give 'No Title Guarantee' as they have no personal knowledge.

propertyPractice.q: The 'Contract Rate' determines the interest payable for late completion.
propertyPractice.exp: SCS 1.1.1(e); if unspecified, the Law Society interest rate applies.

propertyPractice.q: A special condition is required to make a positive covenant enforceable against a buyer.
propertyPractice.exp: The seller requires an indemnity covenant from the buyer to maintain the chain of indemnity.

propertyPractice.q: If the deposit is 5%, the seller can never claim the full 10% on buyer default.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard conditions usually allow the seller to claim the balance of the 10% if the buyer defaults.

propertyPractice.q: The CLLS Certificate of Title allows the solicitor to qualify statements with disclosures.
propertyPractice.exp: The solicitor must disclose exceptions to the standard statements (e.g., missing planning).

propertyPractice.q: A Transfer of a Going Concern (TOGC) attracts VAT at 20%.
propertyPractice.exp: A qualifying TOGC is outside the scope of VAT (effectively tax-free).

propertyPractice.q: The Standard Conditions of Sale default completion time is 1:00 pm.
propertyPractice.exp: The default time is 2:00 pm (SCS 6.1.2).

propertyPractice.q: An oral agreement to sell land is valid if there is part performance.
propertyPractice.exp: s.2 LP(MP)A 1989 abolished part performance; contracts must be in writing.

propertyPractice.q: A solicitor giving an undertaking to send the deposit must have the funds in their account.
propertyPractice.exp: Solicitors cannot give an undertaking they cannot perform (misconduct).

propertyPractice.q: In a residential sale, the purchase price is inclusive of VAT under SCS.
propertyPractice.exp: SCS 1.4.1; the price is deemed to include VAT (if any).

propertyPractice.q: The 'Occupier's Consent' special condition is used to override beneficial interests.
propertyPractice.exp: Adult occupiers sign to waive rights and agree to vacate, ensuring vacant possession.

propertyPractice.q: s.2 Law of Property (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1989 governs land contracts.
propertyPractice.exp: Requires writing, incorporation of all terms, and signatures of both parties.

propertyPractice.q: SCS stands for Standard Conditions of Sale.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard terms used primarily for residential property transactions.

propertyPractice.q: SCPC stands for Standard Commercial Property Conditions.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard terms used primarily for commercial property transactions.

propertyPractice.q: A 'Stakeholder' holds the deposit for both parties.
propertyPractice.exp: Money cannot be released to the seller until completion.

propertyPractice.q: Full Title Guarantee implies the seller has the right to sell.
propertyPractice.exp: Also implies the property is free from undisclosed charges/incumbrances.

propertyPractice.q: Limited Title Guarantee is typically given by Executors.
propertyPractice.exp: Reflects their limited knowledge of the property's history.

propertyPractice.q: An 'Undertaking' is a binding professional promise made by a solicitor.
propertyPractice.exp: Failure to fulfill an undertaking is professional misconduct.

propertyPractice.q: Formula B involves exchange of contracts by telephone.
propertyPractice.exp: The most common method where solicitors hold their own client's signed contract.

propertyPractice.q: Formula C is used for 'chain' transactions.
propertyPractice.exp: Designed to synchronise exchange across multiple linked transactions.

propertyPractice.q: A 'Certificate of Title' confirms the property is good security for the lender.
propertyPractice.exp: Solicitor certifies the title is marketable and valid.

propertyPractice.q: CLLS stands for City of London Law Society.
propertyPractice.exp: Produces the long-form Certificate of Title for commercial lending.

propertyPractice.q: VAT 'Output Tax' is charged on sales.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax collected by a business on its supplies.

propertyPractice.q: VAT 'Input Tax' is paid on purchases.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax paid by a business on goods/services it buys.

propertyPractice.q: An 'Exempt Supply' attracts no VAT.
propertyPractice.exp: E.g., most residential property/insurance; input tax cannot be reclaimed.

propertyPractice.q: A 'Zero-Rated Supply' is taxable at 0%.
propertyPractice.exp: E.g., new residential builds; allows input tax recovery.

propertyPractice.q: 'Caveat Emptor' applies to the physical condition of the property.
propertyPractice.exp: Buyer beware; seller generally has no duty to disclose physical defects.

propertyPractice.q: A 'Special Condition' amends the standard conditions.
propertyPractice.exp: Tailored clauses to suit the specific transaction.

propertyPractice.q: 'Contra Proferentem' construes ambiguity against the drafter.
propertyPractice.exp: Interpretation rule for contracts.

propertyPractice.q: 'Vacant Possession' means the property is empty of people and chattels.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard requirement on completion unless sold subject to tenancy.

propertyPractice.q: 'Indemnity Covenant' protects the seller against future liability.
propertyPractice.exp: Buyer agrees to observe positive covenants and cover the seller's loss.

propertyPractice.q: 'Engrossment' is the final version of the document for signing.
propertyPractice.exp: The agreed text printed on durable paper (traditionally).

propertyPractice.q: 'Ejusdem Generis' limits general words to the same kind as specific words.
propertyPractice.exp: Interpretation rule (e.g., 'cats, dogs and other animals' excludes tigers).

propertyPractice.q: A 'Recital' sets out the background to a deed.
propertyPractice.exp: Usually starts with 'Whereas'; aids interpretation but is not operative.

propertyPractice.q: 'Time is of the essence' means late performance is a breach allowing termination.
propertyPractice.exp: Only applies if expressly stated or Notice to Complete is served.

propertyPractice.q: The 'Option to Tax' makes a commercial property VAT standard-rated.
propertyPractice.exp: Voluntary election by the owner to charge VAT on rents/sale.

propertyPractice.q: Under the Code for Completion by Post, the seller's solicitor acts as agent for the buyer's solicitor on completion.
propertyPractice.exp: The seller's solicitor acts as agent for the buyer's solicitor.

propertyPractice.q: The priority period for an OS1 search is 30 calendar days.
propertyPractice.exp: The priority period is 30 *working* days.

propertyPractice.q: Failure to register a company charge within 21 days makes the charge void against a liquidator.
propertyPractice.exp: It must be registered at Companies House within 21 days of creation.

propertyPractice.q: SDLT must be paid within 30 days of completion.
propertyPractice.exp: SDLT must be paid within 14 days; LTT (Wales) is 30 days.

propertyPractice.q: A buyer's solicitor must carry out a bankruptcy search (K16) against a corporate borrower.
propertyPractice.exp: K16 is for individuals; a Company Search is used for corporate borrowers.

propertyPractice.q: First registration of unregistered land must occur within 2 months of completion.
propertyPractice.exp: If missed, the transaction becomes void.

propertyPractice.q: Under the Standard Conditions of Sale, time is of the essence from the date of exchange.
propertyPractice.exp: Time is not of the essence until a Notice to Complete is served.

propertyPractice.q: A Notice to Complete gives the parties 10 working days to complete.
propertyPractice.exp: Once served, parties must complete within 10 working days.

propertyPractice.q: The date in Panel 3 of the TR1 transfer deed should be inserted before execution.
propertyPractice.exp: Panel 3 is left blank and dated on completion.

propertyPractice.q: Contractual compensation for delayed completion under SCS is calculated using the Law Society interest rate.
propertyPractice.exp: Unless a different contract rate is specified.

propertyPractice.q: If a buyer fails to complete, the seller can immediately rescind the contract.
propertyPractice.exp: The seller must serve a Notice to Complete and wait for it to expire.

propertyPractice.q: A transfer of a portfolio of titles uses form TR5.
propertyPractice.exp: TR5 is used for portfolio transfers; TR1 for whole titles.

propertyPractice.q: A transferee must execute the TR1 if they are entering into a new covenant.
propertyPractice.exp: Execution is required if the buyer gives an indemnity covenant or declaration of trust.

propertyPractice.q: Land Charges searches (K15) confer a priority period of 30 working days.
propertyPractice.exp: They confer a priority period of 15 working days.

propertyPractice.q: Under the Code for Completion by Post, the seller's solicitor undertakes to redeem the mortgage.
propertyPractice.exp: Undertaking to redeem (pay off), not strictly to discharge.

propertyPractice.q: Private Residence Relief (PRR) applies if the property was used exclusively for business.
propertyPractice.exp: PRR is for main homes; business use excludes relief.

propertyPractice.q: VAT is payable on the sale of a commercial property more than 3 years old without an option to tax.
propertyPractice.exp: It is an exempt supply unless the seller opts to tax.

propertyPractice.q: In the principal method of accounting for disbursements, VAT is recorded in the client ledger.
propertyPractice.exp: VAT is recorded in the VAT account and business cash sheet.

propertyPractice.q: A seller's solicitor can release a deposit held as stakeholder before completion.
propertyPractice.exp: Stakeholder deposits must be held until completion.

propertyPractice.q: The time for completion under the Standard Conditions of Sale is 1:00 pm.
propertyPractice.exp: The standard time is 2:00 pm.

propertyPractice.q: An OS2 search is used for a lease of part.
propertyPractice.exp: OS2 searches part of a registered title.

propertyPractice.q: Capital Gains Tax is charged on the total sale proceeds.
propertyPractice.exp: It is charged on the *gain* (disposal value minus acquisition/allowable costs).

propertyPractice.q: A company executes a deed by the signature of one director in the presence of a witness.
propertyPractice.exp: s.44 Companies Act 2006; allows single director + witness.

propertyPractice.q: The buyer's solicitor sends the completion monies to the seller's lender directly.
propertyPractice.exp: Money is sent to the seller's solicitor, who undertakes to redeem the mortgage.

propertyPractice.q: Receipt of mortgage funds from a lender client is a Credit to the Client Ledger.
propertyPractice.exp: Client money received: Credit Client Ledger, Debit Cash Sheet.

propertyPractice.q: TR1 is the form for Transfer of Whole.
propertyPractice.exp: Transfer of whole registered title.

propertyPractice.q: TP1 is the form for Transfer of Part.
propertyPractice.exp: Used when selling part of a title.

propertyPractice.q: OS1 is an Official Search of Whole.
propertyPractice.exp: Protects priority for the whole title.

propertyPractice.q: DS1 is a form to discharge a registered charge.
propertyPractice.exp: Used to remove a mortgage from the register.

propertyPractice.q: AP1 is the application form to change the register.
propertyPractice.exp: Used for registered land post-completion.

propertyPractice.q: FR1 is the application form for First Registration.
propertyPractice.exp: Used for unregistered land.

propertyPractice.q: SDLT stands for Stamp Duty Land Tax.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax on land transactions in England.

propertyPractice.q: LTT stands for Land Transaction Tax.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax on land transactions in Wales.

propertyPractice.q: TA13 is the form for Completion Information and Undertakings.
propertyPractice.exp: Standard Law Society form for requisitions.

propertyPractice.q: K16 is a Bankruptcy Search.
propertyPractice.exp: Carried out against individual borrowers.

propertyPractice.q: A Solvency Search checks for company liquidation.
propertyPractice.exp: Carried out against corporate parties.

propertyPractice.q: Engrossment means the final version of a document for signing.
propertyPractice.exp: Printing the agreed text for execution.

propertyPractice.q: CGT stands for Capital Gains Tax.
propertyPractice.exp: Tax on profit from disposing of assets.

propertyPractice.q: Rescission puts parties back in their pre-contract position.
propertyPractice.exp: Setting aside the contract.

propertyPractice.q: Double Entry requires one Credit and one Debit.
propertyPractice.exp: Fundamental accounting principle.

propertyPractice.q: Attestation Clause is where a witness signs.
propertyPractice.exp: Formalities for executing a deed.

propertyPractice.q: Telegraphic Transfer (TT) is a method of bank transfer.
propertyPractice.exp: Used to send completion monies.

propertyPractice.q: Redemption Statement shows the amount to pay off a mortgage.
propertyPractice.exp: Obtained from the lender before completion.

propertyPractice.q: Indemnity Covenant protects the seller against positive covenants.
propertyPractice.exp: Chain of indemnity.

propertyPractice.q: Certificate of Title confirms good title to the lender.
propertyPractice.exp: Request for drawdown of funds.

propertyPractice.q: A legal lease for exactly three years must be created by deed.
propertyPractice.exp: A tenancy of 3 years or under may be created in writing or orally (s.54(2) LPA 1925).

propertyPractice.q: An agreement for lease is necessary in every commercial lease transaction.
propertyPractice.exp: It is only needed if parties want to bind themselves before they are ready to complete (e.g., construction pending).

propertyPractice.q: In a rent review, the tenant's voluntary improvements should be disregarded.
propertyPractice.exp: It is unfair for the tenant to pay higher rent for value they created (Hypothetical Lease terms).

propertyPractice.q: Under the Code for Leasing Business Premises, producing written heads of terms is mandatory.
propertyPractice.exp: Mandatory requirement for RICS members/regulated firms under the 2020 Code.

propertyPractice.q: A tenant taking a lease of a new building should exclude 'inherent defects' from their repairing obligation.
propertyPractice.exp: Tenants should not pay for structural/design faults in new builds.

propertyPractice.q: In a lease of part, the tenant is directly responsible for repairing the building's structure.
propertyPractice.exp: The landlord repairs the structure/common parts and recovers costs via service charge.

propertyPractice.q: A lease of 5 years must be registered at the Land Registry.
propertyPractice.exp: Only leases granted for more than 7 years must be registered.

propertyPractice.q: If a rent review is late, the new rent is backdated to the review date.
propertyPractice.exp: The tenant must pay the difference plus interest for the delay period.

propertyPractice.q: An 'upwards only' rent review allows the rent to decrease if market rates fall.
propertyPractice.exp: The rent remains the same if the market rate is lower than the current rent.

propertyPractice.q: A tenant on a 6-month lease of a dilapidated warehouse should accept a full repairing obligation.
propertyPractice.exp: A qualified repairing obligation (limited to a schedule of condition) is appropriate for short terms/poor states.

propertyPractice.q: The 'hypothetical lease' assumes the landlord has complied with all their covenants.
propertyPractice.exp: Assuming landlord compliance is unfair to the tenant if the actual building is neglected.

propertyPractice.q: A landlord's solicitor acting for an RICS member must ignore the Code for Leasing Business Premises.
propertyPractice.exp: Solicitors should be familiar with the Code as their client/agent may be bound by it.

propertyPractice.q: Pre-completion searches for a lease grant include an OS1 if the landlord's title is registered.
propertyPractice.exp: OS1 (whole) or OS2 (part) gives a priority period for registration.

propertyPractice.q: A 'turnover rent' is based on the retail prices index.
propertyPractice.exp: Turnover rent is based on the tenant's business revenue at the property.

propertyPractice.q: In a lease of whole, the tenant usually pays the insurance premium directly to the insurer.
propertyPractice.exp: The landlord insures and recovers the cost from the tenant as 'insurance rent'.

propertyPractice.q: The landlord executes the Counterpart Lease.
propertyPractice.exp: The landlord executes the Original; the tenant executes the Counterpart.

propertyPractice.q: SDLT on a new lease is calculated based on the Net Present Value of the rent.
propertyPractice.exp: Commercial lease SDLT involves a complex formula converting rent to a capital figure.

propertyPractice.q: The Code for Leasing Business Premises applies to agricultural holdings.
propertyPractice.exp: It applies to commercial business premises (exemptions include short lets/agricultural).

propertyPractice.q: A 'stepped rent' increases annually by a fixed percentage.
propertyPractice.exp: Stepped rent is fixed at specific amounts for specific periods (e.g., £25k yr 1, £30k yr 2).
